editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Â¶A dyaloge of syr Thomas More knyghte: one of the counsayll of oure souerayne lorde the kyng & chauncellour of hys duchy of Lancaster. wherin be treatyd dyuers maters / as of the veneration & worshyp of ymagys & relyques / prayng to sayntys / & goyng oÌ pylgrymage. wyth many othere thyngys touchyng the pestylent sect of Luther and Tyndale / by the tone bygone in Saxony / and by the tother laboryd to be brought in to Englond

div.head: The preface
div.p:
Â¶Hyt ys aÌ olde sayd saw / that one bysynes bygettyth and bryngeth forthe a nother. whych prouerbe as hit happeth I fynde very trew by my selfe / whych haue bene fayne by occasyoÌ first of one busygnes a â¢â¢ er to take the second / and vppoÌ the seconde now to take yâ¢ thyrd. For where as a ryght worshyp â¢ ull freÌd of myne sent â¢ ny vnto me a secret sure frende of hys wyth certayne credence to be declared vnto me / towchyng many such maters as beyng in dede very certayne and owte of doute / be nethelesse of late by lewd peple put in questy on / the specyaltees whereof doo so ferforth in the furst chapyter of thys boke appere / that we shall here nede no rehersall therof / I thought yt fyrst Inough to tell ye messeÌger my mynd by mouth / accoÌptyng yt af â¢ er our coÌmunycacyon ended / I shuld neuer nede ferther busynes therin. But after that the messenger was departed / & I felte my stomake well eased / in yt I rekened all my laboure done / by thynkyng my selfe a lytle whyle theron / my busynes that I toke for fynyshed I fo â¢ nd very farre fro that poynt and lytle more than bygonne. For whan I consydred what yâ¢ matters were / and how many greate thingys had bene treated bytwene the messenger and me / and in what maner fashyone / albe it I mystrustyd not his good wyll / and very well trustede hys wyt / his lernyng / well seruyng hym to the perseuyng and reportyng of our coÌmunycacyon / yet fyndyng oure treatye so dyuerse and so long / and sumetyme such wyse intrycate that my self could not wythout labour call it orderly to mind / me thought I had not well done wythout wrytynge to trust hys onely memory / namely sith sum partê­ of the mater be such of theym selfe as rather nede to be attentely redde & aduysed / thaÌ houerly hard and passyd ouer. And ouer this I coÌsidred yt thogh I nothynge suspecte the messenger / as in good faythe I do not / and to saye ye trouthe am of my self so lytle mystrustyng / that he were â¢â¢ ke very pl â¢ ynly to shew hym selfe nought whom I shulde take for badde / yet sith no man caÌ loke in to a nothers breste / as yt ys therfore well done to deme the beste / so were yt not mich amysse in sych wyse to êuyde for the worste / as (yf a man happe to be worse thaÌ we take him for) our good opynyon turne vs to none harme. For thys cause me thought that for ye more suertye my parte were to sende our coÌ munycacyon to my sayd frende in wrytynge. wherby yf yt had happed yt hys messenger had for eny synyster fauou â¢ borne toward the wronge side purposely mangled ye matter / his mayster shuld not oÌly know the treuth / but also haue occacyon the better be ware of hys messeÌger / which ellys myght hape to hurte whyle he were mystakeÌ for good. Now whan I had vppon thys delyberacyon taken wyth my self / wrytteÌ all ye mater and sente hyt to my frende / than had I me thought all done and my mynd full sett at reste. But that reste rested not long. For sone after was yt shewed me that of my wrytynge were wrytten dyuerse copies / And one also caried ouer ye se. where whan I remembred what a shrewd sorte of our apostatas are asseÌ blede / parte roÌne owte of religyon / and all roÌne owte of the ryghte faythe / me thought grete parell myght aryse yf suÌ of that cumpany whych are confedered & coÌspyred to gether in the sow â¢ ynge & settynge forth of Luthers pestylent he resyes in thys realme / shuld maliciously chaunge my wordys to ye worse / and
so put in prent my booke framed after theyre fantesye. whych whan I wolde afterward reproue & shew ye differeÌce / I myght peraduenture seme for the coloure of my cause to haue amendede myne own vppon the syght of theyrs. For eschewyng whereof I aÌnow dreuen as I say to thys thyrde busynes of publyshyng and puttynge my boke in prynt my self. whereby theyr eÌtrepryse yf they shuld eny such intend / shall I trust be preuented and frustrate. And thys haue I done not all of myne own hed / but after the couÌsayle of other mo thaÌ one. whose aduyce and counsayle for theyr wysdome & lernyng I asked in that byhalf / and whych haue at my requeste vouchesaufed to rede ouer ye boke ere I dyd put yt forth. For albeit that I dare be suÌwhat bold to coÌmen in famylyer maner wt such as for theyr fantesye lyke to aske me of such maters eny questyon accordyng to ye counceyle of saynt Poule / byddynge vs be redy to gyue a rekenyng and to shew a reasonable cause to euery man of ye faythe and hope that we haue / yet to make & put forth eny boke wherin were tretyd eny such thyngys as to wch our fayth / wolde I not presume but yf better lerned than my selfe shulde thynke yt eyther profytable or at the lestwyse harmlese. To whose examinacion and iudgment I dyd the more studyously submyte thys worke for two thyngê­ in specyall amonge dyuerse other. The one for the lyberall allegacyons of the messenger for the wrong parte so layd out at large / that of my selfe I stode halfe in a dowt whyther yt were coÌuenyent to reherse the wordys of eny maÌ so hoÌ ly and in maner sumtyme vnreuerently spoken agaynst goddis holy halows and theyre reuerente memoryes. The tother was certayne taly â¢ & mery wordê­ whych he mynglid wyth his mater / & suÌ such on myne owne parte amonge as occasyon â¢ ell in coÌmunycacyon. In whych albe yt I saw none harme / yet sumwhat dowted I lest they shuld vnto sadd men seme ouer lyght & waÌton for the wayght and grauyte of such an erenest matter. wherfore in these two poyntys though I hade all redy seene some eÌsaÌples of ryght holy meÌ / whych in theyre bokys answeryng to thobieccions of heretiques in theyr tyme haue nott letted to reherse the very formall wordys of theym whose wrytiÌgis they made answere to / beyng sometyme of such maner & sorte as a good maÌ wold not well bere / and haue not also letted to wryte a mery word in a ryght ernest worke / of whych two thyngs I could owte of godly mennys bokis and holy sayntys workys gether a good sorte / yet in mine owne work I determyned that I wold nothyng allow nor defend that the iudgement of other vertuouse and cunnynge men wolde in eny wyse mysse lyke. And therefore after yt such had red hyt and seuerally sayde theyre aduyce / I found as hyt often happith / that sum thynge whyche one wyse and well lernyd manne wolde haue owte / twayne of lyke wysdome and lernyng specyally wolde haue in / neyther syde lackyng good and probable reasoÌe for theyre parte. wherfore syth hyt bycame not me to be iudge ouer the iudgment of theym whome I toke and chose for my iudges / beyng such of them self as hard were yt for eny man to say which of theym byfore the other he coulde in erudyc â¢ on wytt or prudence eny thing preferr / I could no ferther goo but lene to the more parte. whych I so ferforth haue folowed / that lyke wyse as I dyuerse thyngys put owte or chauÌged by theyr good aduyce & counsell / so let I
nothyng staÌd in this boke / but such as twayne aduysyd me specyally to lette stand / agaynst eny one that eny dowt mouyd me to the contrary. And thus mych haue I thought necessary for my declaracyon and excuse to aduertyse you all that shall happen to rede thys rude symple work / prayeng you of pacyence and pardon / whom god of hys especyall grace graunte as mych profyte in ye redyng / as my pore hart hath mente you and eÌtendede in ye making.

div.head: The furst chapyter
div.p: Â¶The letter of credence sent from hys frende by a trusty secret messenger â¢ wyth the letter of ye authore answeryng ye same. The declara â¢ yoÌ of of ye credence by the mouth of ye messenger whereuppon the mater of all the hole worke dependeth.

div.head: Â¶The letter of credence
div.p:
MAster chauncelour as hartely as I possible caÌ I recomend me to you. Not wythoute a thousand thankys for your good cumpany whan we were last to gether. In whyche for as myche as yt liked you to spend sum of your tyme wyth me in famylyer coÌmunycacion / wherof sum ête I truste so to remeÌber as my selfe shall be the better and some other neuer the worse / which shall haue cause and haue all redy to gyue you greate thank therfore / I am bolde at thys tyme to send you my specyall secrete frende thys berer to breke wyth you suÌwhat ferther / partely of ye same matters partely of suÌ other such as are happed there synnys / wherof greate spech and rumour runneth here / wherby ye shall haue occasyoÌ more at leÌgth if your leysour wyll serue to touche certayn dowtes moued synnes of the maters treated betwene vs byfore. wheriÌ were it not for your other busynes I wold be hold on your goodnes to desyre you to take good time ãâã hym. And yet neuere the lesse do require you hartely as your leysour will serue you to satysfy him at the the full. For he shall how longe so euer he tarye therfore / gyue attendaunce vnto you dayes & howers as ye may spare hym tyme. whych can not in these thingê­ be but well bestowed / consyderynge that the matters be such and so to wchynge to god / as they were well worthy to set worldly busynes asyde specyally iÌ such nede. For I assure you soÌ folk here tal â¢ very straungely of the thyngys that he shall moue you / Not onely for suche wordis as they tell yt come froÌ thense / but also most especially thorough tho â¢
casyon of some letters lewdely wrytteÌ hyther owte of londoÌ by a prest or t â¢â¢ whom they take here for honeste. But what so euer eny man tell or wryte / I shall for ye confydence & truste yt I haue in you surely take and tell forth for the very truth what so euer ye shal afferme vnto my frende / whoÌ I sende vnto you not so myche bycause I may not come my selfe (how beyt therfore to) as for bycause I longe to haue hym talke wt you. To whom what so euer ye say reken yt sayde to my selfe / Not only for hys trouth and secretnes / but also for hys memory. wyth whom to coÌmune I trust shall not mislyke you. For eyther myne affeccyoÌ blyndeth me / or ye shall fynd hym wyse / and as other saye that can better iuge yt theÌ I / more theÌ meaÌ ly lernyd / wythe one thynge addede wherewyth ye be wonte well to be content / a very mery wyt. He is of naturre nothynge tonge tayed. And I haue in these maters beden hym be bolde wyth out any straynynge of curtesye / wherof the cerymonyes in dysputacyoÌ marryth mych of ye mater / whyle one studyeth more how he may behaue him than
what he shall saye. I haue I say therefore boden hym more to mynd hys mater theÌ hys curtesy / â¢ frely to lay forthe not oÌly what he thiÌketh / but also what hym lyst / geuyng no fote in dysputing vnto your authorytye but if he be born bak wyth reasoÌ. Thus may ye se I am bold oÌ your goodnes to put you to labour and busynes / and send one to face you in your owne howse. But so mych am yâ¢ I bolder / for that in such chaleÌgê­ I know you for a redy and sure defender. And of such labour your wysdom wel â¢ seeth that god is ye rewarder / who long preserue you & all yours.

div.head: Â¶The lettre of the author sent wyth the boke.
div.p:
Â¶Ryght worshypfull syr after moste harty recoÌmendacyon / albe yt yt of late I sent you my pore mynde by ye mouth of your trusty frend / to whoÌ ye desyred me by your letters to gyue no lesse credence than to your selfe / concernynge all such thyngys as he brake of & coÌmuned wt me in your bihalfe / & yt for ye coÌfydence yt ye haue iÌ hym / ye wyt & lernyng yt I founde in hym / & honestye yt I so moch ye more thynk hym to be of / in yt I perceyue you beyng of such wysedom & vertu / to haue hym in so speryall trust / I nether do nor caÌ beleue ye coÌtrary but yt he hath of all our coÌmunycacyoÌ made you faythfully / playne / & full reporte / yet sythe I suppose in my selfe yt yf we had mought coÌuenyeÌtly cum to gether ye wold rather haue chosiÌ to haue hard my mynde of myn owne mouth thaÌ by ye mean of a nother / I haue siÌnis iÌ these fewe days in whych I haue beÌ at home put ye mater in wrytyng / to thende ye may not only here hyt by the mouth of your frende / but also whych better ys than sodenlye ones to here hit of mine owne mouthe / rede yt yf ye lyste more often at your beste leysure advysydly from myne owne penne. whych thynge I veryly thought my selfe so mych the more bounde to do / for that yt lyked you of your specyall fauour & affeccyoÌ towarde me so greatly to regarde and esteme my myn â¢ & answere iÌ those maters / yt no rumour there ruÌniÌg or talys in your countre tolde or leters thyther wrytten nor reasons or argumeÌtê­ there made to the coÌtrary / shuld lett or wyth â¢â¢ ande but that ye wolde as ye wrote take that thyng for vndowted trouth yt I shulde by your frended acertayn you. And surely syr iÌ thus poiÌt ye may make your selfe sure yt I shall neuer wyllingly deceue your trust. And lest I might happe to do yt of ouer syght vnware / albe yt I nothynge sayde vnto your frende by mouth but that I was ryght well enformyd of the trouth / yet for as mich as I perceyued by hym ye suÌ
â¢ olke dowted le â¢ te many thyngys were layd to the charge / not onely of that man ye wrote of / but also of Luther hym selfe / otherwyse than coud be proued / I dyd so mych therin that I was suffred to se & shewe hym as well ye bokys of ye tone as the very a â¢ tys of ye court coÌcernyng yt tother / yt we myght both by so myche the more surely wartauÌt you ye trouth. wherin yf ye fynde eny man yâ¢ yet dowteth whether he tolde you and I wryte you the trouth or not / I shall yf he vnderstand the laryne tong fynde ye mean at your pleasure that he shall so see the bokys hym selfe / yt were he neuer so full of mystrustynge he shall not fayle to be fully coÌtent & satysfyed. And thys warraÌtyse wyll I make you as farforth as con â¢ erneth eny acte done here. But as for thyngys reasoned and dysputed bytwene vs / ye coÌclusyons selfe be so sure truthes / yt the â¢ be not dysputable. But whither the reasons by me made in theÌ beÌeffectuall or insufficyeÌt / albe it your
frend eyther for yÌ
â¢ of trouth he thought so / or for that of curtesye he sayd so / accepted them for good / yet wthout preiudyce of ye priÌcipall maters ye may your self be iuge. And thus I pray you take in good worthe ye lytle laboure & great good wyll of hym whom in eny thyng yt may do you pleasure / ye maye to the vttermost of hys lytell power well and boldely commauÌd. And thus our lorde send you wt my good lady your bedfelow & all yours as hartely well to fare as ye wolde all wysh.

yOur frende fyrst after your letter redde / whan I demauÌ ded hym hys credence / shewed me that ye had sent hym to me / not for eny dowte that your self had in many of those thingis that he shuld moue vnto me / but for the dowte that ye perceyued in many other / and iÌ sum folke playne parsuasyoÌ to yÌe coÌtrary / whom ye wolde be glad to answere wyth the trouthe / albe yt some thyngys he sayd were also there so talked / that ye wyst not well your self which part ye myght bileue. For it was there not only spokeÌ but also thether wryten by dyuers honest pre â¢â¢ ys owte of londoÌ / yt the maÌ ye wryte of was of many thyngys bor â¢ e wrong in hand / and therin so sore handelyd / that he was forced to forswere & ab â¢ ure certayn herysyes / and opeÌly put to penaunce therfore / where he neuere held eny such. And all thys don for malyce and enuye / partely of some freres agaynste whose abusyons he preched / partly for yt he preched boldly agaynste the pompe and pryde and other inordynate lyuynge that mo men speke of th â¢
Ì preche of vsed in the clargye. And they take for a gret tokyn that he shuld not meane euyll / the prose and experyence whych men haue had of him yt he lyued well and was a good honest vertuouse man farre from ambycyon and desyre of wordly worship / chaste / humble & charytable / free & lyberall in almose dede / and a very goodly prechour / in whose deuowte sermons ye peple were greatly edyfyed. And therfore ye peple say yt all thys gere ys done but onely to stoppe meÌnys mouthys / & to put euery maÌ to sylence yt wold eny thynge speke of the â¢ autys of the clargy. And they thynk yt for none other cause was also burned at Poulys crosse the new testameÌt late traunslated in eÌglyshe by Master wyllyam huchen otherwyse called Master TiÌdall / who was as meÌ say well knowen ere he went ouer the see for a maÌ of ryght good lyuynge / studyouse & well lerned in scrypture / and in dyuerse pl â¢
cys in Englonde was very well lyked & dyd great good wyth prechyng. And men mutter amonge theÌ selfe that the boke was not onely fawtlesse / but also very well traunslatyd / & was deuyse â¢â¢ to be burned bycause meÌ shuld not be able to proue yt such fawtys as were at Poules crosse declared to haue beÌ fouÌ den in it were neuer fouÌdeÌ ther iÌ dede / but vntruly surmised. And yet such as they were sum men say were no fautis at all / if they had be so traÌslated iÌ dede / but blame layed & â¢ awte fouÌd wt thingê­ nothyng ãâã worthy / onely to â¢â¢ face ye holy worke / to thende yt they myght seme to haue some iuste cause to burne yt. And yt for none other cause but for to kepe owt of ye peples haÌd is all knowlege of Cristê­ gospell & of goddis law / excepte so mych onely as ye clargye theÌ self lyste now & thaÌ to tell vs. And that lytle as it is & seldom shewed / yet as it ys fered not well & truly tolde / but watered wt false gloses / & altered from the trouthe of ye very wordis & sentence of scriptur oÌly for ye mayntenauÌs of theyr authoryte. Â¶And yÌ
â¢ fere lest thys thyng
shulde euydentely appere to the people yf they were suffered to rede ye scripture theÌ self in theyr own tong / was as yt is thoght ye very cause not oÌly for whych ye new testameÌt traÌslated by TiÌdale was burned / but also yt ye clargye of thys realme hath bifore thys time by a coÌstitucion prouyncyall prohybyted eny boke of scrypture to be traunslated in to the englysh tonge / ferynge men wyth fyer as herytyques whose so shulde presume to kepe theÌ / As though yt were heresie for a chrysteÌ maÌ to rede crystê­ gospell. Â¶And surely syr quod he sum folke yt thynk thys dealyng of the clargye to be thus / and good men to be myshandlyd for declaryng the trouth / And the scripture selfe to be pulled owte of ye peples handys leste they shulde perceyue the trouthe / be ledde in theyre myndys to dowte whither Luther hiÌ self of whose opinions or at the leste of whose workys all these bysynesse bygan / wrote in dede so euyll as he ys borne in hande. And many men therbe that thynke he neuer mente such thingis. But that bycause he wrote agaynste thabusyons of pardons / and spake suÌwhat lyberally agaynste the courte of Rome / and generally agaynste the vycys of the clargy / therfore he was brought iÌ hatered / and fyrst cyted to Rome. And wh â¢ n yt forfere of bodely harme wyth wrong / whereof yt wolde haue bene to late or loke for remedy after / if he had ones be burnede vp byfore / he durste not come thether / than was he accursed / and hys bokes dampned / & vnder great paynis forbodden to be redd. And that thyng done / bycause it shulde not be knowen what wronge he had / and yt he neyther meaneth nor sayeth such odyouse and abomynable heresyes as the people be borne in hand to enduce them to hatered of hiÌ / as yt wolde êaueÌture appere y â¢ hys b â¢ kis were suffered to be redde. Â¶And they sey that yt were no mastry to make yt seme that a man shulde be aÌ herytyque / yf he may be borne in hand that he sayeth the thynge whych he neuer sayd / or êadueÌture one lyne taken out amonge meny and myscoÌstrewed / not suffering the remnante to be sene / wherby yt myghte more clerely appere what he meanyth. By whych maner of delynge a man they say might lay heresye to saynte poule / and fynde a faute iÌ saynt Iohns gospell. And yet they say the worst of all is this / that the clargye c â¢ ace not hereby nor holde theym selfe content wt the coÌdempnyng of Luther & forbyddyng of hys bokes / but ferther abuse ye hatered of hys name agaynste euery man that ys in prechynge of the word of god eny thiÌg such as he shulde be / that ys to wyit playne and bolde wythout glose or flateryng. where yf they fynde a man fauty / lett theym lay hys fawte to hys charge. what nedythe to call him a Lutherane? Though Luther were a deuyll yet myght a man êcase say as he sayeth in sum thyng and say trew Inough. For neuer was ther herytyqu â¢ that sayd all false. Nor the deuyll hym selfe lyed not wheÌ he called Chryste goddys sonne. And therefore men thynke that this name ãâã Lutherane seruethe the clargye for a coÌmen cloke of a false crune / yt where they lack specyall mater to charge one wyth by iugemente / they laboure to bryng hym fyrste in the infamy of that name that coÌprysyth as they make it seme / a coÌfuted hepe of heresyes no maÌ caÌ tell what. Â¶And yet in such deling they wounde theyre owne mater a nother way. For whyle they de â¢â¢ ame for Lutherany â¢ /m â¢ that be of knowen vertu & cuÌniÌg / what do they therby but oÌe of ye twayn eyther cause the peple yt haue for good
lyuynge and lernyng those meÌ in gret reputacyon to thynke yt the clargye for malice and enuy doth vntruly defame them / or els that Luthers doctryne is good / whyle so cuÌnyng men and good men lene therto. Â¶And therfore yt were wysedome not to call theym Lutheranys / but rather when they teche & holde eny such opynions as the people know for Luthers / let yt eyther be dy â¢
symuled / or they secretly by fayr ways enduced to the contrary / if the poyntê­ that they teche of hys be nought. Leste by callynge good and cunning meÌ Lutherane / they may peradueÌture bryng them selfe in suspycyone of malice and â¢ nuye / And Luther amonge the peple into good opynyoÌ / Thynkyng as they bygynne to doo all redy / that eythere Luther sayd not so euyll as ys surmysed vppon hym / or els that those thyngê­ yt he sayth as odious as they seme / be good inough in dede. Â¶He sayd also yt yt seemed vnto many men a sore thyng and farr vnresonable / that pore symple and vnlerned men all though they fell in to errours and were ledde oute of the ryghte way by yt they lened to thauthoryte of such meÌ as they byleued to be vertuouse & â¢ uÌnyng / shuld in stede of teching be beteÌ cruelly wyth abiuracyons and opyn shame / wyth êell of burnyng also / yf a few false wytnesse shall after such abiuracyoÌ depose yt they haue harde hym fall in relapse. Â¶Fynally he sayde yt many good and well lernyd men thought playnly that ye clargye semyth farre owt of all good order of cheryte / and that they do contrary to the myldnesse and mercyfull mynde of theyre ma â¢â¢ er / and agaynste theÌsample of all the olde holy fathers / in yt they cause for eny errour or wroÌg opynion in the faythe / eny man one or other to be put to deth.

Â¶For they say that ye olde holy fathers vsed only to dyspute wyth heritiques / techyng them and conuyctynge them by scrypture / and not by fagottê­. And that by that way the fayth wente well forwarde / and one heritique so turnyd dyd torne many othere / where as now meÌ abhorre thys crueltie in the church. And they that seme turned / think styll the thyngê­ that they dare not say. And of thasshes of one herytyke spryng vp many. And that now we make the fassyon of crystendom to seme all turned quyte vpp so down. For wher as Crist made infydelis the persequutours and hys crysteÌ peple the su â¢â¢ rers / we make the chrysten men the persecutours and the infydelys the sufferers. wherby meÌ thynke that secretly Christys order yet standeth styll though yt be not so t â¢ kin and so perceyued. For the peple take yt that styll those that êsequute be ye myscrea â¢
Ìtys / and those pore peple yt suffer yt / be vnder the false name of heretyques the trew byleuyng men and very chrysten martyrs.

Â¶Cryst also they sey wold neuer haue eny man coÌpelled by force and vyoleÌce to byleue vppon hys fayth / nor wolde that men shulde fyght for hym or hys maters. In so farforthe yt he wolde not suffer â¢ aynt peter to fyght for hys own selfe / but repreuyd hym for strykynge Malchus. Nor wold not defeÌd hiÌ self / but helyng the ere agayn of Malchus his persecutour whych Peter had smitten of / and geuyng all his holy body to the pacyent sufferauÌce of all paynefull turmentys that hys cruell enmyes wolde put to it / shewed vs as well by hys effectuall ensaumple of hys dethe / as by hys godly counceyle in hys lyfe / and after that confyrmed by the contynuall pa â¢ syoÌ and marterdums of hys holy martyrs / that hys wyll & pleasure
is that we shulde not so myche as defende our selfe agaynst herytyquys & infidelys / were they paganys turkys or sarasinys. And mich lesse thaÌ shuld we fyght agaynst theym and kyll theÌ / but that we shulde perseuer in setting forth hys fayth agaynst myscreauntis and infidellys / by suche wayes as him selfe began it / keepe it / and encreace it as it was gotteÌ / And that was by pacyence and su â¢â¢â¢ raunce by whyche the fayth was dyuulgate and sprede allmost thorow the world in litle while. Not by warre & fyghting / whych way hath as thay say well nere all redy lost all that the tother way wanne.

Â¶when your frend had thus declared his credeÌs / he desyred me both oÌ your byhalfe and on hys owne in such thingys as were parcas not well sayde to take theÌ as they were iÌ dede the mind of other / whome ye wold fayne answere and satysfye wyth resone / which ye trustyd to be the better able to do by myne aÌswer / and neyther the mind nor opynyon of you nor hym / whych dyd and wold in all thyng stand and abyde by the fayth & byleue of Crystê­ catholyk chyrche. But as for suche êtys of thys mater as concernyd not eny parte of our beleue but the dealiÌg of thys worlde / as the iustyce or vniustyce of sum spyrytuall personys in the pursuyng and condempnyng meÌ for heretyquys or theyr werkys for heresyes / he thought he sayd as of hym selfe that meÌ myght wtoute eny parell of heresy for theyr owne parte notwt standyng eny mannes iudgemeÌt geuin yet well and resonably dowt ther in / For though he thought it heresy to thynke thopynyons of eny man to be good and catholyque whych beÌ herisyes in dede / yet might a maÌ he thought wythout eny parell of heresy dowte whether he were aÌ herytyke or no that were by mannys iudgment coÌdempned for one / syth it myght well happeÌ that he neuer held those opinions that were put vppon hym / but that he was eyther by fals deposycyons of wrong full wytnes / or by the error or malyce of vniust iudges condempnyd. And that sometyme percase the ignorauÌce of som iudges wold coÌdemne for heresye such artycles as wyser and better lernyd wold in poynt of iudgment alow for good and catholyque / and of the tother iudgment decerne & iudge the contrary.

Â¶How be yt he sayd that ye had iÌ me and my lernyng so specyall trust & coÌ fydens / that in any of all these thiÌgys what so euer ye had herd or shuld here ellis where / ye were fully determynyd to gyue full credeÌce to me & take for ye trouth such answere as he shuld briÌg you from me / whereiÌ ye ryght hartely desired me to take some paine that ye myght in these maters by hys mouth know my mynde at large /

Â¶After thys or I made eny aÌswere to hys wordys / I demaunded him what maner acquayntaunce was bytwene hym and you. And theruppon perceyuyng hym to haue your soÌnes at scole enqueryng farther of hym to what faculte he had most geuyn his study / vnderstode hym to haue geuyn dylygeÌce to the latyn tonge / As for other facultyes he rought not of. For he tolde me merily that Logyk he rekenyd but babelyng / Musyke to serue for syngers / Arythmetryk mete for merchauÌtê­ / Geometry for masons / Astronomy good for no man / And as for Phylosophy ye most vanyte of all / And that yt & Logyk had lost all good deuynyte wyth ye
subteltyes of theyre questyons / and babelyng of theyre dyspycyons / Byldyng all vppon reason / whych rather geuith blyndnes thaÌ any light. For maÌ he sayd hath no lyght but of holy scripture. And therfore he sayde that biside the latyne tonge he had ben / whych I mych coÌmende / studiouse in holy scripture / whych was he sayed lernyng I nough for a Crystyn man / wyth which thapposteles held theÌ self coÌtent. And therin he saide he labored not onely to can many textys therof by hart / but also to enserche the sentence and vnderstandyng therof as ferre as he myght perceyue by hym selfe. For as for interpretours he tolde me that neyther hys tyme wolde well serue hym to rede / & also he founde so great swetnes in the texte selfe / that he coulde not fynde in his harte to lese eny tyme in the glosi â¢ . And as towchyng eny defycultye he said that he founde by experience that the beste and surest interpretacioÌ was to ley and conferre one texte wyth an other / whych â¢ ayle not amonge theym well & sufficiently to declare theim self. And thys waye he sayde that he vsyde whych he founde sufficient and surest. For so shulde it most surely tary / when yt were founden owte and lernyd by a maÌnes owne laboure. And that he said was euery maÌ able Inough to do wyth helpe of god whych neuer faylith theym that faythfully truste in hys êmyse. And he hath promysid that if we seke we shall fynde / And if we knocke we shall haue it openyde to vs. And what shalbe openid? but yâ¢ booke which as seynt IohÌn saith iÌ thapocalips is so shytt wyth .vii. clapses that it can not be openyd but by the lambe that whan he shetteth then caÌ no maÌ open it / and whan he openyth it than can no man shytt it. Â¶UppoÌ these wordys & other lyke whan I consyderyde that youre frend was studiouse of scrypture / and all though I now haue a very goode opynyon of hym / nor at that tyme hade not all the contrary / yet to be playne wt you and him both / by reason that he set the mater so well and lustely forward / he put me somwhat in dowte whether he were as yong scolers be suÌtime êne to new fantesyes / fallen in to luthers secte. And that ye peradueÌture suÌwhat feryng the same / dyd of good mynde the rather sende hym to me wyth such a message / for that ye trustyd he shuld be sumwhat aÌswered and satysfied by me. I therfore thought it not metely iÌ so many maters and wegh â¢ y to make hym an vnaduysed answere / but wyth good wordys welcomyng him for the time pteÌdyng lake of leysour for other psent bisines / requyred him to retorne on the morow / Against whych tyme I wold so order myne other affares that we wold haue conference to gether of all hys erande at length. And he in this wyse beyng departyde I beganne to gather in mynde the hole effecte as my rememberaunce wolde serue me of all that he had purposyd. And bycause I wolde haue yt the more redy at myne eye / so that I myght the more fully & effectually answere it leuyng no parte vntouchyd in suche order as he hade purposyd yt that is to wytt after the maner that I haue aboue rehersyd / I bryefely commyttyd yt to wrytynge

div.head: Â¶The second chapyter
div.p:
Â¶ Here suÌmaryly is declared what order the Author intendyth to trete of the matters purposyd vnto hym. wherof because the fyrst was an oppynyon conceyued in some mennys heddes that a certayn parsoÌlate abiured
of heresy for preching against pilgrymagys & ymagis and prayers made to sayntê­ was therin greately wronged / ye author breuely declareth hys mynde concernyng the confutacyon of those perylouse and pernycyouse opy â¢ yons.

ON yâ¢ morow whan he was cuÌ men agayne sumwhat before vii. of the clocke (for so I appoynted hym) takyng hym wyth me in to my stody / and my saruantys warned that yf any other shulde happen to desyre to speke wyth me / certayne excepte of whome I gaue theym knowlege / they shulde dy â¢â¢ erre theym tyll a nother leysor / I sett hym downe wyth me at a litle table. And then I shewed vnto hym that where he had purposed on your byhalf in short wordys many long thyngê­ wherof the rehersall were losse of tyme to hym that so well knew theym all redy / I wolde all suê â¢ iuous recapytulacyon sett aparte / as brefely as I conuenyently coulde / shew hym my mynde in theym all. And fyrst bygyn where he bygan at the abiuracyon of the man he spake. SecuÌdly wold I touche the condempnacyon and burnyng of ye new testament traunslated by Tyndale. Thyrdly sumwhat wold I speke of Luther & hys secte in generall. Forthly and fynally ye thyng that he touched laste that is to wytt yâ¢ wart and fyghtyng agaynst infydelys wyth the condemnacyoÌ of heretyques vnto deth / whych twoo poynty â¢ hym selfe had combyned and knytte to gether. Â¶And fyrst as touchyng the mater of the mannes ab â¢â¢ racyon where it is reported that the spyrytualtye dyd hym wrong. And for to make that seme lykly there is layed in theym displeasure / malice & â¢â¢â¢ y toward hym â¢ or peech â¢ ng as ye say quod I agaynst theyer vycyouse lyuyng / And in hym is on the tother syde alegyd myche connyng vertue and goodnes. I wyll neyther enter in to the prayse of theym nor in to the dyspreyse of hym / wherein standyth nothyng theffecte of thys mater / For if the â¢ e dyd / I wold not passe ouer suÌ parte therof so shortely.

Â¶But now for thys mater all though the hole spyrytualtye / wherin no man dowtith to be â¢
â¢ any a ryght vertuous and godly man / were in theyre lyuyng farr wors than deuyllê­ / yet yf they did that maÌ no wrong / there hath for this matter no man agaynst them eny caus to coÌplayn. And ouer thys yf that man were in all hys other lyuynge as innocent as a saynt / yet yf he were infected & fautye in these herysyes / he had than in thys matter no wrong. And yet besyde all thys yf he not onely were in all other thyngê­ very vertuous / but also were of all thoese heresyes whereof he was detected vtterly clene and fautles / yet yf it were by suffycyent wytnes / were they neuer so fals in dede / seming honest and lykely to say trew / prouyd in opyn courte that he was fauty ther in / albeyt in suche case hys wytnessys had wronged hym / yet had hys iudges done hym but ryght. And therfore letting passe as I say yâ¢ praysse or dysprayse of either hys iudgê­ or him / as thyngys impertinent to yâ¢ point / I will shew you yt they not onely dyd hym no wrong / but also shewed hym / in my mynd the gretest fauour / And vsed toward hym the most charytable â¢â¢ rcy yt euer I wy â¢â¢ vsyd to eny man in â¢ uch case. And fyrst as for any wron â¢ yt hys iudgi â¢ did hy â¢ /I mer â¢ ell me ãâã wher in they that report yt could assygn â¢ it. for yf â¢ ny were done him â¢ it must n â¢â¢ ê­
haue ben in one of the twoo thyngys / eyther in that he was vntruly iudgyd to haue pchyd such artycles as he was detectyd of where he pchyd none such in dede / or ellys in that sum such artycles as he prechyd were iudeged & condemned for heresyes where they were none in dede. Excepte that any man wolde say that though he were proued and conuyctyd of heresye yet he shuld haue bene put to no penaunce at all or ellys to no such as he was. And of that poynt if eny maÌ so thynk / I shall speke in yâ¢ fourth parte where we shall towch in generall the ordre that the chyrche takyth in the condemnacyon of herytyques. But as for the tother poyntys fyrst if eny preest wrote owte of londoÌ in to your cuntraye that eny such artycle of hys prechyng was by hys iudeges declared for herysy as were in dede good & not ageynst the fayth of crystys chyrch / lett hym name what artycle / And eyther ye shall fynde that he shall name you such as yâ¢ man was not charged wyth all / or ellys shall ye fynde yt such as he shall name you were such in dede as your selfe shall pceyue for heresyes at your ere / For yâ¢ artycles where wyth he was chargede were yt we shuld do no worshyppe to eny ymages / nor pray to enyseyntys / or go on pylgrymagys / whyth thyngys I suppose euery good crystyn man wyll agre for heresyes. And therfore we shall lett that poynt passe and so resort to the secund â¢ o se why â¢ her it were well prouy â¢ that he preched them or no. Syr quod your â¢â¢ end I wold for my parte well agree theym for â¢â¢ rysys / but yet haue I ha â¢â¢ some or thy â¢ that wold not d â¢ so â¢ And therfore w â¢ an we â¢ all they â¢ herysye â¢ it were well ãâã to tell why / â¢ ythse â¢â¢ men wold (I we â¢ e yf they myghte ãâã hard) â¢ tyffly say nay / whych now hold theyre pease & bere theym selfe full coldely that wold take ye mater more hote saue for burniÌg of theyr lyppys. Now forsoth quod I who so euer wyll say yt these be no heresyes / he shall not haue me to dispute it which haue no cuÌning in such maters / but as it best becuÌmyth a ley man to do in all thyngys / lene & cleue to the comem fayth / and byleue of crystê­ chyrch. And therby do I plaiÌ ly know it for an herysye / if an herysye be a secte and a syde way takyn by any part of such as bene bap â¢ ysyd and bete the name of crystyn men froÌ the comeÌ fayth and byleefe of the hole chyrch besyde. For thys am I very sure and perceyue it well not only by experyens of myne one tyme & the placys were my selfe hath bene wyth commen report of other honest meÌ from all other placys of crystyndome / but by bokys also & rememberauncys lefte of long tyme wyth wrytyng of the olde holy fathers and now sayntys in heuyn / that from thappostles tyme hytherto this maner hath ben vsyd / taught & allowed / and the contrary comoÌly condenyd throgh ye hole flok of all good crysten people. Â¶And as touchyng such textê­ as thes â¢ heretykys allege agaynst the worshyppyng of ymagys / prayeng to sayntys / and goyng oÌ pylgrymages / as they ley the law geuen to the Iewes. Non facies tibi s â¢ u â¢ p â¢â¢ e / â¢ how shalt carue the none ymag â¢ . And the psalme. In e â¢ i â¢ u Israell â¢ de egipto / And s â¢ l â¢ deo honor et gloria / only to god be honor & glory. And ma â¢â¢ dictus â¢ ui coÌfidit in homine. Accursed is he that putteth hys truste in man wyth many suche other lyke / whych herytyques haue of old euer ha â¢
ked agaynst chrystys catholyk chyrch / very su â¢ e am I yt saynt Austen / saynt â¢
hierome / saint basyle / saint gregory wt so many a godly cunnyng maÌ as hath ben in crystis church from ye begynyng hytherto / vnderstod those textê­ as wel as dyd those heretyques / Namely hauyng as good wittê­ / beyng farr better lernid / vsing in stody more diligence / beyng an hepe to an handfull / & which most ys of all hauyng / as god by many myracles beryth wytnes / besyde theyr lernyng the lyght and clerenes of hys especyall grace / by whych they were inwardly taught of hys only spyryt to êceyue that the word is spokyn in the old law to the iewys people prone to Idolatry / and yet not to all theym nether / For the preestys than had the ymagis of thangell cherubin in the secret place of the temple / shulde haue no place to forbyd imagis among his crysten flok / where hys pleasure wold be to haue ye ymage of hys blessed body haÌgyng on hys holy crosse / had in honour and reuerent remembraunce. where ãâã wold vouchsaufe to send vnto the kyng abiagarus the ymage of hys owne face / where he lykyd to leue the holy vernacle thexpresse ymage also of hys blessid vysage as a token to remayn iÌ honour amoÌg such as louyd hym from ye tyme of hys bytter passyon hytherto. whych as it was by the myracle of hys blessid holy haÌd expressed and lefte iÌ yâ¢ sudari / so hath yt bene by lyke myracle in that thyn corruptyble cloth kepte and preseruyd vncorrupted thys .xv.C. yere freshe and well perceyued to ye iÌwarde cumfort / spyrytuall reioysyng & grete encreace of feruoure and deuocyon in the hartê­ of good crysten people. Crist also taught hys holy euangelyst saynt luke to haue an nother maner mynde toward ymagis than haue these heretyques / whan he put in hys mynde to counterfete and expresse in a table the louely vysage of oure blessed lady hys mother. He taught also saynt amphibalus the mayster and techer of the holy fyrst martyr of englond saynt albane to bere about and worshyppe yâ¢ crucyfyx. who shewed also saynt albane him self in a vysyon ye ymage of ye crucyfyx but god: whych thyng wrought iÌ that holy man so strongly / that he with few wordê­ of saynt amphybalus at yâ¢ sight of that blessed ymage whych our lorde had before shewid hym iÌ hys slepe was clene turned to chrystendome / And in the worshyping of yâ¢ same ymage was taken and brought forth to iudgemeÌt & afterward to marterdome.

Â¶And there ys no man but yf he loue a nother he delitith iÌ his ymage or enythyng of hys. And these heretyques yt be so sore agaynst the ymagis of god & hys holy sayntis wold be yet ryght angry with â¢â¢ n yt wold dishonestly handle an ymage made in remembraunce of hiÌ self / where yâ¢ wrethis forbere not vilanously to handle and to cast dyrte in dispyte vppon the holy crucyfyx anymage made in remembraunce of our sauiour hym selfe / and not only of his most blessyd êson but also of hys most bytter passion.

Â¶Now as touching prayer made vnto the sayntis and worshyp done vnto theym / mich meruayle is it what cause of malice these heretykê­ haue to them. we se yt commen in the wreched coÌdycyon of thys world that one man of a pride in him self hath enuy at a nother or for displasure done / beryth to some other malyce and euyll wyll. But this must nedê­ be a deuelish hatred to hate him whom thou neuer knewist / which neuer did the harme / which if he could now do yt no good where he is / yet eyther
wyth hys good ensample gone before the / or hys good doctryne lefte byhynde hym / doth the / but if thou be very nought of thy self / gret good iÌ this worlde for thy iorney toward heuyn. And thys muste nedys be an enuy cuÌ myng of an hye deuelyshe pryde and far passyng thenuye of the deuyll hymself / for he neuer enuyed but such as he saw & was conuersaunt wyth / as whaÌ he saw man and the glory of god. But these herytyques enuye theym whome they neuer saw nor neuer shall se but whan they shalbe sory and ashamed in theym self of yt gloryouse syght / Â¶For where they pretend the zele of goddys honour hiÌ
â¢ elf / as though god to whoÌ only all honour and glory is to be geuen / were dyshonored in that sum honour is done to hys holy sayntys / they be not so mad nor so chyldyshe as they make theim self. For if all honour were so to be geuen only to god yt we shulde gyue none to no creature / where were than goddys precepte of honour to be geuyn to our father & mother / to pryncys / gouernours & rulers here in erthe / And as saynt Poule sayth euery man to other Â¶And well they wote that the chyrch worshyppeth not saiÌtys as god but as goddis good saruauntis / & therfore the honour that is done to theym redoundeth pryncypally to ye honour of theyr mayster / lyke as in comeÌ custuÌ of people we do reuerence sumtyme & make great chere to sum men for theyr maysters sakes whome ellys we wold not happely byd ones good morow. Â¶And surely if eny benefite or almes done to one of crystê­ pore folke for hys sake / be by hys hygh goodnes reputed and accepted as done vnto hym self / And that who so receyuyth one of hys aposteles or dyscyples receyuyth hym selfe / euery wyse man may well coÌsyder that in lyke wyse who so doth honour hys holy sayntis for his sake doth honour hym self / Excepte these herytyques wene yt god were as enuyouse as they be theym selfe / And yt he wolde be wroth to haue eny honour done to eny other though it therby redounded vnto hymselfe. whereof our sauyoure cryste well declareth the contrary / for he sheweth hym self so well coÌtent, that hys holy sayntys shalbe pertyners of hys honoure / that he promysyth his aposteles / that at ye dredfull dome whaÌ he shall cum in hys hygh maiestye they shall haue theyr honourable seetis and sytte wyth hym selfe vppon the iudegement of the worlde Â¶Cryste also êmised that saynt mary magdalene shulde be worshyped thorow the worlde and haue here an honorable remembrauÌce for that she bestowed yt precyouse oyntement vppon hys holy hed. whych thyng whan I consyder it makyth me meruayle of the madnes of these heretiques that barke agaynst the old auÌcient customes of crystys chyrch / mockyng the settyng vppe of caÌdellys and wyth folyshe facecyes & blasphemous mockery demaunde whyther god and hys sayntys lak lyght or whyther yt be nyght wyth theym that they can not see wythoute candle. They myght as well aske what good dyd that oyntemeÌt to christê­ hed. But the heretyques gruge at the coste now / as theyre brother Iudas dyd than / And say it were better spent in almys vppon pore folk And thys say many of theym whyche can neyther fynde in theyre harte to speÌd vppon yâ¢ one nor the tother. And sum spend sometyme vppon the tone for none other entent but to theÌd that they may the more boldely rebuke and
rayle agaynste the tother. But let theÌ all by that ensample of ye holy woman and by those wordys of our sauyour / lerne yt god delyteth to se ye ferueÌt hete of y â¢ hartê­ deuocioÌ boyl out by ye body / And to do hiÌ seruyse wt all such goodê­ of fortuÌe as god hath geuiÌ maÌ Â¶what ryches deuysed our lord god hym selfe in the making & garnishyng of yâ¢ teÌple & in the ornamentes of ye auter and the prestes apparayle / what was him selfe the better for all thys? what for ye bestê­ yt hym self coÌmauÌded to be offred hym in sacryfyce? what for ye swete odours and frankensence? why do these heretiques more mocke at ye maner of crystê­ chyrche than they do at ye maner of ye iewes synagoge but yf they be beter iewes thaÌ crysten meÌ? Â¶If meÌ wyll say that the mony were better spent amoÌg poore folke by whoÌ he more setteth / beyng the quycke temples of ye holy goste made by hys owne hand / than by the temples of stone made by the hand of man / Thys wold be percase very trew if there were so lytle to do yt wyth that we shuld be dreuyn of necessyte to leue ye tone vndoÌe. But god geuyth inough for both / And geuyth dyuerse men dyuers kyndys of deuocyoÌ and all to hys pleasure. In which as thapostle Poule sayth let euery maÌ for hys parte abouÌ de & be plentuouse in yt kynde of vertu yt the spyryte of god guydeth hym to. & not to be of the folyshe mynde yâ¢ luther is / which wisheth in a sermoÌ of his yt he had in hys haÌd all the perys of the holy crosse / And saith yt yf he so had he wold throw them there as neuer sonne shuld shyne on theÌ. And for what worshup full reasoÌ wold ye wreche do such velany to ye crosse of chryst? by cause as he sayth that there is so mych golde now bestowed aboute ye garneshyng of the pyecys of the crosse that there is none lefte for pore folke. Is not thys aÌ high reason? as though all ye golde yt is now bestowed aboute the pecys of the holy crosse wolde not haue faylede to haue beÌ geuen to pore meÌ if they had not beÌ bestowed abowte the garneshiÌg of the crosse / And as though ther were nothiÌg lost but yt is bestowd about cristê­ cros Â¶Take all ye gold yt is spent about all ye pecys of chrystê­ crosse thorow christendome / albe it many a good chrysteÌ prince and other godly people hath honourably garnyshed many peces therof / yet yf all yt golde were gathered together / yt wold appere a pore porcyon in comparison of ye gold yt is bestowed vppon cuppys / what speke we of cuppys? in whych ye gold albeit yt it be not geuen to pore men yet ys it saued and may be geuen in almouse whan men wyll whych they neuer wyll / how smal a porcyon wene we were ye gold about all ye pecys of chrystys crosse yf yt were compared with ye gold yt is quyte cast a way about ye giltiÌg of kniuis / swordê­ / sporys / arrace / & paynted clothes: and as though these thyngis could not coÌ sume gold fast inough yâ¢ gyltiÌg of postys & hole rofes / not only in the palacê­ of princys and great prelatis / but also many ryght mene meÌnes housis. And yet amoÌg all these thingis coud luther spy no gold yt greuously glyterid iÌ his bleryd eyes but onely aboute ye cros of chryst. yt gold yf yt were theÌs the wyse man wenyth yt wold de streyght geueÌ to pore meÌ. and yt where he dayly seeth yt such as haue theyr purs full of golde geue to ye pore not one pece therof but yf they gyue ought they ransake the botome among all ye gold to seke out here an half peny or in his countrey a braspeny wherof four make a ferthing / such goodly causes fiÌd they yt ptend holines for ye colour of theyr cloked heresyes.

div.head: The thyrd chapiter
div.p: Â¶Thobieccions of ye messeÌger made agaynst prayeng to sayntys / worshyppyng of ymagys / and goyng in pylgrymagys wyth the answere of the author vnto the same. And incydently is it by ye messenger moued that there shuld seme no necessyte for chrysten folke to resort to eny chyrchys / but yt all were one to pray thens or there. And that opynyon by ye author answered and coÌfuted.

AT thys poynt your frend desyryng me that what so euer he shuld say I shuld not rekeÌ it as spoken of hys own opynyon / but that he wold partely shew me what he had hard sum other say therin / to thende that he myght the better answere theym wyth yt he shuld here of me. Thys protestacyoÌ and prefacyon made / he sayd that albe it no good man wolde agre yt it were well done to do â¢ nto sayntys or theyr ymagê­ dyspyte or dyshonor / yet to go in pylgrymagê­ to theym or to pray to theym not only semyd in vayne consyderyng yâ¢ all they yf they can eny thing do / can yet do no more for vs among theym all than chryste can hym selfe alone that can do all / nor be not so redy at our hand to here vs if they here vs at all as chryste yt is euery where / nor bere vs halfe the loue and loÌgyng to helpe vs that doth our sauyour yt died for vs / whome as saynt Poule sayth we haue for our aduocate afore the father / But ouer thys it semyth to smell of Idolatry whaÌ we go oÌ pylgrymage to thys place & that place / As though god were not lyke strong or not lyke present in euery place / But as the deuylys were of olde vnder ye false name of goddys present and assystent in the Idollys & maÌmetys of the paganys / so wolde we make it seme that god and hys saitê­ stode iÌ thys place & yt place to thys post & that post cutte out and caruyd in imagys. For whaÌ we rekyn our self to be better herd wyth our lord in kent than at Cambryge / at the north dore of Poules than at the south dore / at one ymage of our Lady than at a nother / is it not an euydeÌt token and in maner a playne proofe that we put our trust and confydence in the ymage selfe & not in god or our lady? whych is as good iÌ ye tone place as the tother and the tone ymage no more lyke her than ye to â¢ her / nor cause why she shuld fauour the tone bifore the tother. But we blynde peple in stede of god & hys holy sayntys theym selfe cast our affeccyons to the ymagys selfe and therto make our prayers / therto make oure offryngys / & wene these ymagys were ye very sayntys selfe of whom our help & helth shuld grow / puttyng our full trust in thys place & yâ¢ place as negromaÌcers put theyr trust in theyr cercles wyth whyche they thynke theym selfe sure agaynst all ye deuyllys iÌ hell / And wene yf they were one ynch wythout / that than the deuyl wold pull theim in pesys / but as for the cercle he dare not for hys erys onys put ouer hys nose. Â¶And men reken that the clergye is gladde to fauour thys ways & to noryshe thys suêstycyon vnder ye name & colour of deuocyoÌ to ye êell of ye peples soules for the lucre & teÌporall aduauntage yt theym self receyue of ye offrigis. Â¶whan I had hard him say what hym lyked I demaunded if he minded euer to be pre â¢â¢ e / wherunto he answerede nay verely / for me thynketh q he that therbe preestys to many all redy but if they were better. And therfore whaÌ god shall seÌde time I purpose he sayd
to marry. well sayd I than syth I am all redy married twise & therfore neuer can be pre â¢ st / and ye be so set in mynde of marriage yt ye neuer wyll be preest / we two be not the most metely to pondre what myght be said in thys matter for ye preestys parte. Â¶ â¢ ow be it whan I consyder yt / me thynkyth surely that yf the thyng were sych as ye say so far from all frame of ryght relygyon / and so perelous to men soull ys / I can not perceue why that the clergy wold for ye gayn they get thereby / suffer such abusyon to contynew. For fyrst yf yt were trew that no pylgrymage ought to be vsyd / non ymage offred vnto / nor worship done / nor prayour made vnto eny saynt / Than yf none of all these thiÌgê­ had euer bene iÌ vre or now were all vndone / If that were the ryght way / as I wote well it were wrong / than were it to me lytle question but crysten people beyng in the trew fayth and in ye right way to god w â¢ rd / wold therby nothiÌg slake theyr good midê­ toward the minysters of hys chyrch / but theyr deuocion shuld towarde theym more & more encrese. So yt yf they now get by thys way one peny / theye shulde yf thys be wrong and the tother ryght / not fayle iÌ stede of one peny now / thaÌ to receyue a grote. And so shulde no lucre gyue theym cause to fauour this way and it be wrong / whyle they coud not fayle to wyn more by ye right. Â¶Morouer loke me thorow christeÌdome & I suppose ye shal fiÌd ye frute of those offeriÌgê­ & right small parte of the lyuyng of the clergy / And such as though suÌ few placê­ wold be glad to retayne / yet the hole body might without any notable l â¢ sse easily forbere.

Â¶Let vs coÌsidre oure owne cuÌtre he â¢ e / & we shal fiÌd of these pilgri â¢â¢â¢ ê­ ãâ¦ã most parte in ye haÌdê­ of such relygyous êsones or suche pore êryshis as bere no grete rule iÌ ye coÌuocacoÌns â¢ & besidê­ thys ye shal not fiÌd I supopse yt eny bishope iÌ eÌglaÌd hath ye êfite of one grote of eny such offryng wythin hys diocyse. Now standeth then the continuaunce or the brekynge of thys maner and custome specyally in them whych take no profyte therby. whych if they beleuid it to be such as ye call it superstyciouse and wykkyd / wold neuer suffer it contynue to the peryshynge of mennys soules / whereby them selfe shuld distroye their owne soules / and neyther in body nor goodys take any coÌmodyte. And ouer thys we see that the bysshopp â¢ y â¢ and prelatys them seluys visite those holy placys and pylgrimages wyth as large offryngys / and as grete cost in coÌmiÌg and goiÌge as other people do / so yt they not only take no temporall aduaÌtage therof / but also bestowe of ther owne therin.

Â¶And surely I beleue this deuocyoÌ so plantyd by goddes owne hand in the hartê­ of the hole chyrch / that is to wyt not the clergy â¢ only but the hole congregacyon of all crystyn peple / that yf the spyrytualtye were of the mynde to leue it / yet wold not the temporaltye suffer it.

Â¶Now yf it so were that pilgrymagê­ hanged only vppoÌ ye couytyse of euyll prestê­ / for euyll must they be that wold for couytyse helpe the people forward to idolatrye / than wold not good prestys and good bysshoppys haue vsed theÌ theyre selues. But I am very su â¢ e that many an holy bisshop / & therwith excell â¢ ntely well lernyd in scrypture / & the law of god haue had hygh deuocyon therto.

Â¶For where as ye say ãâã that
yt smelleth of Idolatrye to vysyt this place & that place / as though god were more myghty or more present in oone place then a nother / or that god or his sayntys hade bounden them selues to stand at thys Image or that Image / and that by meÌnes demeanure therby shuld appere that the pylgrymys put theyr trust in ye place or the Image yt selfe takyng that for very god / or for the very saynt of whom they seke for helpe / and so fare lyke necromancers that put theyr trust iÌ ye cercle / Surely syr holy saynt Austen man epystyll of hys whych he wrote to the clergy and the people takethe pylgrimagys for a more erenest thynge. And sayeth that though the cause be to vs vnknowen why god doth in some place miracles & in sum place none / yet is it no doute but he so dothe. And therin hade that good holy doctor so grete confydence that as he â¢ ayeth him self / he seÌt twoo of hys prestys in pylgrymage for the tryall of the trouth of a grete matter in contencyon and debate betwene them out of Hyppona in affryke vnto saynt Stephens chyrche in myllayn / where many myracles werre wont to be shewed / to thend that god myght there by sum meanes / cause the truth to be declared and made open by hys power / whych by noo meane knowen to man he could well fynde out /

Â¶Nor they yt goone on pylgrymage do nothynge lyke to those necromancers to whom ye resemble them that put theyre confydence in the rundell & cercle on ye grouÌd / for a specyall beloue that they haue in the c â¢â¢ pa â¢ e of that ground by reason of folyshe ãâã and fygure â¢ about it withe inuocacyons of euyll spyrytys and famylyaryt â¢ with deuy â¢â¢ i â¢ beyng enmys to god / & the crafte & ways of all that warke by god hym selfe prohibyted and forbodeÌ and that vppon the payn of deth / what lyknes hath yâ¢ vnto the goyng of good men vnto holy placys not by enchauÌtmeÌte dedicat to ye deuyl / but by goddê­ holy ordynaunce wyth his holy wordê­ consecratyd vnto hym self. which two thingys yf ye wold resemble to gyther so myght ye blaspheme and haue iÌ dyrision all the deuout rytê­ & cerymonys of the chyrch / both in the deuine seruice as encensyng / haloyng of the fyre / of ye funt / of the pascall lambe / and ouer yâ¢ the exorcysmys / benedyccyons / and holy straunge gesturys vsid in consecracyon or mynystracyon of the blesyd sacrameÌtys / all whych holy thyngys gret parte wherof was frome hand to hand left in the chyrch from the tyme of cristys apostles and by them left vnto vs as yt was by god taught vnto them / men myght now folyly myslyken vnto ye superstycyous demeanure & fond fassyon of iuglery. Nor the flok of cryst ys not so folyshe as those heretyques bere them iÌ hand / that where as there ys no dogg so mad but he knoweth a very cony from a cony carued & paynted / crysten peple that haue reason in theyre heddê­ & therto the light of fayth in theyr soulys shuld wene that thimagys of our lady were our lady her self. Nay they be not I trust so madde but they do reuerence to thymage for ye honour of the person whom yt representyth / as eury maÌ delytyth iÌ thymage & remembrauÌs of hys frend. And al â¢ e yt that euery good crysten man hath a remembryng of crystys passyon in hys miÌd & coÌ
â¢â¢ yuith by deuout meditacioÌ a forme & fassyoÌ therof in hys hart / yet is the â¢ e no maÌ I ãâã so good nor so well ler â¢ ed nor iÌ meditacyoÌ so well accustomyd
/but that he fyndyth hym selfe more mouid to pite and compassion vppon the beholdynge of the holy crucifyxe than whan he lakkith it / And yf ther be any that for the maiÌtenauÌce of hys opynyon wyll perauenture saye that he fyndeth it otherwyse in hym self / he shuld giue me cause to fere that he hath of crystys passyon neyther the tone way nor the tother but a very faiÌt felynge / syth that the holy fathers before vs dyd / and all deuoute people aboute vs do fynde and fele in theÌ selfe the contrary

Â¶Nowe for the reason that you alege quod I / where ye saye that in resorting to thys place and that place / this image and that image / we seme to reken as though god were not iÌ euery place like myghty or not lyke preseÌt / thys reasoÌ procedeth no more against pilgrymagys thaÌ agaiÌst all the chyrchys iÌ crysten doÌe. For god is as mighty iÌ the stable as in ye teÌple. And as he is not coÌpheÌsible nor circuÌscrybed no where / so is he present euery where / But thys letteth not heuen / be it a corporall thynge or not / to be the place of a speciall manere and kynde of hys presence / in whych hyt lykyth hym to shewe hys glorious magestye to hys blessyd heuenly coÌpany which he sheweth not vnto dampned wretches in hell / and yet ys he neuer thense. So li â¢ id it his goodnes to go wyth hys chosen people thorough the deserte iÌ the cloude by day and the pyler of fyre by nyght / yet was he not bounden as ye resemble it lyke the daÌ ned spyrytys to the olde Idolys of the panyms /

Â¶It likid him also to chese the arche yt was caryed wyth hys people / at which arche specially by miracle he diuers tymes declared hys especyall assystence the arche beyng traunslatyd fro place to place. was it not also his pleasure to be specyally present in hys temple of IerusaleÌ tyll he suffred it to be distroyed for theyr synne. And in stede of that oone place of prayer to which he wold byfore that all hys people shuld come he hath vouchsaffyd to sprede hym self abrode in to many teÌples / and iÌ more acceptable wyse to be worshypped in many templys thorow oute hys cristyn flokke /

Â¶Here sayde your fr â¢ nd that the temple of cryste is as saynt poule sayeth maÌ nis harte / and that god is not included nor shytte in any place / And so hiÌ selfe sayd to the woman of Samarie / that very worshyppers shulde worshyp in spyryte / and in truthe / not iÌ the hyll or in hyerusal â¢ m or any other temple of stone /

Â¶whervnto I shewed hiÌ that I wold well agre / that no t â¢ mple of stone was vnto god so plesaunt as the temple of mannys harte / But yet that nothyng letteth or wythstandyth but that god wyll that hys crysteÌ people haue iÌ sundry placys sundry teÌples and chyrchis to whych they shulde besyde theyr pryuat prayours assemble solemply / and resorte in company to worshyp him to gether such as dwell so nere to gether that they may conueniently resorte to one place.

Â¶For albe it oure sauyour sayed quod I vnto the woman of whom ye spake that the tyme shulde come iÌ which they shulde neyther worshyp god iÌ that hill of Gezara not in hyerusalem neyther / whych places were after dystroied and desolate / and the Pagane manere of worshyppiÌg of ye tone / & ye Iues maner of worshippiÌg in ye tother turnyd both in to the maner of worshypiÌg of cristeÌ
Fayth and religyon / yet said he not to her yt they shulde neuer after worship god iÌ none other temple / But he said that the time shuld come / and thaÌ was comen all redy whan the very trewe worshyppers shulde worshyp god in spyryt and truth / And that as god is a spyrytuall substaunce / so lokyd he for worshypers that shuld iÌ such wyse worshyp hym. In whych wordys our sauyour reprouyd all false worship as was vsyd after paganysme iÌ that hyll in Samaria / and all suche worshyp as was done iÌ any place wyth opynioÌ that god myght not be worshyppyd els where. Those yt so byleue they be such as bynde god to a place / whych oure Lorde reprouyth / shewyng that god may in hart truly and spyrytually be worshipid euery where. But this excludyth not that besidis that he wil be worshyppyd in hys holy temple / no more thaÌ whan he gaue couÌcell that for auoydyng of vaynglorye a man shall not stand and praye in the strete to gather worldely prayse / but rather secretly pray in hys chamber / Thys counsell forbadde not the Iewes to whom he gaue it that they shuld neuer after cum in to the temple / and pray.

Â¶And suerly albeit that suÌ good maÌ here and there one among .x. thousaÌd as saynt Poule and seynt Antony / & a fewe such other lyke / do lyue all heuenly far out of all fleshly cumpany / as far from all occasyoÌ of worldly wrechednes / as from the comen temple or parysh chyrch / yet if chyrches & coÌgregacyoÌs of crystyn peple resortiÌg to gether to goddê­ seruyce were onis aboleshed and put away / we were lyke to haue few good teÌples of god iÌ meÌnys soules / but all wolde wythin a whyle weare away clene and clerely fall to nought. And thys preue we by exper â¢
ence / that those which be the best teÌples of god in their soules / they most vse to cum to the temple of stone / And those that lest cum there be well knowen for very rebaudys and vnthryftys / and opeÌly perseyuyd for temples of the deuyll / And thys not in our dayes only / but so hath been from Crystys dayes hether / I trowe no man doutyth but that Crystys appostyls were holy teÌples of god in theyr soules / And well vnderstode ye wordis of theyr master spokyn to the woman of Samary / as the thyng whych theyre mayster after told them hym selfe / or elles how colde sum of them haue wrytyn that coÌmunycacyon whyche none of them hard as apperyth by the gospell. But they not in theyr maysters days oÌly / but also after his resurrexyoÌ and after that they had reseyuyd the holy gost / and were by hiÌ instructyd of euery truth longyng to ye necessyte of theyr saluacyoÌ / were not content only to pray secretly by them self in theyer chambers / but also resortyd to ye teÌple to make theyre prayers / And iÌ yâ¢ place as a place plesaÌt to god dyd they pray in spyryte and in truth / As well apperyth in the boke of saynt Luke wryttyn of the Actys of Crystes holy Apostellys / So that no doute ys there / but that yet vnto thys day and so forth to the worldys ende / it is and shalbe plesauÌte vnto god / that hys chosen people pray to hym and call vppoÌ hym in temple and chyrch. whereof hiÌ selfe wytnessyth wyth the Prophete / Domus mea domus orationis vocabitur. My house shalbe called aÌ house of prayer. Â¶Now makith your reason as I sayed no more agaynst pylgrymagê­ than agaynst euery chirch. For as god is not bounden to the place / nor oure
confydence bounden to the place but vnto god though we rekeÌ our prayour more plesaunt to god in the chyrch thaÌ wythout / by cause hys hygh goodnes accepteth it so / in lyke wyse do not we reken our lorde bounden to ye place or image where ye pylgrymage is though we worshyp god ther bycause hym self lykyth so to haue it.

div.head: Â¶The .iiii. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶Th â¢ author declareth in ye coÌprobacyon of pylgrymagys that yt ys the pleasure of god to be specyally soughte & worshypped in some one place byfore a nother. And albe that we can not attayne to ye knowledge of the cause why god doth so / yet ye author proueth by greatte authoryte that god by myracle testyfyeth yt ys so.

wyth thys your freÌd asked me what reson were there yâ¢ god wold sette more by one place than by a nother / or how know we yt he so doth namely yf the t â¢ ne be a chyrch as well as the tother. Â¶whereunto I answered that why god wold do yt I coulde make hym no answere no more thaÌ saynte austen sayeth that he coud. I was neuer so nere of his couÌsell nor dare not be so bold to ask hym / but that he so doth in dede yt I aÌ sure Inoughe. yet not for that he settyth more by that place for the soyle and pauement of ye place / but that hys pleasure in some place is to shewe more hys assystence and to be more specyally sought vnto than in sum other. Â¶ThaÌ he as â¢ ed me wherby was I so sure of yt. wheruppon I demaunded hym that yf it so were yt the thyng staÌdyng in debate & questyoÌ / it wold lyke our lord to shew a myracle for the proffe of the tone parte / wolde ye not quod I reken than the questyon were decyded / & ye dowte assoyled / and yt parte suffycyently proued â¢ yes mary quod he that wold I. well quod I than ys thys matter oute of doute loÌg a go. for god hath êued my parte in dyuerse pylgrymagê­ by the workyng of many moo thaÌ a thousaÌd myracles one tyme and other. In the gospell of Iohn the fyft chapiter where we rede that the angell moued the water / & who so next went in was cured of hys dysease / was it not a suffycyent profe that god wold they shuld cum thether for theyr helth / Albe yt no man can telle why he sentt thaÌgell rather thyther & there dyd hys myracles than in a nother water? But whan so euer oure lorde hathe in any place wrought a myracle / all though he nothiÌg do it for ye place / but for ye honor of ye saynt whom he wyll haue honored in yt place / or for ye fayeth yt he fyndeth wyth some that prayeth in that place / or for thencrease of fayeth whych he fyndeth fallynge and decayed in that place nedyng the shewe of soÌ myracles for the reuyuyng / what so euer ye cause be / yet I thynke thaffeccyon is to be coÌ mended of men and women yt wt good deu â¢ cyon roÌne thether where they see or here that our lord sheweth a demoÌstracyon of hys specyall assysteÌce. And whan he sheweth many in â¢ one place / it ys a good tokeÌ yt he wold be sought vppon and worshypped there. Many iewes were ther that caÌ to hyerusalem to se ye myracle that chryst had wroght vppon lazare as the gospell reherseth. and suerly we were worse than iewes yf we wold be so neclygent that where god worketh myracles / we lyste not â¢ ons go moue our fote thetherwarde. we marueyle moch that god shewethe â¢ omoo myracles nowe a dayes / whan
yt ys mych more maruell that he doth vouchsaufe to shewe any at all among such vnkynde slouthfull dedely people as lyst not oones lyfte vp theyr heddê­ to loke theron / or yt our incredulyte caÌ suffer hym nowe adays to worke eny.

div.head: Â¶The .v. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶Because pylgrimagê­ be amoÌg other êuys testyfyed by myracles / ye messeÌger doth make obieccyoÌ agaiÌst those myracles / partely lest they be faynyd & vntrew / partly lest they be done by ye deuill if they be doÌe at all

THaÌ sayd your freÌd / well I êseue theÌ yâ¢ force & effect of all ye êfe staÌdyth all in myracles / whych I wyll agree to be a stroÌg êfe yf I saw theÌ doÌ and wer sure yâ¢ god or good sayntê­ did them / But fyrst syth ye meÌ may & happely do of myracles make many a lye / we must not proue thys matter by the myracles / but yf we furste proue yt the myracles were trew. And ouer thys yf they were doon in ded / yet sith ye aÌgell of darknes may traÌsforme & traÌsfigure hym self / in to an aÌgell of lyght / howe shall we know whether ye myracle were don by god to theÌcrease of crysteÌ deuocyoÌ / or doÌ by ye craft of ye deuyl to thaduauÌcemeÌt of mysbyleue & idolatrye / in settyng meÌnys hartys vppon stokkys & stones in stede of sayntys / or vppon sayntys them self that are but creatures in stede of god hym self.

Â¶I answered hym that the force off my tale was not the myracles / but ye thyng yt I hold stronger theÌ any myracles / whych as I sayed in ye begynyng I rekeÌ so sure & fast & therwt so playne & euydeÌt vnto euery crysteÌ maÌ / yt it nedeth no other profe / and ye thyng is as I layed afore ye fayth of chrystê­ chyrch by ye comeÌ coÌsent wherof these maters be decyded & well knoweÌ yt ye worshyp of sayntys & imagys been allowed apêbate & accustumed for good chrysten & merytoryous vertues. and ye coÌtrary opynyon not only reproued by many holy doctours / but also coÌdeÌpned for heresyes by sundry generall couÌsayls. And thys in ye begynyng I told you q I was & shuld be ye force & streÌgh of my tale / Albe yt of trouthe I sayed vnto you besyde / yt me thoght yt ye myracles wrought by god were suffycyeÌt profe & auctoryte therefore all though there were none other. whych thyng syth ye seme to inpugne / I shall as I caÌ make you aÌswer therunto. Â¶Nay syr sayê­ he I pray you take me not soo as though yt I dyd impugne it but as I shewd ye beefore / I rehersyd you what I haue hard som other saye. In good tyme q I. ThaÌ becaus they be not here I prey you defeÌd & bere out theyr ête wt all yt ye haue hard theÌ saye / And sett therto also all yt euer your own mynd geueth you yt they may more heraftyr saye lest you retorn not fully furnishid for your purpose.

div.head: The .vi chapiter
div.p: Â¶Because ye messenger thynkyth yt he may well mystrust and deny the myracles / bycause reason and nature telle hym that they can not be doÌ / therfore fyrst yâ¢ author sheweth what vnresonablenes wold ensue / if folke wold stand so styffe agaynst all credence to be geuen to any such thyng as reason and nature shuld seme to gayne saye.

ANd fyrst where ye say. Nay quod he where they saye. well quod I soo be it where they saye / For here euer my tonge tryppythe. But now therfore fyrste where they saye yt they neuer sawe any of these myracles theym self / and therfore the myracles
be no profe to them whych whyle they neuer sawe them are not boundeÌ to be leue them / they seme eyther very necligent yf they nothyng â¢â¢ uere whaÌ they mystrust & dout of the trouth in such a wayghty matter / or yf they haue dylygeÌtly made enserche than must it nedê­ be yt they haue hard of so many tolde & rehersyd by the mou â¢ hes & the writing of so good and credyble personis / that the ye seeme vnreasonably suspycyous yf they thynke all to gether lyes that so many tre â¢ meÌ or meÌ like to be trew so faythfully do report. If these meÌ were â¢ uggys fewe maters wold take eÌde at theyr haÌd / or at ye le â¢ t yâ¢ playntife shuld haue well spede if they wold bileue no thyng but that were proued / nor rekeÌ nothiÌg proued but yt they se them selfe. Â¶Thus may euery man rekeÌ him selfe vnsure of hys owne father if he beleue no maÌ / or bycause all ye profe therof staÌ dyth but vpoÌ one woman / And yt vpoÌ her whych though she can tell best / yet yf yt be wrong hath gr â¢ test cause to ly. Let ye knowlege of yâ¢ father alone ther fore amoÌg our wy â¢â¢ y â¢ mysteries / And lett vs se yf we beleue nothynge but yâ¢ we se our self. who caÌ rekeÌ him self sure of hys own mother / for pos â¢â¢ ble it were yâ¢ he were chaunged in ye cradell / and a â¢ yche maÌnis ãâã bring hoÌ
â¢ h â¢ r owne chylde for her masters / & kepe her masters for her own to make her o â¢â¢ a geÌ tylmaÌ good â¢ h â¢ pe. And thys were no grete mastery / whyle ye mother hath of her owne child no â¢ re marke. Â¶Sir q your frend yf I shuld ãâ¦ã & by thes exaÌples proue theÌ yt they wer of reasoÌ bouÌdeÌ to beleue ãâã

â¢ e our self / and than were all the â¢â¢ rld full of coÌ
â¢ u â¢ yon / nor no iudgmeÌt could be geu â¢ /but vppoÌ thyngys ãâã iudgê­ â¢ ight / I shuld I fere me very â¢ ebly saty â¢â¢ y them. For they wolde ãâã say yt t â¢ eÌ samples be nothynge like yâ¢ mater. But as it is reasoÌ yt I shuld beleue honeste meÌ in all such thyngê­ as may be trew / & whereiÌ I se no cause why they shuld lye / so were agayn â¢â¢ all reasoÌ to bileue meÌ be they neuer so many / seme they neuer so credible / where as reasoÌ & nature (of whych tw â¢ yne euery one ys alone more credyble then they all) sheweth me plainly yt theyre tal â¢ is vntrew / as yt muste nedy â¢ yf the matter be unpossyble as it is in all â¢ hes myr â¢
cles. And in such case though I can â¢
seue no êfit yt they caÌ receyue therby / yet wh â¢ I wel se yt it coud not be trew I must well se that it ãâã not tre â¢â¢ . And therby must I nedi â¢
â¢â¢ owe yt y â¢ they can take no profyt by lying / they ly not for eny coueryer / but eueÌ oÌly for theyr specyall pleasure. Â¶Forsoth q I thys is right meryly aÌswered. & to say the trothe / as far as we be yet gone in the matter of these myracles not my ãâã amysse / nor very far fro ye poynt. But syth thys thyng ys mych materyal â¢ as wheruppoÌ many grete thy â¢â¢ ys do depend / we shall no â¢ so shortely sha â¢ e y â¢ of / but we shall cum one â¢â¢ ep or ãâã nere to yâ¢ matter. And fyr â¢â¢ I wy â¢â¢ say to theÌ that it were hard for them & n â¢â¢ very sure to beleue yt euery â¢ aÌ lyeth / why â¢ h tellyth theÌ a tale for trew ye re â¢â¢ & nature semyth to she â¢ theÌ to be fals & iÌpossible. For iÌ this w â¢â¢ e shall they in many thiÌgys erre & clerely deceyue th â¢
