done beleue no man that tell yt them / able yt yt yt be no perell to theyr soule / yet so much haue they knowlege ye les / & vnresonably stande in theyr â¢â¢â¢ our â¢ horow the mystrustyng of the trewth. Â¶It ys not yet fyfty yeres a goo syns yâ¢ furst man as far as meÌ haue hard / caÌe to loÌdon that euer parted yâ¢ gylt from the syluer consumyng shorte â¢ y the syluer into dust with a very fayer water / In so farr forth that whan the fyners and goldsmythes of london hard fy â¢ st therof they nothynge wondred therof but laughed thereat as at an impossyble ly / iÌ which perswasions if they had coÌtynued styll â¢ hey had yet at this day la â¢â¢ ed all that connyng. Â¶yet wyll I not say nay but that a man may be to lyght in beleue / and be by such ensamples brought into beleue to farr. As â¢ good fe â¢ ow and frend of myne late iÌ talkyng of this matter of marueylys & miracles entending merely to make me beleue for a trouth a thyng yt could neuer be / fyrst brought in what a force the fyre hath that will make two peces of yron able to be ioyned and cleue to gyther / and wyth the helpe of ye h â¢ me â¢
â¢ e made both one which no h â¢ meryng could do wythout the fyre / whych thiÌg because I dayly see I assented. Than sayed he ferther / yt yet was more maruayle that the fyer shall make â¢â¢ en to â¢ oÌne as syluer or lead doth / & make it take a prynt. whych thyng I told hym I had neuer sene / but byc â¢ use he sayed he had sene it I thought it to be trew. Sone after thys / he wold haue me to beleue yt he had sene a pece of syluer of twoo or thre inchys aboute & in leÌgth leesse than afote draweÌ by maÌnes haÌd thorowe strayte holes made in a irone tyll it was brought in thyknesse not halfe a inche aboute / & iÌ leÌgth draweÌ oute I cannot tell how many yardys. And wheÌ I hard hiÌ say yt he sawe thys hiÌ selfe thaÌ I wyst well he was merely dysposed. Mary syr q your freÌde it was hye time to gyue him ouer whaÌ he caÌ to yâ¢. well said I what yf I shuld tell you now yt I had seen ye same / by my faythe q he merely I wold beleue it at leysour whan I had seen the same / and in ye meane whyle I could not let you to say your pleasure iÌ your own house but I wold thynk that ye were dysposed merely to make me a fole. wel seyd I / what yf there wold besydys me / ten or .xx. good honest men tell you ye same tale / and that they had all seen the thiÌg done them self. In fayth quod he syth I am seÌt hyther to beleue you / I wold in that poynt beleue your self alone / as well as them all. well quod I ye mean ye wold beleue vs all a lyke. But what wold you than say yf one or twayne of them wold say more. Mary q he than wold I beleue them lesse. what yf they wold q I shew you yt they haue seene that the pece of syluer was ouer gylt. & the same pece beyng styll drawen thorow the holes ye gylt not rubbyd of but styll goo forth iÌ lenght wyth the syluer so that all ye lenght of many yerdê­ was gylted of the gyltynge of the fyrst pece not a fote longe? Surely syr quod he those twayne yt wold tell me so moche more I wold saye were not so cuÌnyng in the mayntenaÌce of a lye as was the pylgrymys companyon whyth whan hys felowe had told at yorke yt he had seene of late at londoÌ / a byrde that keuered all poules chyrch yarde wt hys wyngys: commynge to the same place on the morowe sayd that he sawe not that byrde: but he harde mych speeche therof / but he saw in Powles chyrche yard an egge so greate that .x. menne
could scant moue yt wyth leuers / thys felowe could help it forth wyth a proper syde way / But he were no good vnder propper of a lye that wold mynyshe hys credence wyth afyrmyng all the fy â¢ st and settyng a lowder lye therto. well sayd I thaÌ I haue espied if .x. shuld tell you so ye wold not beleue theÌ. No quod he not if .xx. shuld. what yf an huÌ dred wold quod I that semed good and credable. if they were q he ten thousand they were not of credeÌce wyth me whan they shuld tell me that they sawe ye thiÌg that my self knoweth by nature & reasoÌ vnpossyble For whan I know it could not be donne / I knowe well that they lye all / be they neuer so many that say they sawe it done. well quod I syth I se well ye wold not in thys poynt beleue a hole towne / ye haue put me to sylence / that I dare not now be bol â¢ e to tell you that I haue seen yt my s â¢ lfe. But surely if wytnes wold haue seruede me I wene I myght haue broght you a grete meny good men that wold saye and swere to that they haue sene it theÌ self. But nowe shall I êuide me to morowe peraduenture a cople of wytnes of whom I wote well ye wyll myst â¢ uste neyther nother. who be they quod he for yt were hard to fynde whoÌ I could better trust theÌ your self / whoÌ what soo euer I haue merely sayed I cold not in good fayth but beleue you in that ye shuld tell me ernestly vppon your owne knowlege. But ye vse my master sayeth to loke so sadly / whaÌ ye meane merely / that many tymes men dowte whether ye speke in sport whaÌ ye mene good erneste. In good fayth quod I / I meane good ernest now / & yet as well as ye dare trust me I shall as I sayed yf ye wyll go wyth me prouyde a couple of wytnesse of whom ye wyll beleue any one better thaÌ twayne of me / for they be your nerre frendys / and ye haue bene better acquaynted wt them / and such as I dare say for them be not often wont to lye. who be they q he I pray you. Mary quod I your owne twoo eyn / for I shall if you wyll brynge you where ye shall se it / no ferther hens than euyn here in london. And as for iron & laten to be so draweÌ in leÌgth ye shall se it doÌe in .xx shoppê­ almost in one strete. Mary syr quod he these wytnes in dede wyll not lye / As the pore man sayed by the preste if I may be so hoÌly to tell you a mery tale by the waye. A mery tale quod I cummyth neuer a mys to me. The pore maÌ quod he had found the preste ouer famylyer wyth hys wyffe / and because he spake hy â¢ a brode and coulde not proue it the prest sued hym before the bysshoppys offycyall for dy â¢ famacyoÌ / where the pore man vppoÌ payne of cursyng was coÌmaunded that in hys paryshe chyrch he shuld vpon the sonday at hygh masse tyme / stand vp and saye mou â¢ h thou lyest. whereuppon for fulfyllyng of hys penaunce vpp was the pore soule sett in a pew that ye people myght wonder on hym and here what he sayed / And ther all a lowd whan he had rehersyd what he had reportyd by ye prest / than he sett hys handys on his mouth / & sayd mouth mouth thou liest. And by & by theruppon he sett hys haÌd vpon both hys eyen & sayed / but eyen eyen quod he by the masse ye lye not a whytte And so syr in dede / & ye bryng me those wyttnes they wyll not lye a whyt Â¶How be it syr and though thys be trewe / as in good fayth I beleue & am sure that it ys / yet am I neuer the more bounden by reason to beleue theÌ yâ¢ wolde tell me a miracle. For though
thys thyng be incredyble to hym that hereth it / and straunge and meruelus to hym that seeth yt / yet is it a thynge that may be done / But he that telleth me a myracle / telleth me a thynge that can not be don. I shewed you quod I thys ensaÌple to put you in mynd that in beyng ouer hard of byleue of thynges tha â¢ by reason and nature seme & apere iÌpossyble / where they be repottyd by credyble witnes hauing no cause to lye / ther is as moch peryll of errour as where men be to light of credeÌce / And thus much haue I proued you oÌwarde that if ye beleue no man in such thiÌgê­ as may not be / than must it folow that ye ought to beleue no man in many thyngys that may be / for all is oone to you / whyther they may be or may not be / yf it seme to you that they may not be. And of truthe ye caÌnot tell whether they may be or may not be / except they be two such thyngys as imply coÌtradiccion / as oone selfe thyng in oone selfe parte to be both whyte & blakke. For ellys many thyngys shall seme to you such as all reson wyll resyste / and nature wyll in no wyse admytte / And yet they shall be done well inoughe / And be in some other place in comen vse & custome. But nowe bycause / all your shyfte standeth iÌ thys that of a myracle tolde you ye may wyth reason byleue that all men lye bycause reasoÌ and nature beyng more to be beleuyd than all they / telleth you that they say wronge in that the thyng reportyd for a myracle can not be donne / I haue shewed you that nature / and reasoÌ doth shew you yt many thyngys may not be don whych yet in dede be done so ferforth yâ¢ when ye se theym done ye may right well accompte theÌ as miracles for any thyng that reason or nature can shew you by what naturall order and cause yt could be done / but that ye shall styll se reason stand quyte agaynst yt as in the drawynge of the syluer or iron.

div.head: Â¶The .vii. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶The Author sheweth that nether nature nor reson do deny the myracles to be trew / nor do not gayn say but yt they may be well & easly done.

SIr sayth he yet hytte we not the poynt / for albe it yt many thiÌgê­ be well done / & by nature / whych neyther my wytte nor happely no mannys ellys can attayn so nere to natures couÌ sell that we can theriÌ êceyue her crafte / But like as suÌ rude people / muse vppoÌ a clokke / yt hath ye spryng whych is the cause of hys mouyng secretly coÌueyed and closed in the barrell / so marueyle we & wonder on her worke / yet allway all those thyngys dyffer and be vnlyke to myracles. In that your self wyll agre with me yt whan I beleue yt reason and nature techeth me surely that miracles be thyngys that can not be done / I am not iÌ this deceyuyd thogh I may be iÌ such other thiÌgê­ deceyued as seme impossyble and yet may be done. And therfor as coÌcernyng myracles iÌ which your self wyll agre that I am not by any mystakyng of reasoÌ and nature deceyued / ye may not your self me thynketh say nay / but yt I may well with reason beleue theym twayne agaynst all theym that wyll tell me they haue sene such thyngys don as your self doth agre / that they twayne that ys to wytte nature and reason dothe verely and trewly shew me can not be don. what maner of thingys be those q I. Mary myracles quod he such as your self â¢ wyll agre to be don agaynst nature. Geue vs therof quod I sum eÌsample. As yf meÌ quod he wold now cum tell
me yt at oure lady of rouncyuale / there were a dede chylde restored agayne to lyffe / lett that quod I be oone / and lett a nother be yt a bysshop in the byldyng of hys chyrch fyndyng one beame cutt a greate dele to shorte for hys worke / drewe it forth betwene a nother man & hym foure fote (& ye wyll) lenger than it was and so made it serue / Be yt by my trouth q he. wyll we quod I take for the thyrde / yt a maÌ was by myracle in a pater noster whyle / coÌueyd a myle of from oone place to a nother. be hit so quod he. Nowe they that shuld tell me quod he that they had seene these thre myracles were I bound to beleue theÌ? whether ye were bouÌdeÌ quod I or no / we shall see ferther after / But now whye shuld ye not of reasoÌ trust them yf the men be credyble / and ernestly reporte yt / and peraduenture on there othes depose it / hauiÌg no cause to fayne it nor lykely to lye and be forswornen for nought. I wyll quod he not beleue them bycause that nature and reasone are twoo recordys more to be byleued thaÌ all they that bere wytnesse agaynst them. why quod I what doth reason & nature tell you. They twayne tell me quod he yt those .iii. thyngys caÌ not be done / whych those men sey they sawe done. wote you quod I that reasoÌ and nature tell you so. ye mary quod he yt I wote well they do / & I thynke youre self wyll agre that they tell me so. Nay by saynt Mary syt quod I that wyll I not â¢ for I thynke that neyther reson nor nature telleth you so / but rather both twoo tell you clene the contrary / that ys to wyte that they both bere witnesse that those thre thyngys and such other lyke be thingys that may be well â¢ nd easly done / ye quod he: mary thys ys a nother way. TheÌ haue we walked wrong a whyle yf ye proue that. Me thynketh quod I no thyng more easy to proue than that / For I pray you tell me quod I do reasoÌ and nature shewe you that there ys a god or not? Fayth sheweth me yt surely quod he / but whyther nature and resoÌ shew â¢â¢ me or no that I doute / syth grete reasoned men and phylosophers haue dowted therof And some of them playnly perswaded and in beleue that there was none at all / and the hole people of the world in effecte fallen from knowlege or beleue of god in to Idolatry & worshype of mammottys. Nay quod I there ys lytle dowte I trowe â¢ but that nature & reason geueth vs good knowlege that there is a god. for albe it the gentylys worshypped among them a thousand false goddis / yet all that proueth yt ther was and ys in all mennes heddys a secrete consent of nature that god there is or ellys they wold haue worshypped noÌe at all. Now as for ye philosophers though a very fewe dowted / and one or twayne thought ther was none / yet as oone swalow maketh not somer so ye foly of so fewe maketh no chaunge of the matter agaynst all the hole noumber of the olde philosophers. whych as saynt Poule confessyth found owt by nature and reasoÌ that ther was a god eyther maker or gouernour or both of all thys hole eÌgyne of the world. The maruelouse bewtye & constant course whereof / sheweth well that it neyther was made nor gouerned by chaunce. But whan they had by these vysyble thyngys knowlege of hys inuysyble magestye / thaÌ dyd they / as we do / fell from the worshyp of hym to ye worship of Idoles as now do chrysten meÌ / not as herytyques lay to ye charge of good people in doyng reuerence to sayntys

/he wrought it not to the vttermo â¢â¢ s of hys power / but with sych degrees of goodnes as his hye plesure lyked to lymyt. For els were hys work of as infynyte êfeccy â¢ n as hym self. And of such infynyte eg â¢ ll ê â¢ eccyoÌ was ther by god brought forth nothyng but only ye two êsons of the trynyte / yt is to wyt ye soÌne & the holy goste. of which two the sonne was furste by the father begotten / & after the holye goste by the father and the sonne / after I say iÌ order of beginning but not in tyme producyd and brought forth. And in thys hye generacyon and produccyon dyd the doers work bothe wyllyngly & naturally / & after the vtterest parfeccyon of them self / which they dyd only therin â¢ in none other thyng. And therefore god myght breke vp the hole worlde yf he wolde & make a beter by & by. and not onely chauÌge in the n â¢
turall cours of thys world sum thyngê­ to the beter. How be it god in workyng of myracles doth nothyng agaynst nature / but some specyall benefyte aboue nature. And he doth not agaynste you that doth a nother a good torne whych ye be not able to do. And therfore syth god may do what he wyll beiÌg almyghty / and in doynge of myracles he dothe for the beter / neyther reson nor nature shewyth you that they whych saye they saw such myracles / do tell you a thyng yt can not be done / syth ye haue no reason to proue that god either can not do yt or wyll not do yt. For syth he caÌ do it and yt may be that he wyll do yt / why shuld we mystruste good & h â¢ nest men that say they saw hym do yt.

div.head: The .ix. chapyter.
div.p:
Â¶The author shewyth ãâã albe yt men m â¢ y mystruste some of the p â¢â¢
tyculer myracle â¢ /yet c â¢â¢ there no resonable ãâã neyther deny nor ãâã /but that â¢ any myracles hath there bene done and wrought.

FOrsothe quod he & yet ãâã for myracles I were notte for all thys bouÌdeÌ to beleue any. for I spake n â¢ uer yet wt any man yt cou â¢ e tell me that euer he saw any Â¶It may q I fortune you to lyue so loÌg that yt shall fynde no maÌ that was by at your crystenyng / nor when ye were bishopped neyther. Â¶Mary q he for ought â¢ I wot I haue lyued so longe all redy. Â¶why dout we not than q I whyther ye were euer crystenyd or not? Â¶ For euery man quod he presumyth & beleueth that I aÌ crystenyd / as a thyng so comenly done / that we reken our selfe sure yt no man leuyth yt â¢ ndone. Â¶I â¢ the comen presumpsyon quod I suffycyently serue you to set your mynd in surete / than albeit myracles be nothiÌg comenly & customably done / nor that no presumpcyon can suffy â¢â¢ ently serue for ye profe of thys myracle or that / yet hathe there euer from the begynnyng of the world in euery nacyon crysten â¢ he then / and almost euery town at so â¢ dry times so many myracles and m â¢â¢
uayls bene wrought besyde the come â¢ cour â¢ of nature / that I thynk thorow ye world yt is as well beleuyd vnyuersally that miracles and maruayl â¢ the â¢ be / as any thyng ys beleuyd that men loke vppon. So that if comen presuÌpsioÌ serue you / ye may as I sayd as w â¢ l beleue that myracles be done / ãâã that youre selfe was euer cry â¢â¢ enyd. For I dare well say that the â¢ e â¢ r a thousand yt bele â¢ e ther hath bene myracles doÌe / against one that beleuyth that ye wer euer cry â¢â¢ enyd / or euer wyst whether ye were borne or n â¢ t. Â¶Nor ye doctors of Cry â¢â¢ ys chyrch dyd n â¢ u â¢ r mystrus â¢ ye wonders & m â¢ r â¢â¢ yl â¢ t â¢â¢ t the â¢â¢â¢
nymes
telle and wryte too ha â¢ e beene done by theyr false goddis / but assygneth them to haue ben done by the deuyll thorow goddê­ sufferauÌce for thyllusyon of them that with idolatry had deserued to be deluded. And whyther they be myracles by whyche name we coÌmenly call the wonders wrought by god or merueyles done by the deuel it forseth not for thys purpose of ours. For yf ye graunt that the deu â¢ ll may do any by goddis sufferaÌce / ye can not say nay but god may much more â¢ asily do hym self. Â¶And sith ye be a christen maÌ and receyue scripture I might iÌ this matter quod I haue choked you long a go / wyth the manyfold myracles and meruailes yt be shewed there.

div.head: Â¶The .x. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶Thauthor prouyth yt many thiÌgê­ dayly don by nature or craft wherof we nothynge merueyle at all / be more meruelous and more woÌderfull in dede than be the myracles yt we mooste marueyle of and repute most incredyble.

NAy quod he suerly though it hath doone me good to here what ye wold say / yet I nether dout nor I suppose no good man ellys / but that god hath besyde the comen course of nature wrought many myracles. But yet of those that men tell of / as done in our tyme / by whych ye wold it shuld seme that it were well prouyd that the prayng to sayntys / goyng on pylgrymagys / & worshyppyng of ymagys were well and suffycyently prouyd / all though there were none other profe theruppoÌ / of these myracles dyd I mene / in the report of whych me thynkyth I neede not beleue a comen fame of â¢ hys myracle and that begon by such sily womaÌ sekiÌg saynt Sythe wheÌ
â¢ he syghyth for myscastyng other â¢ ays. Of these myracles I speke / & all such as men say now adays be done at dyuers pylgrymagê­ by dyuers sayntê­ or dyuers ymagys / in whych the thynkyth yt such as be told to be don which nature and reson sayth be impossyble / I may well mystrust ye tellers. Or ells how many of theÌ shall make me a suffycyent profe of an impossyble mater? One or two or thre eyther semyth me to few to trust theyr credence in a thiÌg so incredible. And if I shall not beleue theym tyll I fynde many recordys / I wene I were fayne to wander ye world about or I êuyd many myracles suffyciently / of such I say as ye êue your pylgrymages by. Â¶youre few wordys q I haue wrappyd in them many thingys that seme somwhat as they be couchyd to geder. which when we se them vnfoldyd and consyder ech part a sonder / than may we better examyn th â¢ m & better se wherof they serue. Â¶Furste ye speke of sekiÌg to sayntys for sleyght causys. as for ye losse or mysse of kyttis ka â¢ s. Than ye wolde wyt how many ye must here say they saw a myracle or ye shuld of reason beleue yt. Thyrdly ye thynk ye were lyke to go long or ye shuld fynde any prouyd trew. Fynally whan ye say that ye meane onely those myracles that men tell of / as doone at pylgr â¢ magys / ye seme to put styll a differeÌs betwene those myracles wroght in pylgrymag â¢ & such as are wrought by god otherwyse / The cause wherof I must ferther aske you after. For I perceyue not well what ye meane by yt / Â¶But fyrst where as ye speke styll as though ye myght mistrust theÌ were they neuer so many: because they tell you a thyng that reasoÌ & nature sayeth is impossyble / me thynketh yt ye shuld
now chaunge that worde. For I haue all redy / êuyd that reasoÌ & nature say not that a myracle ys iÌpossible / but only that it is impossyble to nature. And they coÌfesse both that myracles be possyble to god and they that report them do report them for such. And therfore they do report you none iÌpossible tale. For the clerer coÌsyderacion wherof / let vs resort to ye miracles which we were agreed shuld stand for examples / And fyrst yf men shuld tell you yt they sawe before an ymage / of the crucifix a dede man raysid to lyfe / ye wold much merua â¢ le therof / and so myght ye well. yet could I tell you sum what that I haue seen my selfe that me thynketh as gret a meruayle / but I haue no lyst to tell you because that ye be so circumspect and ware in beleue of any myracles / yt ye wold not beleue yt for me but mystrust me for it. Nay sir quod he iÌ good fayth / yf a thiÌg semed me neuer so farr vnlykly / yet yf ye wolde ernystly say yt your selfe haue seen yt / I neyther wold nor could mystrust yt, well quod I thaÌ ye make me the bolder to tel you. And yet wyll I tell you nothing / but that I wold yf nede were find you good witnes to proue it. It shall not nede syr q he / but I besech you let me here it. For soth quod I because we speke of a maÌ raysyd from deth to lyfe. There was iÌ the parish of saynt steuenes iÌ walbrok in loÌdoÌ where I dwellid before I came to chelsyth / a maÌ and a woman which at yet quyk and quethynge and yonge were they both. The eldyst I am sure passyd not .xxiiii. It happed them as doth among yong folke / ye tone to cast a mynd to the tother. And after many lettis / for yâ¢ maydeÌs mother was mich agaynst yt / at last they came to gether and were maryed in saynt Stephens chirch which is not gretly famouse for any myracles / but yet yerely on saynt steuyn day it is soÌwhat sought vnto / & vysyted with folkis deuocioÌ. But now short tale to make / thys yong woman as the maner is in brydis ye wote well was at nyght brought to bed with honest womeÌ. And than after that went the bryde grome to bed. And euery body weÌt theyr wayes & left them twayn there alone. And that same nyght / yet abide let me not lye. now iÌ faith to say the trouth I am not very sure of the time / but suerly as it aperid afterward yt was of lyklyhod yâ¢ same nyght or suÌ other tyme sone after except yt happened a lytle afore. No force for the tyme quod he. Troth quod I / and as for the matter all the paryshe wyll testefye for trewth the woman was knowen for so honest. But for the conclusion the seed of them twayn / turned in the womans body / fyrst into bloode / and after into shape of man chylde. And than waxed quyk and she gret therwyth. And was within yâ¢ yere delyuered of a fayr boy / and forsoth yt was not than (for I saw yt myselfe) passing the lenght of a fote. And I am sure he is growen nowe an ynch lenger than I. How long ys yt agoo quod he. By my fayth q I / about xxi. yeres. Tush quod he this is a worthy myracle. In good faith quod I neuer wyst I that any maÌ could tell that he had any other begynnyng. And me thynkyth that thys ys as gret a myracle as the reysyng of a dede man. Â¶If yt seme so q he to you / than haue you a maruelouse semynge / for I wene yt semyth so to no man els. Â¶No quod I caÌ ye tell what is ye cause? None other surely but that the acquayntauÌce and dayly beholdyng takyth a way the woÌ deryng / as we nothyng wonder at the
ebbyng and flowyng of the see / or the thamys bycause we dayly se it. But he that had neuer seene it nor hard therof wolde at the fyrste syght wonder sore the â¢ at to se that great water cum walowyng vp agaynst the wynde keping a coÌmen course to and fro / no cause êseyued yt dryueth hym. If a maÌ borne blynde had sodeÌly hys syght what wouÌ der wold he make to see the sonne the mone / and the starres / where as one yt hathe sene them syxtene yere to gether marueylyth not so moche of theÌ all / as he wolde wonder at the fyrst syght of a pecokkys tayle. And veryly cause can I se none / why we shulde of reasoÌ mo â¢ e maruayle of ye reuyuyng of a dede maÌ than of the bredyng / bryngyng forthe and growyng of a chyl â¢ e vnto ye state of a man. No more meruelouse ys a koko thaÌ a cokk / though ye tone be sene but in somer and the â¢ other all ye yere. And I am sure yf ye sawe dede meÌ as coÌmenly called a gayne by myracle / as ye se men brought forth by nature / ye wolde rekeÌ yt lesse maruayle to bryng the soule agayne into the body / kepiÌg yet styll hys shappe and hys organys not moch pereshyd / thaÌ of a lytle seede to make all that gere new / and make a newe soule therto. Now yf ye neuer had sene any gonne in youre days nor herd of any before / yf .ii. men shuld tell you the tone that he had wyst a maÌ in a pater noster while conueyd & caryed a mile of from one place to a nother by myracle / & ye tother shulde tell you yt he had sene a stone more than a mannys weyght caryed more than a myle in as lyttyll space by craft / whych of these wolde you by your faythe take for the more incredyble? Â¶Surely q he both twayne were very strange. But yet I could not chese but thynke yt were rather trewe yâ¢ god dyd ye tone / than that any crafte of maÌ coulde do the tother. well quod I let vs than to oure thryde ensample. If it were shewed you that saynt Etkenwalde or hys s â¢ ster drewe out a pece of tiÌber yt was cut to shorte for the rofe iÌ makyng barkyng abbey / shulde thys be so incredyble to you to beleue that they drewe in lenght a pece of wood by ye power and helpe of goddys haÌd / whaÌ we se dayly a grete pece of syluer brasse / laten or iren drawen a lenght iÌto smale wyer / as woÌderfully by mannys hand

div.head: Â¶The .xi. chapiter
div.p: Â¶The author shewyth that a myracle is not to be mystrustyd thogh yt be done in a small mater and semith vppon a sleyght occasyon.

NOw though ye wold paraduenture as ye seme to do / reken thys cause very sleyght for god to shew sych an hygh myracle / syth there myght haue bene wtout myracle a lenger pece of tymber gotten / & so ye wold happely mystrust yt for the slender occasion / resemblyng yt to the myscastynge of some good huswyuys kays / god hath I wene so much wyt of hym selfe / yt he nedyth not our aduyce to eÌforme hym what thyng were suffycyent occasyon to worke hys wonders for. But & if ye rede in ye bokys of Cassyan / saynte Gregory / saynt Austyne / saynt Hyerom / & many other holy vertuous men / ye shall (excepte ye beleue theÌ not) lerne & know that god hath for hys saruantys don many a gret myracle in very small maters. And so mych ye more ar we boundeÌ to hys goodnes in yt he vouchesauyth so famylyerly in smal thiÌgê­ to shew vs so gret a tokeÌ of his mighty godhed. & no resoÌ wer it to wtdraw his thaÌk & honor because of his
famylyer goodnes. And yf ye paraueÌ ture wold not beleue theyr wrytyngê­ / go to Crystê­ gospell & loke on hys fyrst myracle whether he myght not haue êuydyd for wine without miracle. But such was his pleasure in a small mater to do a greate myracle for sum shew of hys godhed amoÌg them whoÌ he vouch saufyd / where on the tother syde afore Herode that wold fayn haue sene sum myracle where yt stode vppon his lyfe & myght haue delyueryd hym from the iewes / yet wolde he not vouchsafe eyther to shew the proud curyouse kyng one myracle / or speke one word. So yt tymys placys & occasyons / reason is yt we suffer to rest in hys arbyterment. & not loke to prescrybe & appoynt at our pleasure / and ellys blaspheme theym & say we wyll not beleue them.

div.head: Â¶The .xii. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶The author sumwhat notyth the froward myndys of many folk that wold be very hard to beleue a man in a myracle vppon his othe / & very light in a shrewd tale to beleue a woman on her word.

NOw where ye requyre how many witnes shuld be requisite and suffice to make you thynk your self in reson to haue good cause to beleue so strange a thyng / me thynkyth yt ryght few were suffycyent of them that wold say they saw a grete good thyng done by the power & goodnes of god. except it be harde for vs to beleue eyther that god ys so myghty yt he may do it or so good yt he wold do it Â¶But because ye wold wit of me how many recordys were requysyte / ye thiÌg standyth not so much in nomber as in weyght. Some twayn be more credyble than sum .x. And albe yt yâ¢ I se not greatly why I shuld mystrust any one that semith honest & tellith a good tale of god in whych there apperyth no specyall cause of lyeng / yet yf any wytnes wyll serue you / thaÌ wold I wyt of you how many your self wold agre. For I now put case yt there cam .x. dyuers honest men of good substaunce out of .x. dyuers partyes of the realme / â¢ che off them wyth an offeryng at one pylgrymage / as for ensample at our Lady of Ipswych / & ech one of them affyrming vppon theyr othe a myracle don vppoÌ them self in sum grete so dayn help wel apperyng to passe the power of crafte or nature / wold ye not beleue yt amoÌg them all at the lestwyse twayn of those .x. sayd trew? Â¶No by oure lady q he not & they were .x. and .xx. Â¶why so q I. Â¶Mary quod he for wer they neuer so many hauyng none other wytnesse but eche man tellyng hys tale for hym selfe / they be but syngle all & lesse than syngle. for euery myracle hath but one record / and yet he not credable in hys owne cause. & so neuer a myracle well êuyd. Â¶well sayd I / I lyke well your wysdome yt ye be so cyrcumspect that ye wyll nothyng beleue without good suffycyent & full profe. I put you than quod I a nother case that .x. yong womeÌ not very specially known for good but takeÌ out at aueÌture / dwellyng all in one towne / wold report & tell that a frere of good fame heryng theyr confessyons at a pardon / wold haue geueÌ them in penaunce to let hym lye wyth them / on youre fayth wolde ye not beleue yt among so many sum of theÌ said trew? yes yt I wold quod he by ye mary mas beleue they said trew all .x. & durst well swere for them & they were but .ii. whi so q I they be as sigle witnes as ye other of whoÌ I told you before. for noÌe of theÌ caÌ tell what was sayd to aÌ other
& yet they be vnsworn also / & therwyth be they but womeÌ whych be more light & lesse to be regardyd / dwellyng all in one towne also / & therby myght they ye more easely conspyre a false tale. They be q he wytnes good ynogh for such a mater / the thyng ys so lykely of yt selfe that a freer wylbe womanysh loke the holy horeson neuer so sayntly. Â¶ye deny not q I but god may as easly do a good turn by myracle as any maÌ may do an yuell by nature. That is trew q he & he lyst. well quod I se now what a good way ye be in / yt ar of your owne good godly miÌde more redy to beleue ii. siÌple womeÌ yt a man wyll do noght / than .x. or .xx. men yt god wyll do good

div.head: The .xiii. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶Thauthor sheweth yt vntowarde miÌd of many meÌ / which in miracles so hyely touchyng ye honor of god & wele of theyr own soulys / wyll neyther beleue other folk yt tell theÌ / nor theÌ self vouchsafe to go preue theÌ. BUt syth yt thys kynde of profe wyll not suffyse you / I dare say if ye wold seke & enquere / ye shuld fiÌde many done in your days in ye presence of mych peple. wher shuld I se yâ¢ q he? ye myght q I vppoÌ good friday euery yere this .ii.C. yere till wtin this .v. yere yt the turkys haue take the town / haue sene one of ye thornys yt was in Crystê­ crown / bud & bryng forth flowrys in ye seruyse tyme / if ye wold haue gon to ye Rodys: So far q he â¢ ay yet had I leuer haue goddys blessyng to beleeue yt I se not / than go so far therfore. I am well apayd q I therof. for yf ye had leuer beleue than take the payn of a loÌg pylgrymage / ye will neuer be so styf in any opynyon yt ye wyll put your self in ieoêdy for êtynacy & stoborne staÌdyng by your parte. No mary q he I waraÌt you I will neuer be so mad to hold till it wax to hote. For I haue such a fond fansy of myne owne yt I had leuer shyuer & shake for cold in yâ¢ myddys of somer / than be burnyd iÌ yâ¢ myddê­ of winter. Merely sayd q I. but yet in ernest wher such a solemne yerely myracle is wrought so woÌdersly in the face of the world before so gret a multytude / it is a gret vntowardnes in a thiÌg so hyly touchyng ye honor of god & helth of our own soule / both to mistrust all theÌ yt sey they haue sene it / & eyther of slouth or incrudelyte not vouchsafe hym self to proue it. If I shuld haue gon quod he & fouÌd it a ly / thaÌ had I walkyd a wyse iorney. & oÌ ye tother side if I shuld haue sene ther such a thing my self / yet coud I scantly rekeÌ my selfe sure. No q I yt were a strange case. Not very strange q he. For where ye speke of myracles done before a multyrude / a man may be dysseyuyd therin ryghte well.

div.head: The .xiiii. chapiter.
div.p: Â¶The messeÌger makyth obieccyoÌ yâ¢ myracles shewed byfore a multitude may be fayned / & by ye author shewd how yâ¢ goodnes of god briÌgyth shortly yâ¢ truth of such falshed to lyght / wt eÌsaÌples therof one or two rehersed. & farther shewed that many myracles therebe whych no good crysten man may deny to be trew.

SOme pteste to bryng vp a pylgrymage in hys êyshe may deuyse suÌ false felowe faynyng hym self to com seke a saynt in his chyrch / And there sodenly saye that he hath gotten hys syghte. Then shall ye haue the bellys rongeÌ for a myracle / And ye foÌd folke of the countre soone made foles. Than women coÌming thether wt their caÌdells. & the persoÌ byyng of sum la â¢ e begger .iii. or .iiii. payre of theyre olde
â¢ rutches wt .xii. pennes spent iÌ meÌ & womeÌ of wex thrust thorow dyuers placê­ some wt arrowes / & suÌ wt rusty knyuys wyll make hys offeryngys for one .vii. yere worth twyse hys tythes. Thys ys q I very truth that such thyngys may be & suÌtime â¢ o be iÌ dede â¢ As I remeÌber me that I haue hard my father tell of a begger yt in kynge Edwardê­ dayes yâ¢ fourth cam wyth hys wyffe to saynt Albonys / And there was walkyng aboute the towne beggyng a fyue or six dayes before ye kyngê­ coÌmyng th â¢ ther sayng yt he was borne blynde / & neuer sawe in hys lyfe / And was warned in hys dreame yâ¢ he shuld coÌ oute of Berwyke where he sayed he had euer dwelled to seke saynte alboÌ / And yâ¢ he hade bene at hys shryne and had not been holpen / And therfore he wold go seke hiÌ at some other place / for he had hard some say synne he caÌ / yâ¢ saynt albonys body shuld be at Colon / And in dede such a coÌteÌcyoÌ hath ther beene. But of trouth as I am surly iÌformed he lyeth here at saynt albonys / sauyng some relyques of hym whych they there shew shryned. But to tell you forth whaÌ the kyng was cuÌmeÌ & yâ¢ towne full / sodaynly thys blynde man at saynt Albonys shryne had hys syght agayne / And a myracl â¢ solemply rongeÌ / and Te deuÌ songen / so that nothyng was talked of in all the towne but thys myracle. So happened it than that duke huÌfrey of gloucester a great wise maÌ & very well lerned / hauyng greate Ioy to se such a myracle / called yâ¢ pore maÌ vnto hym And fyrst shewyng hym selfe ioyouse of goddys glory so shewed iÌ yâ¢ gettyng of hys syght / & exortyng hym to mekenes & to none ascrybyng of any parte yâ¢ worshyp to hym self / nor to be proud of the peoples prayse whych wolde call hym a good & a godly man therby / At last he loked well vppon hys eyen and asked whyther he coud neuer se nothiÌg at all in all hys lyfe before. And whan as well hys wyfe as hym self affermed fastely no / than he loked aduysedly vppoÌ hys eyen agayne / & sayed I beleue you very well / for me thynketh yt ye caÌ not see well yet. yes syr q he I thanke god & hys holy marter I can se now as well as any man. ye caÌ quod the duke / what colour is my gowne? ThaÌ anoÌ yâ¢ begger told hiÌ. what color q he is thys maÌnys gown? he told hiÌ also â¢ & so furth wythoute any stykkyng / he told hym the names of all the colours that could be shewed hym. And wheÌ my lord saw that / he bad hym walk faytoure / And made hym be sett openly in ye stokkys. For though he could haue seen â¢ oodeÌly by myracle ye dy â¢ ference bytweene dyuerse colors / yet coud he not by ye sight so sodenly tell ye names of all thees colours but yf he had knowen theÌ before nomore thaÌ yâ¢ names of all yâ¢ men that he shulde sodeÌly se. Lo therfore I saye quod youre frende who may be sure of such thyngys whan such pageantys be played before all yâ¢ towne. I remeÌber me now what a worke I haue hard of that was at lempster iÌ yâ¢ kyngê­ fathers dayes where ye pryour brought preuyly a strauÌge weÌche iÌto ye chyrch yt sayd she was sent thyther by god / & wold not ly oute of ye chyrch / And aftere she was gratid wtiÌ ireÌ gratê­ aboue iÌ yâ¢ rood loft where it was byleued yt she liued wtout any mete or drynke oÌly by aÌgels fode. And dyuers tymes she was houseled iÌ syght of ye peopl â¢ wt aÌ hoste vncoÌsecrate / & all ye peple lokiÌg vpoÌ / ther was wt a small here yt coÌueyd ye hoste from ye pateÌ of ye chalyce out of ye pryours haÌ dê­ iÌto her mouth as thogh it caÌ alone /
so that all the people not of the towne only / but also of yâ¢ con â¢ rey about / toke her for a very quyk saynte / and dayly soughte so thyk to se her / that many yt coud not come nere to her cryed owte alowd / â¢ oly mayden Elyzabeth helpe me â¢ and were fayn to throw theyr offeriÌg ouer theyr felows heddê­ for prece. Now lay the pryour wyth holy maydeÌ Elyzabeth nyghtly in the roode lofte / tyll she was a â¢ ter taken out & tryed in the kepyng of my lady the kyngys mother. And by the longynge for mete wt voydaunce of that she had etyn which had no sayntly sauour / she was parceyuyd for no saynte and confessyd all the mater. In fayth q I it had bene gret aluies ye pryour & she had bene burnyd to gether at one stake. what cam of the pryour? Â¶Quod he that caÌ I not tell / But I weene he was put to suche ponishment as the pore nunne was / that had gyuen her in penaunce to say this verse. Miserere mei deus / quoniam conculcauit me homo. wt a grete thre â¢ e that and she dyd so any more she shuld say ye hole psalme. But as for holy may den Elsabeth I harde say she lyuyd & faryd well / & was a comeÌ harlot at Calyce many a fayre day after / where she laughed at the mater full merely. The more pyte q I that she was so let pas. Â¶That ys trouth quod he. But now what say you what trust can we haue / or at lest way what suerte can we haue in such thyngys whan we se theÌ faynid so shamfully in the face of the world / & so mych people abusyd so far / that they wold not haue lettyd to swere / & some to ieopard theyr lyuys theron / that all this work was wroght by goddys haÌd tyll the troth cam to lyght / and yt drab dryuen out of the chyrch in the dyuyls name. Â¶Uerely sayd I there was abusyon in the tone syde / & grete foly in ye tother syde. And as yâ¢ noble duke HuÌ frey wysely found out the falshed of yt blyson begger / so dyd that noble lady the kyngys mother prudeÌtly decypher & founde out that bestely fylth. And to say the trouth there was cause inough in both these partyes wherof the peple myght resonably gather so mych suspicyon / yt yf they had made theruppoÌ suffycyent inquysycion & serch / they coud neuer haue beene so far â¢ e abusyd. For both myght they well mystruste a beggers worde whom they had but newly known & well lykly to ly for to wynne fu â¢ st fauour & after money / And also men might well thynk that a yong she saynte was not metely to be shrynyd quyk in a monastery among a meyny of monkys. And yet in conclusyon because no such faynyd wonders shulde eÌfane goddê­ very myracles / his goodnes shortly broght them both to knowlege. And so doth hys especyall cure & prouydence bryng euer shortely suche falshed and faytery to lyghte to theyre shame and confusyon. And as he dyd in Berna a gret cyte in Almayne briÌg to knowlege ye fals myracles / wherby certayne frerys abusyd the people / for whych they were openly burnyd. And so god alway bryngyth such fals myracles to lyght. Â¶Nay nay q he there be many such I warrant you yt neuer â¢ uÌ to light / & ar styll taken for very good Â¶ye cannot very well warant yt q I. For syth god brought to lyghte yâ¢ false faynyd myracle of ye prestê­ of the ydoll Bell in yâ¢ old tyme / as appetyth in the xiiii. chapter of yâ¢ prophet Danyell / yt is more likly yâ¢ amoÌg crysteÌ meÌ he wyl suffer no suche thyngys longe lye hyd. And also howe can ye warraunte that many of th â¢ se myracles be false.

For whyle ther is no dowte but many be trew / and ye knowe not eny which ye precysely knowe for false / ye be not sure whyther eny be such or not. Mary quod he yâ¢ reasoÌ holdeth as well on the tother side. For syth I knowe not any whych I precysely knowe for trewe / I know not whither eny be trew or not. Nay quod I that argument wyll not serue you so. For though no maÌ bidith you to beleue yt euery thyng ys trewe yt ys told for a myracle / yet suÌ there be of whych ye must nedys rekeÌ your selfe sure / and of whych ye can not yf ye be a chrysteÌ maÌ haue any scruple or dowte. ye quod he? Fayne wold I wit whych were one of those. Mary quod I all yâ¢ are wrytten in the gospell. Mary quod he that wote I well / but them we speke not of / for they were done by god hym selfe. why q I be they not so all. If ye wyll not agre yâ¢ ye be not sure of any which be told by sayntê­ / whatsaye you by the myracles of thapostels wryten by saynt luke. Nay q he ye mysse take me yet / for I do not mean eny mistrust in the myracles doÌ of old tyme by god for hys appostellys or holy marters in coraboracyon and settyng forth of the fayth. I mene oÌly these myracles that men tell and talke of nowe a dayes / to be don at those Imagys where these pylgrymagys be / and where we see suÌ of them our selfe proued playnly false / And yet told for so trew / and so many false shrewes affyrme it / so many siple soules trust it / so mych folyshe folke be lyue it / that a maÌ may well with reasoÌ mystrust all ye remnant. Ueryly quod I and yet I thynke that â¢ ryste amoÌge chryste people suffreth not such thiÌgys to happeÌ ofte / nor such delusyoÌ to last long / but shortely (to theyre shame as yt hath appered in some) doth vt â¢â¢ r â¢ make open theyre falshed as hym selfe sayed of all such. That ye whysper one in an others ere shalbe preched oute a lowd vppon the rygge of yâ¢ house rofe.

div.head: Â¶The .xv. chapiter
div.p: Â¶The author sheweth yt yf of those miracles that are told and wrytten to be done at dyuers pylgrymagys & coÌmynly beleuyd for very trewe / we certeynly knew some falsly fayned / yet were that no cause to mystrust the remnaunt.

But be yt yt amonge so many myracles as be dayly told & wryteÌ doÌ at diuers pilgrimagê­ / betweÌ which myracles and other why ye put a deference we shall as I sayd before knowe ferther your miÌd hereafter / And be it also that of such as long haue be reputed and styll taken for trew / your selfe vndoutedly knewe sum for very false / wold ye therfore thynk that among all yâ¢ remnauÌt / ther were neuer one trew? what if ye fynd som fayer womaÌ paynted whose colour ye had went wer naturall / wyll ye neuer after beleue that any woman in the worlde hath a fayre colour of her selfe? If ye fynd som fals flatterers that long semed freÌdly wyll ye take euer after all yâ¢ world for suche? If some proue starke ipochrytes whoÌ the world wold haue sworn for good & godly meÌ / shall we therfore mystruste all other for theyr sake and wene there wer none good at all? By my troth q he I rode ons iÌ good coÌpany / & to say yâ¢ troth for good coÌpany to walsynghaÌ in pylg â¢â¢ mage / where a good felows hors so fell in haltynge yt he was fayne to hyer a nother and let hym goo lose / whych was so lene and so pore and hallted so sore yâ¢ empty as he was he could scant kepe fote with vs. And when we had went we shuld haue left hiÌ behiÌde /
sodenly he spyed a mare / and forth he lymped on thre legges so lustely / that hys masters hors wyth foure fete coud â¢â¢ aÌt ouer take hiÌ. But whaÌ he caught hym & cam agayne / he sware in greate anger all the othys he myght swere yt he wold trust haltyng syr Thomas the worse whyle he lyuyd. what was that haltiÌg syr thomas quod I. Mary q he theyr paryshe preste as he told vs / as lene and as pore and as haltynge as hys horse / and as holy to. But syn he wold whyle he lyued mystrust yâ¢ haltiÌg preste for hys haltiÌg horse / yf I fynde an holy horeson halte in ypochrysye / I shall not fayle while I lyue to trust all hys felowes the worse. well quod I ye speke merely / but I wot well ye wyll do better what so euer ye lay. Nor I aÌ sure though ye se sum whyte safyre or byrall soo well counterfete / and so set in a ryng yt a ryght goode iueller wyll take it for a dyomound / yet wyl ye not dowt for all yt but yt there be in many other ryngê­ all redy set right diamouÌtê­ in dede. Nor ye wyll not mystrust saiÌt Peter for iudas. Nor thoughe the iues were many so noughty that they put chryst to deth â¢ yet ye be wyser I wot â¢ well than the geÌtyllwomaÌ was / whych in talkyng ones wyth my father when she harde saye yt our lady was a iewe / fyrst could not beleue it / but sayd what ye mok I wylle I pray you tell trouth. And when it was so fully affermede yâ¢ she at last beleued it / & was she a Iewe quod she so helpe me god and halydoÌ I shall loue her yâ¢ worse whyle I lyue. I aÌ sure ye wyll not do so / nor mistrust all for some neyther men nor myracles

div.head: The .xvi. chapiter
div.p: Â¶Thauthor sheweth that who soo wold enquere shuld sone fynd that at pylgrymagys bene dayly many gret & vndowted myracles wroght and well knowen. And specyally he speketh of the great & open myracle shewed at our lady of Ippyl wyche of late vppon the doughter of Syr Roger went worthe knyghte.

ANd as for yâ¢ poynt yâ¢ we spake of concernyng myracles done in our dayes at diuerse imagys where these pylgrymagys be / yet could I tell you some such done so openly / so farre from all cause of suspycyoÌ / and therto testyfyed in such suf â¢ ycyent wyse / that he myght seme allmost madde yt her â¢ g yâ¢ hole mater will mystrust ye miracles. Amonge whych I durste boldelye tell you for one the woÌderfull work of god that was wtyn these few yeres wroght in the house of a ryghte worshypfull knyght syr Roger wentworth vppon dyuerse of hys chyldern / and specyally one of hys doughters a very fayr yoÌge gentyll woman of .xii. yeres of age in maruelouse maner vexyd & turmeÌ
â¢ yd by our gostely ennemy the deuyll / her mynd alienated & rauyng wt dyspisyng and blasphemye of god / and hatered of all halowed thyngê­ / wyth knowleg and perse â¢ uynge of the halowed from the vnhalowed / all were she nothyng warned therof. And after that moued in her owne mynde and moneshed by the wyll of god to goo to oure ladye of Ippyswyche. In the waye of whyche pylgrymage she prophesyed and tolde many thyngys done and sayed at the same tyme iÌ other placys whyche were proued trew / and many thyngê­ sayed lyyng in her traunce of such wysoome and letnyng that ryght connyng men hyghly marueyled to here of so yong an vnlernede mayden whan her selfe wyst not what she sayde / such thyngys vttred and spoken as well lerned men
myght haue myssed wyth a loÌge study, and fynally beyng brought and layed before the ymage of our blessed lady / â¢ as there iÌ ye syght of many worshypfull people so greuouslye turmentede / and in face eyene loke & countenauÌce so grysely chaunged wyth her mouth drawen asyde / and her eyene leyd oute vppon her chekys yt yt was a terryble syght to behold. And after many maruelouse thyngys at ye saÌe tyme shewed vppon dyuers parssones by the deuyll thorow goddys sufferauÌce / as well all the remnant as the mayden herself in the presence of all the cuÌpany restored to theyre goode state perfitely cured & sodeÌly. And iÌ thys matter no pretexte of beggyng / no suspycyoÌ of faynyng / no possybylyte of counterfettyng / no symplenesse iÌ the seers / her father and mother ryght honorable and rych sore abashed to se such chaunces in theyre chylderne / the wytnes / grete nouÌber / and many of grete worshyp / wysdome and good experyeÌce / the mayd her self to yong to fayne / and ye fashyon it self to strauÌge for any man to fayne / And the ende of the matter vertuouse / the vyrgyne so mouyd iÌ her mynde wt the myracle / that she forthwyth for ought her father could do / forsoke the world and professed relygyon in a very good and godly cumpanye at the mynoresse where she hath lyued well & graciously euer syns.

div.head: The .xvii. chapiter
div.p: Â¶The messenger laythe forth obieccyons agaynst myracles doÌe at pylgrymagys / of whych he confessyth many to be trew. but he layth causes and reasoÌs wherby he seyth yt many men be moued to beleue and thynk that those myracles yt be don there be doÌe by ye deuyll to sett our hartê­ vppon ydolatry by ye worshyppyng of ymagys in stede of god.

BUt nowe albe yt as I sayed yt I myght allege you thys myracle and proue yt you in such wyse that I wot well ye wold be as far owte of all dowte therof as ye wold be depe in the maruayle of the myracle / And peradueÌture dyuerse other could I shewe you done of late at dyuerse pylgrymagys / and proue them well to / yet wold I fayn fyrst here of you / what dystynccyon and dyffereÌce ys yt that ye make / and wherfore ye make it bitwene ye myracles don of olde tyme / and these that be now adayes don at these pylgrymagys. Syr quod he sum what a lytle I towched yt in the begynnyng & made in maner a glaunce therat. But loth wer I to hyt yt wyth a full shot and a sharpe as I haue sene sum wyth suche reasons cleeue the pryk in twayne / yt they semyd to bere ouer the but And all â¢ whych reasons I wolde be loth in so sore maner to allege / lest I myght happely gyue you suÌ occasyoÌ to thynk that eyther I set to sumwhat of myne owne / or elles at the leste wyse lyked well that syde and wer a fauorer of ye factyoÌ / Nay nay quod I fere not that hardely / for neyther aÌ I so suspecyouse to mystrust that one thynkyth euyll because he defeÌdeth the worse parte well by way of argumente and reasonyng / And also I truste that all theyr shottê­ shalbe so far to feble to bere ouer yt but that few of them shall towche ye mark / many to faynt to perce the paper / And sum to hygh / and sum to shorte / And some walk to wyde of yt but by a bow. And therfore I requyre you spare not to bryng forth all yt euer ye haue harde â¢ or that ye thynke may be sayde in the mater. Â¶Syr quod he syth ye can here
yt so indyfferently / I shall not spare to speke it. And suerly to begynne wtall yt I thynk trew I wyll not fayle to confesse. For albe yt that I haue long stycked wyth you to wythstand any credence to be geueÌ to myracles doÌ now adayes / in whych I haue moch ye leÌget stykked bycause of sum whom I haue knoweÌ ere thys so farre from ye byleue of any myracles at all / yt in good feyth they put me half iÌ dowte whether they beleue that there wer god at all / if they du â¢ st for drede & shame haue sayd all yt they semed to thynk / yet to saye the truth I neuer hard any thyng sayd so sore therin yt euer moued me to thynk yt any reason wold bere the importune mystrust of them / that amoÌg so many aÌ open myracle as ys dayly in dyuers placys doon / wolde wene that none at all wer trew. But veryly as I begoÌne a lytell to touche in the begynnynge whether these myracles be made by god & for good sayntys or by ye deuyll for oure deceyt and delusyon / albeyt I beleue & euer wyll as the chyrch doth / yet sum men among sum such thyngê­ say therin that I am dryueÌ to doo as I do in other articlys of the fayth / lene fast vnto belefe for any reason that I fynde to make them aÌswere wyth. For fyrst they take for a grouÌde yt the deuill may do myracles / Or yf we lyst / not to suffer theÌ callyd by yt name / the mater shalbe therby nothyng ameÌded. for yf we wyll haue only called by the name of myracles thyngys by god doÌ aboue nature / yet wyll we not deny but that god sufferethe ye deuyll to worke wonders whych the people caÌ not dyscerne from myracles. And therfore wheÌ they se them / myracles shall they call them / and for myracles shall they take them. Now syth yt so is that the deuyll may do suche thyngys / whereby shall we be â¢ ure that god doth them? And syth the dyuyll may do theym / & we be not sure that god doth them / why may not we aswell beleue that ye dyuyll doth them Â¶Mary sayd I ye told me that ye sett noght by Logyk / but now ye play the Logycyen out ryghte. Howe be yt that argument men may torne oÌ the tother syde & saye / that syth god may do them mych beter than the dyuyll / and we be not sure that the dyuyll doth theÌ / why shulde we not rather beleeue that god doth them / whych may do them beter. And myche more reason yt ys where a wonderfull work ys wrought there / to ascrybe yt to god the master of all mastryes / rathere than the dyuyll that can do nothyng but by su â¢ fraunce / excepte we se some cause that caÌnot suffer that work to be rekenyd goddys. Â¶well q he / than is yt reason that we shew you sum such cause. It ys quod he cause ynoughe in that we se that god hath yn scrypture forboden suche ymagry / and that vnder great maledyccyon / As yn the law. Non facies tib â¢ sculptile. And iÌ the psalme. In exitu israel de egipto / where he furst by the mouth of the Prophete / dyscrybyth the folye of suche as worshyppyth those imagys / that hath crys and cannot here / handis and can not feele / fete and cannot go / mouth & cannot speke. All whych absurdytees & vnresonable folyes apperyth aswell in the worshyp of our imagê­ as in the panyms idollys. And after he shewith the maledyccion yt shall fall theruppoÌ / Seynge lyke mote they be to them all such as make them / & all suche as puttyth theyr trust in theÌ. And forthwyth he declareth in whom good men haue theyr trust / and the profyte that procedyth theruppon saynge. Domus israel
sperauit in domino adiutor eoruÌ et êtector eorumest / The house of Israell hath put theyre truste in our lorde the helper and defender of theÌ ys he. Now when the wordys of god be clere / open and playne vppon thys syde / what reason ys yt to beleue the coÌmentys and glosys of menne wherewyth ye wold wynde owt agaynst she trew textys of god? what shulde we gyue credens to theÌnsample of meÌnys doyngê­ ageynst the playne commauÌdement of goddys wrytyngys. And wheÌ that oÌly chryste ys our sauyour and our medyatour to bryng our nature agayne to god / and our oonly proctour and aduocat afore hys father and may helpe vs best and will helpe vs most / what shall we make eyther our lady or eÌny other creature our aduocat or praye to theÌ whych of lykelyhod here vs not / For there can none of them be present at so many placys at onys as they be callede vppon. and if they were / yet arte they no nere vs then god hiÌ selfe / nor so fayne wold that we dyd well as he yt dyed for vs. and therfore whaÌ we not only doo theÌ reuerence (whyche I were conteÌt wer done them for goddes sake as ye sayd before) but also praye to them / we doo chryste and god great Iniury. For yf we pray to theÌ as medytours & aduocatê­ for vs / we take fro Cryste hys office & gyue yt them. yf we aske helpe & helth of them / then make we theÌ playne god dys and betake to them the power of ye godhed. For only god ys yt yt geuethe all good as wytnessyth saynt Iames. Euery good and very perfyte gyfte coÌ meth from aboue descendyng from the father of lyghtys. And suerly yf we coÌ syder how we behaue vs to theÌ though ye saye that all the honoure geuen to sayntes redoundeth vnto god / syth yt ys doon as ye saye not for theyr owne sakys but for hys / yet wold not I wene that god be well coÌtent that we shuld for hys sake do to any creature lyke honour as to hym selfe. For scrypture sayeth that he wyll not gyue hys glory froÌ hym nor to any other creature lyke honoure as to hym selfe / And therfore ye scolys as I here saye deuyse a treble dyfference in worshyppyng / callyng ye one dulya the reuerence or worshyp yt man dothe to man / as the bonde man to the lorde. The second yêdulya that a man doth to a more excellent creature as to angellys or sayntys. The thyrde latria the veneracyon honoure and adoracyon that cretures doth oÌly to god. In whych of these partyes ye put the worshypping of imagys / I am neyther so well sene therin to tell / nor so curyouse gretly to care. But thys I se well yf any of all these .iii. kyndes of worshyp be better theÌ other / thymagê­ hath yt. For they haue all that euer we caÌ doo. For what do wee to god when we doo worshyp hym in that fassyon yt they call latria / but we doo the same to sayntys and ymagys bothe? yf yt stande in knelyng / we knele to saintys and theyre ymagys. yf in prayeng / we praye as bytterly to them as to god. yf in sensyng and settyng vp of caÌdyllys we cense them also and sett some saynt vii. candelles agaynst god one. So yt what so euer fassyon of worshyppyng latria be / the same ys as largely don to sayntys and ymagê­ as to god / And thys not vnto ymagys only (whyche though they haue no lyfe haue yet som shappe and fassyon after man) but as menne wene vnto pyggys bonys also sumtyme. For what reuerent honour ys there dayly don vnder ye name and oppynyon of a sayntys relyke / to sum
old rotton bone that was happely sumtyme as Chaucer sayth a bone of some holy Iewes shepe. Se we not yt someone sayntys hed ys shewid iÌ .iii. placys And some one hoole sayntys body lyeth in dyuers contres / yf we beleue the lyes of ye people. And in bothe the placys ys yt one body worshypped where the one or the other ys false / and one body mystakyn for a nother / an euyll man happely for a good. And yet wyll the prestes of both placys take offryngê­ and toll men theder wyth myracles to. In whych case eyther must ye saye that the myracles of the one place bee false and feynid / or elles that myracles make not your matter good nor proue your pilgrimagê­ trew. & yet myght all this gere be mich ye beter born if it wer trew ye ye defend the thyngê­ wtall / wheÌ ye saye that in worshyppyng of sayntê­ and ymagis men worshyp neyther the tone nor ye tother as goddys / but thyngys for the sayntys and the sayntis for god. But now as yt semeth the matter ys iÌ dede far otherwyse / For the peple pray to the sayntys for theyre necessytys / puttynge thereto truste for theyre petycyons in the sayntys them selfe as though god gaue yt not but they. And in the ymagys putte the people theyre truste in stede of the sayntys self / For albe yt that yt myght stande wyth reasoÌ as ye haue aÌswered me that presupposed the myracles in these pylgrymagys to be doon by god / ye peple myght then wyth reason goo seke and vysyte such placys as god by miracle declared that he wolde haue hym selfe or hys holy sayntys sought and honored in / yet now thys answere to wcheth the poynt but in parte & matcheth not the hoole matter / For the people doo not onlye vysyte these placys and ther do all the worshyp to the sayntys yâ¢ they can possyble doo to god (wyth hope of theyre helpe from the sayntys self / whych they shuld well wyt oÌly to be geuin by god / and thus by thys demenour make the sayntys goddys fellawes / yt
â¢ s to saye the seruantys matches wt theyr master and the creaturs matys to the maker) but also vse them selfe in as relygyous fassyon / and as feruent affeccyoÌ to the ymagê­ of stone or tre / as eyther to sait or god. And playnly take these ymagê­ for the sayntys selfe and for god hym selfe. And put in these ymagê­ of theyr pylgrymagys theyre full hope & hoole trust yt they shuld put in god. Â¶whych besydes that I haue sayd byfore apperyth well in thys / that they wyll make comparysoÌs betwene our lady of Ipswych and our lady of walsyngam / As weenyng ye one ymage more of power theÌ the tother / whych they wold neuer doo / but if iÌ stede of our lady they put theyre truste in the Image selfe. And the people in spekyng of our lady / Of all our ladyes sayeth one / I loue beste our lady of walsingham / And I sayth the other oure lady of Ipeswyche. In whyche wordys what menyth she but her loue and her affeccyon to the sto â¢â¢ that standyth in ye chapell at walsyngham or Ipswych.

Â¶what say you whaÌ the peple speke of thys fassyon in theyr paynys & parellis Helpe holye crosse of Bradinan. Helpe our dere lady of walsyngham. Doth yt not playnly appere yt eyther they trust in the imagys in Crystys stede & oure ladys / lettyng Cryst and our lady go / or take at the leste wyse those ymagys so / that they wene they were verely the tone Cryst the tother our lady her self â¢ And so euery way the fayth and deuocion wythdrawen froÌ god that shulde
haue yt & our hartys by these ymagys blynded and set vppoÌ the dede stockê­ and stonys. Now se the good frute also yt foloweth theruppon. I lett passe ouer the faytery and falsehede that ys therein vsed amonge / sumtyme by the prestes / suÌtyme by beggers in fayniÌg of false myracles. Loke what deuocyon men come thyther wyth. wyth the moste com they that moste abuse them selfe / such I mene as moste trust haue and blynde fayth in these blynde ymagys. But the most part yt coÌmeth / commyth for no deuocyon at all / but only for good coÌpany to bable thyderward and drynke dronk there / and daunce & rele homward. And yet here is not all For I tell you nothyng now of many a noughty pak / many a flekke and hys make that maketh theyre metyngê­ at these holsum hallows. And many that semeth an honeste huswyfe at home / hath helpe of a bawde to bryng her to myschefe as she walketh abrode about her pylgrymagys. I harde onys when I was a chylde the good scottysh freer father d â¢â¢â¢ ld whom I reken suerly for a saynt yf there be eny iÌ heuyn / I hard hym prech at powlys crosse that our lady was a vyrgyn and yet at the pilgrymagê­ be made many a foule metyng. And loude he cryed out. ye meÌ of loÌdoÌ gang on your selfe wyth your wyffys to wyllesoon in the deuylles name or ellys kepe theÌ at heme wyth you wyth sorow. And surely so many good men wene yt were best / coÌsyderyng yt those vyagys bene but wanderyng abowte vanyte or supersticyous deuocyoÌ / and the nexte dore to Idoletry when men haue theyre af â¢ eccyons in stede of god bounden to blokkys and stonys / And now syth that thys gere ys such / what marueyle ys yt though (as I sayd before) the deuyll be gladde to geue atteÌ daunce theron / and doo for hys parte what he maye to helpe hys owne deuycys forward? Or what marueyle ys yt though god in thys cursyd world wheÌ we fall from hym to other / and from yt honoure of hym selfe to hys sayntys / when we doo as the Paynyms dyd in stede of god worshyp maÌmottys / and all thys by fallynge to folowe mennys glosys before hys one textê­ / what woÌ der ys yt though god agayn serue vs as he seruyd theÌ / and suffer the deuyll delude vs as he dyd them / and make vs lene to fals miracles as we fall wylfully to fals goddys? Thus say they q he that speke on yt syde / And yet moch more then I caÌ call to mynd. But suerly syth ye willyd me to forbere nothiÌg / I haue as I coud rather set to suÌwhat not of myn owne opynyoÌ / but of myn owne inuencyon / then any thyng left owt that I coulde remember whyche I had euer hard any man ley / to êue the myracles done at pylgrymagys to be vncertayn by whoÌ they be wroght / or rather to proue that they shulde not be goddes myracles but the deuyllys wonders.

div.head: The .xviii. chapiter
div.p: Â¶The author dyfferreth thanswere to the forsayde obieccyons. & fyrst by scrypture he proueth yt ye chyrche of chryste can not erre in eny necessary artycle of chrystys fayth. And in thys chapyter bee those wordys of cryst specyally touched. Suê cathedram Moysi sederuÌt. &c. Que dicuÌt vobis facite. que autem faciunt nolite facere / coÌcernyng the authoryte of the chyrch.

SUerly quod I for my parte I caÌ you very good thaÌk for ye haue not fayntely defendyd youre parte as
though yt were a corruptyd aduocate yt wold by colusyon haÌdell hys clyentê­ mater feebly for the pleasure of hys aduersary / but ye haue sayd therin / I caÌ tell whe â¢ her as mych as any man may say / but certenly I suppose as mich as ye eyther haue hard any man say or caÌ your self say / And at ye lest wyse much more than I haue hard of any maÌ els / or coud haue sayd of my self. And vndowtyd as ye spake of shotyng in the begynniÌg / thys gere how nere it goeth to the pryk we shall see after. But thys I promyse you yt wold fayn bere ouer the but & all. For if yt myght hold & be bidden by / and were as well ab â¢ e to be prouyd trew as I trust to êue yt fals / the but we shote at were quite gon for any suerte yt we coud rekeÌ of our fayth & cristendome. But now to cum to the poynte / Syth yt is agreed all redy betwene vs / that at these ymagys & pylgrymagys myracles bene there / eyther shewyd by god for the comprobacyon of hys plesure theryn / or woÌders wrought by the dyuyll for oure delusyon & dampnacyon / If it may eyther appere to vs yt they be not done by the dyuell / then wyll yt well folow yt they be done by god. Or yf it be prouyd to be done by god for the good of hys chirch / then wyll it be clere ynough that they be no wonders wrought by the dyuell to the dysceyt of crysten peple. And syth that eyther other of â¢ these partyes prouyd / implyeth the reprofe of your purpose / I wyll assay to shew / & trust ryght well to proue you the trouth of our syde by sum one of these ways or paradueÌture by both / that ys to wete aswell in prouyng that god doth these myracles / as in reprouing & confutyng yt they shuld be done by the dyuell. And furst wold I fayne mete wyth your obieccyons & answer them forthwyth whyle they be fresh / sauyng that me semith better for the whyle to differ them / forasmuch as sum thyngê­ therbe / wheruppon it wyll be requisyte yt we furst be both agreed: wythout whych we were lyke to walke wyde in wordys & ronne at all ryot so lose / that our mater could nother haue ground / order / nor ende. Â¶Now yf I wer in thys mater to dyspute wt a paynym that wolde make the questyon betw â¢ ne theyr myracles & ours / albeyt I shuld haue a clere mater in thend / yet must it nedys be a longe mater & much entryked or yt shuld cuÌ at thend. And hole bokys wold yt hold / both the confutyng of theyrs & vnto them thassertacyoÌ of our own / specyally for that they receyue not oure scrypture / & betwene them & vs nothyng coÌmune to grouÌd vppon but reason. And yf we shoulde dyspute wt a iew lesse labour shuld we haue / syth that we shulde haue wt hym thogh he deny the new testamente / yet reson & ye old testament agreed vppoÌ / wherin we shuld not â¢ ary for the text but for ye sentence and vnderstanding. For therein we shulde haue hym styfly wythstande vs. Â¶But now syth wee shall in our mater dyspute and reason wyth those that agree theym selfe for crysten menne / oure dyspycyons ys so much the shorter in that we muste nedys aggree to gether in moo thyngy â¢ . For wee muste agree in reason where fayth refusyth yt not. And ouer that wee shall agree vppon the hole corpus of scrypture / aswell the new testament as the olde. But in the interpretacyon wee maye paraduenture stykke. Is yt not so? Â¶yes quod he. Â¶well quod I / ys there any other thynge wherein ye thynke that wee shall vary / but the
interpretacyoÌ of the scrypture. Â¶Not that I remember quod he / except the scrypture yt self wheruppoÌ we talk / as of the worshyppyng of ymagê­ or prayeng to sayntys / in whych men thynke there can be no greate questyon yf the scrypture be well interpretyd. Â¶ ye do q I agre that such thyngys as arn meÌ cyonyd in the gospell spokyn by Cryst vnto saynt Peter & other hys apostels & dyscyples / were not only sayd to theÌ self / nor onely for them selfe / but to theÌ for theyer successours in Crystys flok / And by them to vs all / that ys to wete euery man as shall appertayne to hys parte. Â¶whereby mene you that q he. Â¶I mene quod I as for eÌsample whaÌ he sayd / Nisi abundauerit iusticia vestra plusquam ScribaruÌ & phariseo
rum / non intrabitis i â¢ regnuÌ celo
rum . Except your iustyce abound & excede ye iustyce of the Scrybys & pharesyes / ye shall neuer cuÌ in heuyn. And where he saith If thou wylt enter into the kyngdome of heuyn kepe the coÌmaundementys / dyd he not say such thyngys to theym for all crystyn men yt shuld come after? Â¶I thynke yes quod he for the seconde word concernyng the coÌmauÌdmentê­. But as for the furst / that theyr iustyce shulde be better than the iustyce of the scrybys & pharesyes / paraduenture he spake specyally to hys appostels them self / yt they shuld not be lyke ye scrybys & pharesyes / whych comaundyd other many thyngys / & dyd nothyng theym selfe. Â¶That ys in my mynde quod I well taken. and so doth holy saynt Augustyne expoune it. But syth ye think he sayd that word to hys appostels specyally rather than to all hys hole flok / whether thiÌk you that he sayd yt onely to them / or els to all other also yt shuld after come in theyr placis & succede theÌ in offyce? Â¶Nay for god q he to all ye byshoppys he sayd yt & prelatê­ & spyrytuall rulers of hys chirch yt euer shalbe in ye chyrch / forbyddyng them to binde & lay vppon other pore mennys bakkê­ importunable burdeyns / to the bering wherof theÌ self wyll not onys put forth a fynger. Â¶Uery well sayd q I. what thynke you than of that he sayd / Do ye suche thyngys as they byd you do / but do not as ye se theÌ do? Â¶In that wold our lord quod he yt all the people shuld do all that the prelatys shuld coÌmauÌd as far as was coÌmaundyd in the lawe by god / but he mente no further. And therfore he sayed that they sat vppon ye chayr of Moyses. & he wyllyd that they shuld for ye cause be obeyd. And therin he ment in such thyngys onely as they shuld coÌmaund / that were by god commaundyd the people in the law gyuen vnto Moyses. And that crystyn men in lykewise shall obey the byshoppys & prelatys / commaundynge onely suche thyngys as hym self hath coÌmaundyd hys people in hys gospell & hys owne law. Â¶And in nothyng els q I? what meanyth yt than that our Lorde in the parable of the Samarytane / beryng ye wouÌdyd maÌ into ye inne of hys church / and delyueryng hym to the hoste after that hym self had dressyd hys woundê­ wythe wyne and oyle / & lef â¢ e wyth the hoste the .ii. grotys of the two testameÌ tys / promysyd the hoste besyde / ye what so euer the hoste wolde bestowe vppon him more / he wold when he cam agayn recompense hym therfore? And also in that place that we spake of our Sauyour sayd that the Scrybys and pharesyes besyde ye law of Moyses on whose sete they satt / dyd lay greate fardellys and faste bounde them on other mennys bakkis / to the beryng wherof they
wold not moue a fynger theÌ self. And yet for all that he bad yâ¢ peple do what theyr prelatys wold byd them / though the burden were heuy / And let not to do yt though they shuld se the bydders do clene the contrary. for whych he addyd / but as they do / do not you. Â¶By oure lady q he I lyke not thys glose. For yt makyth all for the bo â¢ dys / by which the laws of the church bynde vs to more a do thaÌ ye iewes were almost wyth Moyses lawe. And I wote well Cryst sayd cum to me ye that be ouerchargyd and I shall refreshe you. And hys appostels sayd / that the bare lawe of Moyses beside the ceremonys that were set to by the scrybys & the pharesyes / were more than euer theye were able to bere and fulfyll. And therefore cryst caÌ to call vs into a law of liberte. And yt was in takyng away the bande of those wery ceremoniall lawes. And therfore sayth our sauyour of the law yt he callyth vs vnto / My yoke (saythe he) ys fyt and easy / & my burdeyn but lyght. wherby yt apperyth that he meÌt to take away the strayte yoke & put on a more easy. And to take of the heuy burdeyne & lay on a lyghter. whyche he had not done yf he wold lade vs wyth a fardell full of mennys lawes mo thaÌ a carte can cary away. Â¶The lawes of Cryste quod I be made by hym selfe & hys holy spyryte for the gouernaunce of hys people / and bee not in hardnes & dyffyculte of kepyng any thyng lyke to the lawes of Moyses. And thereof durst I for nede make your self iudge. For yf ye bethynk you well / I wene if ye were at thys age now to chose / yow wold rather be bounden to many of ye lawes of Crystys chyrch than to ye cyrcumcysyoÌ alone. Nor to as much ease as we wene that Cryste callyd vs / yet be not ye laws yt haue â¢â¢ ne made by his chyrch of halfe the payne nor halfe the dyffyculte that hys own be / whych him self puttyth in the gospell / though wee set asyde the councellys. It ys I trow more hard not to swere at all thaÌ to forswere / to forbere ech angry word than not to â¢ ill / coÌtinuall wa â¢ h & prayer theÌ a few days appoyntid. Than what an anxyete & solicytude is there in ye forberiÌg of euery ydyll word? what an hard thret after the worldly coÌpt for a small matter? Neuer was there almoste so sore a worde sayed vnto the Iues by Moyses / as ys to vs by Cryste in that worde alone where he sayethe that we shall of euery ydle worde gyue accoÌpt at the day of iugmente. what saye ye then by deuorsys restraynyd & lybertie of dyuerse wyuys wythdrawen / wher they hade lyberte to wedde for theyre pleasure yf they cast a fantesy to any yt they toke iÌ the warr. Â¶One of ye ware ys ynoughe quod he to make any one maÌ warre. Â¶Now that is merily sayd q I / but though one eye were inough for a fletcher / yet ys he for store coÌtent to kepe twayn / and wold though they were sumtyme sore both and shuld put hym to suÌ payn / what ease also call you thys that we be bounden to abyde all sorow and shamefull deth and all marterdum vppoÌ payne of perpetuall daÌpnacyon for the professyon of our fayth. Trowe ye yt these easy wordys of hys easy yoke and lyght burden were not as well spoken to hys apposteles as to you. and yet what ease called he them to. Called he not them to watchynge / fastyng / prayeng / preching / walkyng / hunger / thurst / cold / and hete / betyng / scorgynge / prysonemente / paynefull & shamefull deth. The ease of hys yoke staÌdeth not iÌ bodely ease / nor the lyghtnes of his burden standeth nott in the
slaknes of any bodely payne (excepte we be so want on that where hym selfe had not heuyn wtout payne / we loke to cum thether wt playe) but yt staÌdeth in the swetnes of hope / wherby we fele in our payne a plesaunt taste of h â¢ uyne. Thys ys ye thyng as holy saynt Gregory Nazanzeno declareth yt refresshyth men yt arn ladid / & maketh our yoke easy & our burdeyn light. not any delyueryng froÌ ye lawes of ye church or froÌ any good teÌêall lawes eyther / in to a lewd lyberte of slouthfull reste. For yt were not a easy yoke / but a pullyng of ye hed owt of ye yoke. Nor it were not a lyght burdeyn / but all ye burden dyschargyd coÌtrary to ye wordis of saint poule and saynt Peter both / which as well vnderstode the wordys of theyr mayster as these men doo. And as a thiÌg coÌsonant & well aggreable therwt doo coÌmauÌde vs obedience to our superiors & rulers one & other iÌ thyngis by god not forboden all though they bene harde & sore. Â¶But see for goddes sake how we be ronne a gret way further theÌ I thoght to go wheÌ I begane / & haue lefte yt we shuld go forth wyth all. It ys no losse quod he for there is a good thyng well towched by ye waye. well q I let vs go bak agayne where we left. syth ye agre yt chryste spake hys wordys not to hys appostels onely for theyr owne tyme / but suche thyngys as he sayd to theÌ he ment to al yt shuld folow theÌ / And ther of suÌwhat he spake to theÌ for ye prestys & bysshoppys onely / As when he sayd / vos estê­ sal terre / ye be ye salt of ye erth / & suÌwhat to ye hole flokke as when he sayd / MandatuÌ nouuÌ do vobis vt diligatis inuicem sicut ego dilexi vos. I geue you a new coÌmaundment yt you loue to gethere as I haue louyd you / Tell me theÌ I requyre you / whaÌ chryst sayd to saynt Peter / sathanas hath desyred to sy â¢â¢ e yt as men syfte corne / but I haue prayd for yâ¢ yt thy faith shall not fayle / sayde he thys to h â¢ as a promyse of ye fayth to be by goddes helpe êpetually kepte & preseruyd in saynte peter only / or elles in ye hole churche / that ys to wete ye hole coÌgregacyoÌ of chrysten people professyng his name & his fayth & abydyng in ye body of the same / not being precided & cut of / meanyng yt his fayth shuld neuer so vtterly fayle â¢ his church / but yt yt shulde hole & entyere abide & remayn theriÌ? Mary q he this ys good to be aduysed of. For though chryste for yt more parte suche thyngys as he spake to oÌe spake to all / accordiÌg to hys owne wordes / q vm dico oÌnibê° dico / yt I say to one I say to all / yet suÌ thyngis he sayd & ment perticulerly as he spake it. As when he bad saint peter cuÌ vpoÌ ye water to hym / he bad not the remenaunte com so. And so may yt êaduenture be yt thys word was spoken and ment toward Peter alone. That wylbe q I very harde to hold. For his faythe after fayled. But syth that vppon hys fyrst confessyon of the ryghte fayth that chryste was goddes soÌ / our lorde made hym hys vniuersall vicare / and vndere hym hed of hys churche / And yt for hys successour he shuld be ye fyrst vppoÌ whoÌ & whose ferme coÌfessed fayth he wolde bylde hys churche / & of any yt was oÌly maÌ make hym ye fyrste & chefe hed and ruler therof / therfore he shewyd hym that hys faythe / that is to wete the fayth by hym confessed / shuld neuer fayle in hys churche nor / neuer dyd yt / not wythstaÌdyng hys denyeÌg. For yet stode styll the lyghte of faythe in our lady / of whom wee rede in the gospell contynewall assystence to her swetest son wythout fleyng or flyttiÌg
And in all other we fynde eyther â¢â¢ riÌg from hym one tyme or other / or ellys doute of his resurreccyoÌ after hys deth (hys dere mother only excepte) For ye sygnyfycacyon and rememberaunce wherof the church yerely in the â¢ enebre lessons leueth her caÌdyll burnyng styll when all the remnaunt that signyfyeth hys appostels and dyscyples be one by one put out. And syth his fayth iÌ e â¢ tect fayled / and yet the faythe yt he êfessyd abode styll in our lady / ye promyse that god made was (as it semith) ment not to hym / but as hed of the churche. And therfore our lorde added therto / And thou beyng one of these dayes conuertyd / conferme & strength thy brethern. In whych by these wordê­ our sauyour meÌt & êmysed that ye fayth shuld stand foreuer. So yt the gates of hell shulde not preuayle there agaynste. Or elles myght ye say yt these wordys spoken to saynt peter / fede my shepe / was meÌt but for hym selfe / & no coÌmaundmente to any successour of his or any bysshop or prelate. Andby that mean myght ye say also that these wordes of Chrystys promyse made vnto his dyssyples that the holy goste shuld enstructe them of all thyngys / were only mente for them selfe in theyre owne parsons. And not that euer he shulde eÌstructe his church af â¢ ere theyre dayes.
