Â¶But as I began to say / the holy appostels beynge taughte by theyr grete master Cryste / did reche vnto ye chyrch as well the artycles of the fayth / as the vnd â¢ rstandyng of such textys of scrypture as was meete and conuenient for the matter. wherby it is not vnlykly yt the gospell of saynt Iohn / & the epistels of saynt Poule / were than beter vnderstanden among the comen people / thaÌ they be paraduenture now wyth some that take them selfe for greate clerkys. And as thappostels at yt tyme taughte the people / so dyd euer some of them yt hard theÌ tech forth and leue theyr doctryne and tradycyons to other that caÌ after. By resoÌ whereof not onely cam the rytys and sacramentys and the artycles of our fayth froÌ haÌd to hand / froÌ Cryste & his appostels vnto our days / but also the greate parte of the ryghte vnderstandynge of holy scrypture by good and godly writers of sundry tymys. By whose good & holesome doctryne set forthe by theyre vertew wyth goddys good inspyracyon grace and h â¢ lp of the holy goste / we haue also the knowlege & parceyuynge what was ye fayth of Crystys church in euery tyme syns. And thereby parceyue we yt these hereti â¢ ys be not only barkers agaynst ye fayth that now is / but also that hath bene euer synnys Cryste dyed. Â¶And therefore is holy scrypture as I sayd ye hyest & the best lernynge that eny man can haue / yf one take the ryght way in the lernynge. Â¶It ys (as a good holy saynte saythe) so maruelously temperyd / that a mouse may wade therin / and an olyphaunt be drownyd therin. For ther is no maÌ so low / but if he will seke his way wyth the staff of his faith in hys hande / and holde that faste and serche the way therwyth / and haue the olde holy fathers also for his gidis / goynge oÌ wyth a good purpose & a lowly harte / vsyng reason and refusinge
no good lerninge / with calling of god for wysdome grace & help that he may well kepe his way and follow his good gidys / thaÌ shall he neuer fall in parell / but well and suerly wade thorow and cum to suche ende of his iorney as him self wolde well wyshe. But suerly if he be as long as Longius / & haue an hye harte and truste vppon hys one wytt (as he doth loke he neuer so louly / that settethe all the olde holy fathers att noughte) that fellow shall not fayle to synk ouer the eris and droune. And of all wreches warst shall he walke / yt forciÌg litle of the fayth of Christê­ church / cuÌmeth to the scrypture of god to loke and trye therin whyther the chyrche by leue a right or not. For either douteth he whyther Chryste teche hys chyrche trew / or ellys whyther Chryste techeth it at all or not. And thaÌ he doutith whither Christ iÌ his wordis did say trewe / whan he sayde he wolde be wythe hys chyrch tyll the ende of the worlde. And surely the thynge yt made Arrius Pelagius / Faustus / Manicheê° / Donatê° / Eluidius & all ye table of the old herytikes to drown them self in those daÌpnable herysyes / was nothynge but hygh pride of theyre lernynge in scrypture / wherin they folowed there owne wyttys and lefte the coÌmen faythe of the catholyke chyrche / preferrynge theyre own gay glosys bifore the ryght catholyke fayth of all Christis chirch / which caÌ neuer erre in eny substaÌciall poynte that god wolde haue vs boundeÌ to byleue. And therfore to ende wher we bygan / who so wyll not vnto the study of scrypture take the poyntê­ of ye catholyque fayth as a rule of interpretacyon / but of dyffydens and mystruste study to seke in scrypture whyther the fayth of the chyrch be trew or not / he caÌ not fayle to fall in worse errors & farr more ieoperdous than eny maÌ can do by phylosophy / wherof the reasons and argumentys in maters of our faythe haue nothyng the lyke authorytye.

div.head: Â¶The .xxvi. chapyter
div.p: Â¶The messenger sayenge that hym semed he shulde not byleue ye chyrch if he saw the chyrche saye one thyng and holy scrypture a nother thynge because the scrypture is the word of god / the author she wyth yt the fayth of the chyrch ys the word of god as well as the scrypture / aÌd therfore as well to be beleuyd. And yt the fayth & the scrypture well vnde â¢ staÌden be neuer coÌtrary. And farther she with yt vppon all doutys rysynge vppon holy scrypture concernynge any necessary artycle of the faythe / he that cannot vppon all that he caÌ here in the mater oÌ both the sydys parceyue ye beter & trewer parte / hath a sure & vndoutable refuge êuydyd him by the goodnes of god to brynge hym out of all êplexyte / in that god hath coÌmaundyd hym in all such doutys to beleue hys chyrch.

TRuly syr q he me thynketh it is well sayed that ye haue sayed. And in good faythe to say the truth I se not what I shuld answere yt wythall. And yet whan I loke bak agayne vppoÌ holy scrypture / and consyder that yt ys goddys owne wordys whyche I wote well ye wyll graunte / I fynde it harde iÌ myne har â¢ to beleue all the meÌ yn the hole world / yf they wolde say eny thyng wherof I shuld se that the hol â¢ scrypture sayth ye contrary / sythe yt ys reason that I beleue god alone far better than theÌ all. Â¶In that quod I ye say very trouthe. But nowe I putt case that god wolde
tell you .ii. thyngys whether of theym wolde ye beleue best. Â¶Nether nother q he / but I wolde byleue theym bothe firmly & both a like Â¶. what if neyther nother quod I were lykely to be trew but semede bothe twayne impossyble. Â¶That shold quod he make litle force to me. For that onis knowen that god telleth theym / semed they neuer so far vnlikly nor neuer so far impossible / I neyther shuld nor could haue eny dout but that they were both twayne trew. Â¶That ys well sayde q I. But now and yt so were that those .ii. thyngis semed the tone to the tother clene coÌtrary / what wolde ye than thynk & which wolde ye thaÌ byleue? Â¶yet could I not quod he dout eny thyng but that they were very trew bothe / but I wolde veryly thynke that I dyd not well vnder stande the tone of theym. Â¶what wold ye than do quod I if he bad you bileue theym bothe. Â¶Mary q he than wold I praye hym tell me furste how he vnderstandeth theym bothe. For though I bileue that they be both trew in that sense and purpose that he takythe hys owne wordes / and may in that maner vnderstanden / well stande and agree to gether / yet can I not byleue theym both in that sense and vnderstandyng wherin they repugne and be directely coÌtrary eche to other. Â¶That is quod I so well sayd yt in my mynde no man caÌ amend yt. Â¶But now wold I wytt quod I whyther that the faythe of the chyrche be the worde of god / & by god spoken to the chyrche or not. Â¶yes q he god speketh to hys chyrche in ye scripture. And ys nothyng goddes wordê­. q I but scrypture? The wordys yt god spake to Moyses were theye not goddys wordys all tyll they were wrytteÌ? And the wordys of Chryste to hys aposteles were they not hys wordys till they were wrytteÌ? Â¶yes than quod he. But now sythe he hathe perfyted and finished the corpus of holy scrypture / all thynge that he wold chrysteÌ people shulde byleue / and all that he wold the chyrche wold do / and all that he wold the churche shuld eschew / all thys hath he lefte theym hys mynde suffycyently in holy scrypture. Â¶And none other wyse quod I bysyde? I had wentt we had bene at a nother poynt / in that ye se ye sabbat day chaunged in to soÌday wythoute eny worde of scrypture / geuyng eny coÌmauÌdement of ye chaunge in the new testement / from the coÌmauÌ demente geuyn for the saterday in the olde. And also for the poynte that we spake of / towchinge the perpetuall virginite of our lady wherof ys no worde wrytten in scrypture. But syth I perceyue that the grete affeccyoÌ and reuerence that ye bere to the scrypture of god / not wythout greate cause but wt out eny mesure / makethe you in the case that ye take all authoryte and credence from euery word of god spoken besyde the scrypture / I wolde ask yow therfore thys questyon. If god yn holy scrypture tell you .ii. thyngê­ that seme the tone contrary to the to â¢ here / as for ensample yf he tell yow in one place yâ¢ he ys lesse than hys father / and in a no there place that he and his father be all one / whych of these wyll you beleue?

Â¶Mary quod he both twayn. for they may stande to gether well inough. For he was lesse as man / & was all one & egall as god. Â¶Uery trouth yt ys quod I that ye say. But now yf ye had bene born in ye days of Arrius the heretyke / he wolde not haue receyuyd nor holde hym self contente wyth thys answere / but he wold haue agreed you the furst
parte and put you ferther to proue the secunde parte. And vnto that t â¢â¢ te he wolde haue made you a glose that hys father & he were one not in substaunce but in wyll. And that glose he wolde haue fortyfyed & made suÌwhat semely wyth a nother word of Chryste iÌ which he prayed hys father sayyng / as thou & and I be bothe one so make thou that they & we may be made one / meniÌg by hys chrysten peole whyche shall neuer be one wyth hym in substance. So yt for the inequalitie of Chryst by reason of hys maÌhed / ye must agre wyth him. But for vnyte of godhed / he wyll not agree wythe hym but putt you alway to proue it. Â¶well quod he and thoghe he so dyd yet yf I were prouydid there fore / therbe textis ynowe that playnly proue yt. Â¶That is quod I very truth But yet ys there none but he shall alway set you a nother agaynste yt / and a glose as faste for yours as ye shall haue an answere for hys / in such wyse as he may abuse a right wyse and well lernyd man as he dyd iÌ hys owne days & many dayes after many a thousaÌd. Than yf yt so were that in that dyspycyons ye coude not make youre audyence to dyscerne the truthe / nor peraduenture persuade theym to byleue the truthe / bycause the false parte myghte happe to haue to the myndys of many a more face of trewth / as it had at that tyme to manye that than were of that secte / what way wold ye wynde oute? Â¶Mary quod he I wolde byleue well my selfe the trewthe & go to god / and lett theym that wolde byleue the false parte go to the deuyll / Â¶ye shulde q I haue takyn therin a good sure way. But now yf ye had bene in that tyme (albe yt ye be now faste and sure in the trewthe) ye myght haue happed whyle the matter was in questyone / & many greate clarkys & well scryptured men / and some semyng ryght holy / sett on the wronge syde / ye myghte haue happed I say so to haue bene moued wi â¢ h the reasons on bothe the sides / that ye shulde not haue wyste on whych parte to determyne your byleue. And what wolde ye than haue done? Â¶Quod he ye put me now to a pynch / and I shall ans â¢ ere you as I haue harde say that doctor Mayo sumtyme almoigner to kyng henry yâ¢ seuynth answered onys the kynge at hys table. It happed that ther was fallen in coÌmunicacioÌ yâ¢ story of Ioseph how his masters Putiphers wyfe a greate maÌ wt yâ¢ kyng of Egipt / wold haue pullid hym to bed / & he fled away. Now master Mayo (q ye kingê­ grace) ye be a tall stronge man on the tone syde / and a cunnynge doctor on ye tother syde / what wold ye haue done yf ye had bene not Iosephe but in Iosephes stede? By my trouthe syr q he and yt lyke your grace / I can not tell you what I wold haue don but I can tell you well what I shulde haue don.

By my trouthe quod the kynge that was very well answerid. And sith that answere serued hym well there / I shall make ye same serue me here. For surely if I had bene in Arrius days iÌ ye poynt that ye speke of / what I wold haue doÌ that wot I nere. But what I shulde haue done that can I well tel you and surely trust I wolde haue done so too. Â¶what ys yt quod I. Â¶Mary I wolde haue byleued the beste quod he. Â¶The best quod I? that were beste in dede yf ye wyst whych yt were. But the case ys put / that the reasons grounded vppon scrypture semyd vnto you in such wise eche to impugne and answere other / yt ye stode in such a dout / that ye coud in
no wy â¢ e dyscerne whythere syde sayde best. Â¶By god quod he I had forgoteÌ that. well than were it beste quod he / and so wolde I haue done I thynke / knele me downe and make my speciall prayour to god yt yt myght please hys goodnes iÌ so great a parell not to leue me êplexed / but vouchesafe to enclyne myne assent vnto that syde yt he knew were trew / and wolde I shulde byleue to be trew. And then wold I boldly byleue the tone whyche god shulde haue put in my mynde. Had not thys bene ye best way? Â¶If yt were not quod I the best / yt myght paraduenture serue for a seconde. Â¶A secunde quod he thaÌ ye take yt for noughte. Â¶Nay quod I / ther be two secondys after two maner countyngys. One nexte vnto yâ¢ worst / a nother nexte vnto ye beste. And your way ys surely far fro yâ¢ worste. But yet dare I not assent that yt were the beste tyll I vnderstand yt better. And therfore I pray you tell me thys. If after your speciall prayours made / ye wrote the tone parte in one paper and the tother parte iÌ a nother and layed theym both on the grounde / and then sett vp aÌ staffe bytwene theym both / wolde ye be then indefferent to take yâ¢ tone side or yâ¢ tother after / as yt shulde hap your staffe to fall? Â¶why not quod he. Or ellys put yt vppon two lottys / and than at auenture drawe the tone & take yt. For wheÌ I haue done as mych as mine owne wyt wyll serue / and haue harde therto all that I can of other meÌ / and yet by neyther can perceyue the better opinioÌ / what shuld I do or what could I do ferther thaÌ pray for grace to gide my choyce / and so at auenture bol â¢ dly take ye tone and holde it fast / dowtyng nothynge but god assysted my choyce / yf I haue a ferm fayth in hys promyse by whyche he promyseth that yf we as â¢ we shall haue askyng as saynt Iamys sayeth wythout any dowte. And why shulde not I in suche perplexed case after help callid for of god / take the tone parte at aduenture by lot as dyd thappostels in the chesyng of a new / to fulfyll yâ¢ place of yâ¢ tratour Iudas? Â¶Lottys quod I be well lawfull iÌ the choyse of such two thyngê­ as be both so good yt we be lykly to chose well inough why there so euer we take. But now yf ye were in the case that I haue harde my father meryly say euery man ys at the choyse of hys wyfe / that ye shulde put your hande in to a blynde bagg full of snakys & elys to gether .vii. snakis for oÌe ele / ye wold I wene rekeÌ it a êilous choyse to take vppe one at aduenture though ye had made your speciall prayour to spede well. Nor ye ought not in suche case to aduenture it vppon your prayour and trust of god wythout necessytye. Â¶That ys êadueÌture trouth quod he. But in our case there ys necessytye. For there were none othere way to auoyde the êplexitie / but euyn take the tone by prayour and ferm truste in god / whyche neuer deceyued theym yt truste in hym. Â¶If there were quod I none other way sumwhat were it than yt ye say. But now consyder your case agayne. And whan yt so were that ye coulde not vppon that ye hard the Arryanys and the catholyke parte argue to gether / parceyue whyther part were the better / and therfore of those two talys tolde you by god in many textis of holy scrypture / some semynge playnely to say that Cryste was not egall wyth hys father / some semynge as playnely to say the contrary / ye coud in no wise fynde ony reason / whereby ye coulde finde your self moued to take the tone
parte for more probable than yâ¢ tother. I put case than that god wold hym self saye to you I haue shewed the trouthe of this mater to suche a man / and how my scrypture ys to be vnderstandeÌ coÌ cernyng the same. Go thy wayes therfore to hym. And that thyng yt he shall tell the that thyng byleue thou. wolde ye saye nay good lorde I wyll aske no man but thy self / and therefore tell me thyne owne mouth / or els I wyll take the tone parte at all aduentures / and thynke that thou wolde haue yt so / or ellys wold ye thynke yt god were your good lorde & had done myche for you in that it lykyde hym so graciously for your surete to brynge you oute of such a great perplexitye / wherby ye shulde for your owne mynde haue remayned in an insoluble dowte iÌ a mater of the fayth / whereiÌ it ys damnable to dwell in dowte or (whyche y â¢ t myche worse were) haue declyned peraduenture in to an inuyncyble errour? Â¶Ueryly q he greate cause shuld I haue had lightly to thanke god. Â¶ ye wolde not than quod I fyrste make your prayour and than wyth good hope that grace shall guyde your fortune take yâ¢ tone parte at aueÌture by lot / but ye wold in your prayour thank god for that prouysioÌ. And theÌ wold ye get you to that man as faste as ye coulde. Â¶Uery trouthe quod he. Â¶Than yf yt man shulde tell you that Arryus and his cuÌpany were herytyques all and toke textis of scripture wronge ye wold bileue hym? Â¶ye veryly quod he yt wold I. Â¶I put case quod I that ye had not dowted byfore b â¢ t had bene iÌ your self at clere poynte yt yâ¢ Arryans opynyoÌ were the trouth / â¢ et ye wolde agaynste Arrius and all hys / and agaynst your own mynd also lene vnto hys worde / whome god had beden you bylefe. Â¶what els quod he? Â¶what yf ye asked hym q I whythere god haue suffycyently shewed yt poynt in scrypture / so that yt may by the wordys of holy wrytt well and euydentlye be proued / and yt he tolde you ye / And that theruppon he wolde brynge in all the textys that ye had well in remembraunce all redy / & yt ye layed agaynste theym all that you coulde lay for the coÌ trary / so ferforth that whaÌ eche of you had layed all your textys and all your glosys that eyther of you bothe could brynge forthe tyll ye bothe confessyd yt neyther of ye bothe coulde eny ferther thyng fynde therin / he sayenge styll yt hys way were the truthe and yt he had by sc â¢ ypture well proued yt vnto you / and your selfe on the tother side for all that euer ye had hard hym say / parceyuyng in your owne mynde none other but that ye had by scrypture better prouyd the tother ête / which wold ye now bileue / that way that as far â¢ e as ye see god sayth him self in holy scrypture / or els that man whom god sente you to & bade you beleue? Â¶Nay verely q he I wolde byleue hym. Â¶well sayde quod I. But whether wold ye onely beleeue him that the trowth of the mater were agaynst the Arryans / or els wold you beleue hym ferther in yt he sayd he had so prouyd yt vnto you by scrypture. Â¶I wold q he beleue hym therin also. For syth god so had coÌmaunded me / & had shewed me that he had him selfe instructyd that maÌ in what sence yâ¢ scrypture were to be vnderstanden / I coud none otherwyse thynke / but that were trew / and thowgh it apperyd to myne own reason the contrary. Â¶Uery well sayd q I. Now if god had sayed vnto you that ye shulde byleue that man coÌ cerning the matter selfe / & of scrypture
had nothyng spokeÌ / than wold ye haue byleuyd hym yet in the mater? wold ye not all though he shuld haue tolde you that he vnderstode no scripture at all? Â¶That ys trew quod he. Â¶Now yf he sholde then haue tolde you that the Arryanys were herytyques in yt poynte and theyre opynion erroniouse & false / ye wolde haue byleuede hym? Â¶what els q he. Â¶what if he had told you ther wyth quod I that he wyste nere whyther yt myght be well proued by scrypture or not? Â¶yet wolde I quod he neuerthelesse byleue to be trewe the mater selfe that he had tolde me. Â¶ what wolde you than think quod I of those textys that ye reken byfore well & plaiÌ ly to proue the contrary? Â¶I wolde q he than reken that they were mente suÌ other wayes thaÌ I could vnderstand. For I could not doute but beiÌg trewly vnderstanden / theye coulde neuer wytnes agaynste yâ¢ trouh. Â¶In good faith quod I ye say maruelously well. Doo ye nott quod I take yt for all one whyther god byd you do a thynge hys owne mouthe or byd you by holy scrypture? Â¶yes quod he sauiÌg / that I take the byddinge by scrypture for the more sure. For there wot I wel god speketh & I can not be illuded. Â¶Now quod I thys man that god byddeth you go to & in all thyng byleue hym wyll it make â¢ ny chaunge in our mater whyther yt be man or woman? Â¶No chaunge at all quod he. what yf yt were a certeyn knowen cumpany of men and women to gether quod I wold that make eny dyfference. Â¶Neuer a whyt quod he. Â¶Than quod I in case yt apere vnto you as I suppose it doth to you and to euery christen man els / yt in all poyntê­ of fayth both in thyngys to be byleued aboue nature / and in thyngê­ also that ar of nece â¢â¢ itie to be knoweÌ & byleuyd / whych may be perceyued by reason geuyn vs wyth nature / god geueth vs in coÌmauÌdement that we shall byleue his chyrch / than are ye full answered. For than haue ye the man that ye muste nedys resorte vnto for your fynall aÌswer and solusyon of all poyntys and dowtys / in eny wyse concernynge the saluacyon of your soule. of whyche poyntys no man can denye / but one of the most especiall poynte is to take in holy scripture alway the ryght sense. Or ellys yf we cannot attayne the ryght vnderstaÌ dynge / yet than at the leste wyse to be sure that we shall auoyde and eschewe all such misse takyng as myght brynge vs in to eny damnable errour.

div.head: Â¶The .xxvii. chapyter
div.p: Â¶Thauthor prouyth that god hath coÌmauÌdid vs in all thyng necessary to saluacion to gyue ferme credence and full obedyence vnto his church. And a cause why god wyll haue vs bounden to byleue.

THat is trothe quod he if this may appere. But where shal it appere that god coÌmaundyth vs in all such thyngys to beleue ye chyrch? For furste me thynkyth yt were a very strange maner of coÌmauÌ
â¢ yng. For of the church be all we that shulde as ye say bee by god coÌmaunded to beleue the chyrche / And all we to gether make the hole chyrch. And what reasoÌ were yt than to coÌmaund vs to beleue the chyrche. whych were no more in effect / but to byd vs all beleue vs all / or eche of vs to beleue other. And then yf we fell at dyuers oppynioÌs / why shuld the tone parte more beleue the tother / thaÌ be beleuyd of the tother / sith bothe the partys be of the chyrch and make ye chyrch amoÌg them? sauyng that alwey
that parte semeth to byleue whych best and moste clerely can alledge yâ¢ scrypture for theyre opynyoÌ. For the wordes of god must breke ye stryfe. He is onely to byleued & hys onely sonne of whom him self commaunded. Ipsum audite / here hym sayd the father at the tyme of hys baptysme. And therfore the maÌ yâ¢ ye speke of whome god sendeth me to / and whom he byddeth me here and byleue / ys our sauyour Cryst onely / and not eny congregacyon of men. whose wordes yf we byleue byfore ye wordes of god / and in the s â¢ ede of the scripture of god put our truste and con â¢ ydence in ye doctryne & ordynauÌce of ye chyrch / it were happely to be fered / lest we fall in the reprofe that ys touched in ye gospell where is sayed / in vayne wurshup they me wyth the doctryne of meÌ / and where our sauyour also reproueth the scrybes & the pharesyes saynge vnto theym / wherfore do you breke & transgresse the coÌmauÌdemeÌt of god for your tradycyons. Â¶I trust q I yet at laste we shall agre. But myche a do me thiÌ keth it ys to cuÌ to it. But syth we must as ye say and treuth yt ys / here our sauyour Chryste and byleue hym / ys yt ynough to here hym and byleue hym / or be we bysydes that also bounden to obay hym? Â¶To obay hym also q he. For els were he better vnherd. Â¶well sayd quod I. But whyther are we bouÌ den to here hym and obay hym in som thynges or in all thinges? Â¶In all thiÌ ges quod he wythout excepcyoÌ that he coÌmauÌdeth vs to do. Â¶ThaÌ yf Chryst quod I bydde vs byleue and obay hys chyrch / be we not bouÌdeÌ so to do. Â¶yes quod he? &Than may we quod â¢ no more dowt to be trew what so yâ¢ chy â¢ ch byddeth vs byleue / than the thynge yt our sauyour hym self byddeth vs byleue / yf he bydde vs here hys chyrche as his father bad vs here hym. Â¶That is trouth q he yf he so do / but me thynketh yt were a straunge byddyng as I sayd to byd eche of vs of bileue other. Â¶It seme â¢â¢ not q I so strauÌge a thiÌg to Seynt Poule. For he meruelouse effectually besecheth Chrysten people to agree to gether all in one mynde / and in the fayth to tell one tale / sufferyng no sectis or scismes amoÌg theym. whych agrement & consent caÌ neuer be where no maÌ geueth credeÌce to other. But amoÌg ChristeÌ people yt w â¢ ll sone be / yf euery man geue credence to the chirch. Â¶But yet q he syth all be of the chyrch of dyuerse parties / whych shall byleue whych? Â¶ye take yâ¢ quod I for a grete dowt & a thiÌg very êplex / whych semeth me very playn. For eyther fi â¢ st yâ¢ chyrche hath ye treuth & byleue all one way tyll som one or som fewe begynne yt chaunge / and than though all be yet of yâ¢ chyrch tyll som by theyr obstynacie be gone oute or put oute / yet ys yt no â¢ owt but yf I wyll byleue yâ¢ chyrche I must byleue theym yt styll byleue that way whych all ye hole byleued byfore / or els yf there were eny thynge yt was êadueÌture such / yt in yâ¢ church somtym was dowted & reputed for vnreueled & vnknoweÌ / yf after yt ye holy chryche fall iÌ one coÌseÌt vppoÌ ye tone syde / eyther by coÌmeÌ determynacyoÌ at a generall couÌ sayle or by a êfyte perswasyoÌ & bylyefe so receyued thorough christendoÌ yt the ChrysteÌ peple thiÌk it a daÌpnable errour to byleue ye coÌtrary / thaÌ yf eny wold after yt take ye coÌtrary way were it one or moo / were yt fewe or many / were they lerned or vnlerned / were they ley peple or of ye clergie / yet caÌ I nothiÌg dowte whych ê â¢ e to bileue yf I wyl bileue the chirch. Â¶yt is trouht q he. But ye êue
me not yet that god hath boden me byleue the chyrche. Â¶ ye sumwhat interrupted me quod I with your other subtylty / by whych ye wold yt shold seme an absurdytye to bydde vs byleue the chyrch / For as mych as therby ye sayd yt shulde seme yt we were coÌmaunded nothyng els but eche to byleue other / and than in dyuerse opynyons taken we coud not wyt whyche parte shulde byleue whych. wherof syth I haue shewed you the contrary and remoued ye blocke oute of the way for stumblyng / we shall I thiÌk sone se yt tother poynt / that Cryst coÌmauÌdith vs to byleue his chyrch. For as hys father sayd of hiÌ self here hym / so sayd he of hys chyrch whaÌ he sent it abrode to be spred forth. For whaÌ he had gathered hys chyrch of hys apostles & hys dyscyples and theruppoÌ set theym forth to preche / sayed he not vnto theym / he that hereth you hereth me? Dyd he not also coÌmaunde yt who so wolde not here the chyrche shulde be reputed and taken as paynyms and publycanys? Â¶That was q he where men wold not amende theyre lyuyng. Â¶was yt not q I generall where a maÌ wold not amiÌde eny dampnable fawte? Â¶yes q he. Â¶Is mysbelefe quod I none suche? Â¶yes mary q he. Â¶Than ys quod I the chyrche hys Iudge vppoÌ hys byleue / to shew hym whyther it be trew or false. Â¶So yt semeth quod he. Â¶Hath hys lyuyng quod I no thynge a do wyth fayth? Â¶How meane you yt quod he? Â¶Thus quod I as yf Luther late a frere and hauyng now wedded a NuÌne / were coÌmaunded to amende hys lewde lyuyng and put away that harlot whome he abuseth in coÌtynuall inceste and sacrylege vnder ye name of a wyfe / and he wolde say yt he dyd well ynough / and that theyr vowes coude not bynde theym / were he not boundeÌ to byleue ye chyrche and obay therto as well coÌcerniÌg hys bylefe as his lyuiÌg? Â¶yes veryly quod he. Â¶ThaÌ appereth yt quod I that we be by Cryst coÌmauÌ ded to here / byleue & obay yt chyrche as well in maters of fayth as of maners. whych thiÌg well appereth also by yâ¢ our lorde wold yâ¢ who so were dysobedyeÌt shulde be taken as a paynyme or a publycane. Of whych .ii. yâ¢ tone offeÌded iÌ mys â¢ yleue the tother in lewd lyuiÌg. & thus yt appereth yt not onely Cryst ys the maÌ yt ye be seÌt vnto & coÌmauÌded be god to byleue & obay / but also ye chyrch ys the êsone whom ye be by Cryste coÌ mauÌded to here and byleue and obay. And therfore yf ye wyll in fayth or lyuiÌg or a voydiÌg of all daÌpnable errour yt ye myght fall in by mysse vnderstaÌ diÌg of scriptur take a sure & vnfallyble way / ye must in all these thynges her â¢ /byleue and obay the chyrch / whyche ys as I say the persone whom Cryst sendeth you to for the sure solucyon of all suche doutys / as to the man in whose mouth he speketh hym selfe and the holy spyryte of hys father in heuiÌ. Â¶And surely thys ys mych to be marked. For yt ys the perpetuall order whyche our lord hath contynued in the gouernauÌ ce of good men frome the bygynnyg / ye lyke as our nature fyrst fell by pryde to ye dysobedyeÌce of god wt inordynate desyre of knowlege lyke vnto god / so hath god euer kept maÌ iÌ humilytye / strayniÌg hym wt ye knowlege & coÌfessyoÌ of hys ygnorauÌnce / and byndiÌg hym to yt obedyeÌnce of bylyue of certayn thiÌges wherof his own wit wold verely wene yt coÌtrary. & therfore are we bouÌdeÌ not oÌly to bileue agaiÌst our own resoÌ yâ¢ poiÌ tê­ yt god sheweth vs iÌ scriptur / but also yt god techith his chirch wtout scriptur &
agaynst our owne miÌde also / to gyue dylygent heryng / ferme credence / and faythfull obedieÌce to yt chyrch of chryst / concernyng the sence & vnderstaÌdyng of holy scripture. Not dowtiÌg but sith he hath coÌmaÌded his shepe to be fedde / he hath prouyded for theym holesome mete and trewe doctryne. And that he hath therfore so farre inspyred the olde holy doctours of his chyrch wt the lyght of his grace for our instruc â¢ yoÌ / that ye doctrine wherin they haue agreed and by many agys conseÌted / is yt very true fayth and ryght way to heuyn / beyng put in theyr myndes by the holy haÌd of hym / qui facit vnanimes iÌ domo / yt maketh yâ¢ chyrch of Cryst all of one mynd.

div.head: The .xxviii. chapyter
div.p: Â¶The messenger eft sonys obiected agaynst thys / that we shulde byleue yâ¢ chyrch iÌ any thyng where we fynd ye wordes of scrypture semiÌg playnely to say the contrary / or byleue yâ¢ olde doctours interpretacyons in any necessary artycle / where they seme to vs to say coÌtrary to ye texte. shewiÌg yt we may êceyue yâ¢ scripture aswel as they might. & ye answer of ye author êuiÌg ye authorite of ye old interpters & ye infallible authorite of ye chirch iÌ yâ¢ god techith it euery truthe requysite to ye necessite of maÌnys saluacyoÌ. which he êueth by a deducey oÌ êtely depeÌdiÌg vppoÌ naturall resoÌ.

IT semeth me quod he that all thys goth well that we shulde byleue the chyrch as chryst / as longe as they say as Cryst sayth / for some thynkethe ment our lorde. Â¶But now yf they tel me talis of theyr owne wherof Cryst neuer spake worde nor mencyoÌ made therof in holy scrypture I may thaÌ say wt ye êphet Hieremie / noÌ mittebaÌ prophetas et ipsi currebant. Non loquebar ad eds et ipsi prophetabant / those prophetis (quod our lord) ranne forthe of theyre owne hed and I sent theym not / And êphecyed of theyr owne heddes whaÌ I spake nothyng to theym. And than how myche may I more say so / yf they say me a thynge wherof Cryste or holy scrypture sayth the contrary / shall I byleue the chyrch aboue chyrste? were that a good humylyte to be obedyent more to menne than to god? More ought I me thynketh to byleue god aboue spekynge in hys holy scrypture hym selfe / than all the olde fathers yf they make a glose agaynste the texte. Nor they doo nott theym selfe for theyre opynyons say & wryte / that they haue theym by inspyracyon / or by reuelacyon / or by myracle. But by wysedome / studye / dylygence / and collacyoÌ of one texte wyth a nother. By all whych meanys men may now perceyue the senteÌce of scrypture as well as they myght than. And yf ye wyll peraduenture say that grace holpe the â¢ m whych I wyll well agree / than wyll I say agayne that goddys grace is not so farre worn oute yet / but yâ¢ yt may as well helpe vs as yt holpe theym / and so may we be for the ryght vnderstandynge of scrypture equall wyth theym / and peraduenture one ace aboue theym. wherby whan we êceyue that they went wrong and other after theym / shall we than call yt humylyte so to captyue & subdue our vnderstandynge / wherby god hath happely geuen vs lyght to perceyue theyr errours / yt without thank geuyn him therfore we shall so sett hys gyfte at nought / that we shall byleue theym byfore hym selfe / & tell hym yt hym self bad so â¢
â¢ therfore me thiÌke where yâ¢ old doctours or the holy chyrche telleth me
the tale that god doth / ther he byddeth me byleue theym. But where god sayeth one thynge in scrypture and they tell me a nother / yt thynkith me that I shuld in no wyse byleue theym. Â¶well quod I than in suÌwhat ye saye ye will bileue the chirch but not in all. In eny thynge bysyde scrypture ye wyll not / nor in the interpretacion of scrypture ye wyll not. And so where ye sayed yt ye byleue ye chyrch in suÌwhat / in very dede ye beleue ye church iÌ right nought. For wherein wyll ye byleue yt yf ye byleue it not in the interpretacioÌ of scripture? For as touchynge the texte ye byleue the scrypture self and not ye chirch Â¶Me thynketh q he the text ys good ynough and playne ynough nedynge no glose yf yt be well consydered & euery parte compared with other. Â¶Hard yt were quod I to fynde eny thynge so playne that yt shulde nede no glose at all. Â¶In faythe quod he theye make a glo â¢ e to suÌ textys / yt be as playne as yt is yâ¢ twise two make four. Â¶why quod I nedeth yt no glose at all? Â¶I trow so quod he. Or els the deuyll ys oÌ yt / Â¶I wysse quod I / and yet though ye wole bileue one yt wold tell you yt twise two gaÌders made alway foure gese / yet ye wolde be aduysed ere ye byleued hym that wolde tell you yt twyse two geese made alway foure ganders. For theriÌ might ye be deceyued. And him wold ye not byleue at all that wolde tell you that twise two gese wold alway make foure horse. Â¶Tut quod he thys ys a mery mater. They must be all yt twyse twayne alway of one kynde. But gese and horse be of dyuerse. Â¶well quod I than euery man that ys neythere gose nor horsese â¢ th well yt there is one glose yet. But nowe quod I the geese and ye ganders be both of one kynde and yet twyse two gese make not alway foure ganders. Â¶A swete mater quod he / ye wote what I meane well ynough. Â¶I thynke I do quod I â¢ but I thinke if ye bryng yt furth yt wyll make a nothere glose to your texte as playne as youre texte ys / and ye wyll in all holy scrypture haue no glose at all. And yet wyll ye haue colla â¢ yon made of one texte wt a nother / and shew how they may be agreed to gether as thogh all that were no glose. Â¶ye quod he but wold you yt we shulde byleue the chyrch yf yt se â¢ t a glose that wyll in no wyse agree wyth ye text / but that it aperyth playnly that the texte well consydered sayeth clene the contrary? Â¶To whoÌ dothe yt apere quod I so playnly / whaÌ yt aperyth one to you / and to the hole chirch a nother? Â¶yet yf I se yt so quod he / though holy doctours & all the hole chyrch wolde tell me the contrarye / me thynkythe I were no more bounden to bileue them all yt the scrypture menith as they take yt / than if they wolde all tell me that a thynge were whyte whych I se my self ys blak. Â¶Of late quod I ye wolde byleue ye chirch in sum thynge. And now not onely ye wold byleue it in nothiÌg / but also where as god wold the church shulde be your iudge / ye wold now be iudge ouer the chirche. And ye wyll by your wyt be iudge whyther the chyrch in the vnderstaÌdynge of holy scripture yt god hath wryten to hys chyrche / do iuge a right or erre. As for your white & blak / neuer shall it be yt ye shall se the thiÌg blak yt all other shal se white. But ye may be sure yt yf all other se it white & ye take it for blak / your eyene be sore deceyuyd. For ye chirch wyll not I thiÌk agree to call it other than yt semyth to theÌ. And mych maruayle were yt y â¢ ye shuld iÌ holy scripture se beter thaÌ ye old
holy doctors and Crystys hole chyrch. Â¶But furste quod I ye must consyder that ye and I do not talke of one doctour or twayne / but of the consent and comen agrement of ye old holy fathers. Nor that we speke not of the doctryne of one man or two in the chyrch / but of of the comen consent of the chyrche. we speke nott also of any senteÌce taken in eny text of holy scrypture / wherby rysyth no dout or question of eny necessary artycle of oure fayth or rule of oure lyuynge / For in other bye maters may there be taken of one text .x. sensys paraduenture and all good ynough wythout waraÌtyse of the best / But we speke of suche two dyuers and contrary sensys taken / as yf the tone be trew the tother must nedys be false / and that as I say concerning some necessary poynte of oure faythe or rule of oure lyuynge / whych is also dependyng vppon fayth and reducyble therto. As yf one wolde boldely breke his vow for yt he thought that no man were bouÌdeÌ to kepe any. Sych poyntys I saye lett vs consyder they be that wee speke of. And thys remembryd betwene vs / than wyll we suÌ what se what your sayng doth proue. I shall not myche nede quod I to styk wyth you in dysputiÌg by what meanis the scrypture ys vnderstanden / syth ye be agreed wyth nature and dylygence the grace of god must nedys go / or els no dylygence or help of nature can preuayle. Nor I wyll nothyng deny you / but that god may and wyll also / gyue hys grace now to vs as he gaue of old to hys holy doctors / if there be as mich towardnes and no more let or impedymente in our selfe than was in them. I wyll also grauÌt yow that we may now by ye same menis by whych they might than / vnderstand the scripture as well as they dyd than / and I wyll not mic â¢ styk wyth you for one a â¢ e better. And were it not for the synnys that we sink in / we myghte parcase vnderstande yt beter by quater tredeuce / hauiÌg theyr labours therin & oure owne therwyth. But syth I am so gentyll to grauÌt you so many thyngê­ / I trust ye wyll grauÌt me thys one / that yf any such poynt of our fayth as god wolde haue meÌ bounden to beleue / they dyd vnderstande ye scripture one way and we a nother / beyng the tone to the tother so clene contrary yt yf the tone were trewe ye tother must nedê­ be false / ye will thaÌ graunt â¢ I say yt either they erre or we. Â¶That muste nedys be quod he. Â¶ye wyll also graunt quod I that in such poyntis as we speke of / the erroure were dampnable. For we speke of those poyntys onely / to the beleefe wherof god wyll haue vs bounden. Â¶I graunt quod he. For dampnable were yt in suche case to beleue wrong. And wrong shuld they or we beleue if they or we beleued a wroÌg artycle / because they or we thoughte yt the scrypture affyrmyd yt. And as daÌpnable were yt and yet mich more / if we beleuyd a thyng wherof we beleuyd yt the scrypture affyrmyth ye coÌtrary. For theÌ beleuyd we that the scrypture were false. Â¶Thys is q I very well sayde. â¢ But for the more playnnes let vs put one exaÌple or twayn. And what poynt rather than the ar â¢ ycle towchynge the equalite iÌ godhed of our sauiour cryste wt hys â¢ ather? For yf the coÌtrary belef â¢ were trew / than were this alway damnable & playne idolatry. Â¶Uery trothe quod he. Â¶May not quod I the tothe â¢ example be the matter that we haue in hand / coÌcerniÌg sayntê­ reliques / imagê­ & pylgrymagê­. whych thyngys yf yt be (as ye say many reken yt) ydolatrye /
thaÌ ys yt yet worse to do therin as we do / than yf our byleefe were wrong in the tothere poynte. And that as myche worse / as the sayntys or the ymagys eyther / be worse than ye holy manhode of Christe. Â¶That ys q he very trew. Â¶ThaÌ q I let the furst point alone because therein wee be all agreed / & speke of the second yf tholde fathers toke the scryptures one way & we the contrary. Though yt myghte be yt we were able to vnderstaÌd the scryptures as well as they / yet yf they so vnderstode theim yt thei thoght this kiÌd of worship not for beden but coÌmauÌdid & plesauÌt to god / & we new men oÌ the tother syde thoght yt vtterly forbeden & holden for ydolatry / the tone ête did not in dede vnderstand the scrypture ryght / but were in a dampnable erroure. Â¶That wyll no maÌ deny q he. Â¶I doute not now q I but yt your self seeth very well how many thiÌgys I might here lay for them to proue you yt they erryd nott so. Furste theyr wyttys as mych as our new meÌ nys / theyr â¢ ylygeÌce as grete / theyr erudycyon ãâã theyr study as faruent / theyr deuocion hoter / theyr noÌber farr greter / theyr tyme coÌtynued lenger by many agys parseueryng / the contrary oppynyoÌs in few & those alway sone fadyd / they taken alway for catholyke / ye coÌtrary ête for heretykys. Here myght I lay you the holynes of theyre lyfe & ye plentye of theyr grace well apperynge therby. And yt our lorde therfore openyd theyr eyen & suffred & causyd them to se ye trothe. And albeyt he vsed theriÌ none open myracle nor sensyble reuelacyoÌ / wherof as ye say they none allege or preteÌd for the profe of theyr opynioÌs in theyr interpretacyons of holy scrypture / yet vsyd he the secret suênaturall meane / by whych his grace assystent wt good meÌ yâ¢ labour therfore / by mocioÌs insensyble to them self / inclynyth theyr assent vnto the trewe syde / & that thus the old holy fathers dyd in the poynt yt we speke of & in such other / parceyue ye ryght seÌce of holy scrypture so farforth at the lest wyse / as they well knew yt yt was not coÌtrary to theyr beleefe. And here myghte I lay you also yt yf yt had bene otherwyse & yt they had therin daÌ nably bene deceyuid / than liuyng & dyeÌg in dampnable errour they coud not haue beene sayntys / as god god hathe shewyd theÌ to be by many a thousand miracle both iÌ theyr lyuys & after theyr dethys. wyth thys might I also lay & very well coÌclude / that syth those holy doctors and the chyrch / be (as by theyr bookys playnely apperethe) all of one fayth in thys poynt & such other / yt ther by well apperyth yt the chyrche is in the treuth / & ys not in the vnderstandyng of ye scrypture yt spekyth of ye mater eny thing deceyuyd / but they clerely deceyuyd yt do vnderstand those textê­ of holy scrypture to the contrary. These thiÌ
â¢ gys as I saye and yett many other mo myght I lay. But syth ye dyd your self put the chyrch & them both in one case / & so they be in dede / I wyll rather êue you the treuth of them by the treuth of the chyrch / than ye treuth of ye chyrch by the treuthe of theÌ. & so semyth me good reason. For surely syth they were but meÌbers of hys chyrch / god had hys specyall cure vppon them moste especyall for the profyte of his churche / by whose hole corps he more settyth than by eny member therof / saynt / apostle / euangelyst / or other. And therfore must I yet ask you agayn whether the chyrch may haue eny dampnable errour in ye fayth by mystakiÌg of scripture or otherwise. Â¶That ys q he sumwhat hard to tell. Â¶Now quod I sumwhat I meruayle that ye remember not yt your self hath
agred all redy / yt these wordê­ of Christ spoken vnto Peter I haue prayd that thy fayth shall neuer fayle / were not oÌ ly ment by the fayth iÌ Peter hys owne persoÌ / but also by the fayth of ye chyrch. For to hym was yt spoken as hed of ye chyrche? Â¶yes I remember q he ryght well yt I agreede yt. But I remember also yt notwtstanding mine agremente ye were content yt we shulde enserch agayn and agayne ye matere otherwyse bysyde / wherin myne agrement shuld not binde me. Â¶Lo quod I that had I forgotteÌ agayne But let it thaÌ alone for ye whyle and tell me this. Dyde not Chryste entende to gader a floke & congregacyon of peole yt shulde serue god and be hys specyall people? Â¶yes quod he that ys very trouthe / For so sayethe playne scrypture of Christe in sondry placys. As where the fathere of heuen sayeth vnto Chryste in ye psalme / Postula a me & dabo tibi gen â¢ es hereditatem tuam / aske of me and I shall giue the paynym people for thyne enherytaunce. & many other placys. And els vndowtedly hys hole coÌmiÌg had bene in maner frustrate & in vayne. Â¶That people quod I whych shulde be aÌ eÌherytaunce â¢ yd he entende shulde endure for hys owne dayes oÌly while he lyued her â¢ /or els that y â¢ shulde go forth & coÌ tynue long after. Â¶Nay quod he that shall coÌtynue whyle the worlde lasteth here tyll domys daye / & after in heuen eternally. Â¶Shall this peple q I haue amonge theym the knowlege & vnderstandynge what he wolde they shulde do to please god wythe all? Â¶ye q he. Â¶why â¢ her shall they quod I haue thys knowlege for a while iÌ the bygynnyng & than lese yt / or shall they haue it styll as longe as they contynue? Â¶Here he bygaÌ a litle to stagger. why quod I caÌ ye call th â¢ hys peple any lenger yf they lese ye knowlege how to serue hym and please hym? yf they for sloth to do theyr dutye as slake seruauntys suÌtyme do / yet may they mend & do beter a nother tyme. But yf they lese the knolege of theyre dutye / t â¢ aÌ wot they nere which way to mend / As he that knoweth fornicacyon for syn / may fall by frayletye to fornycacyon. But syth he knowethe yt for nought / thoughe he sinnid more in ye doyng than yf he had not knowen the prohybycyon / yet doth ye knowlege gyue hym warnynge and occacyon of repentaunce and amendment / whych must nedys lack yf he had lost ye knowlege. Â¶UppoÌ this he grauÌted yt it must nedys be that thys peple muste nedys haue alwaye the knolege how to serue and please our lorde / or els they ceaced to be hys peple. Â¶Is not this peple q I called ye chirch? Â¶yes quod he. Â¶ThaÌ the chyr â¢ h quod I alway hath & â¢ lway shall by your reasoÌ haue the knowlege & vnderstaÌdiÌg / how god may be seruid and plesed. Â¶Trouth q he Â¶Is quod I that knolege fully had wtout the knolege of such thingê­ as god biÌdeth vs to bileue? Nay q he. what if we knew theÌ iÌ such wise q I as we could rehe â¢ se theÌ oÌ our fiÌgers eÌdys & yet byleuyd theym not to be trewe / wolde thys knowlege serue? Â¶In no wyse q he. for yf ye byleued the to be false / thogh ye so knew theÌ yt ye could reherse theym by rowe / ye coud take no warniÌg by theÌ to plese & serue god with theÌ / which is the caus â¢ wherfore the chyrch shulde of necessyt â¢ know theÌ. This is q I v â¢ ry well sayd. thaÌ sith ye grauÌt yt ye chyrch shall euer eÌ dure / & yt it coud not â¢ dure wtout ye knolege of sich thiÌgê­ as may plese god / nor thos thiÌgê­ can be all known if knolege laked of those thiÌgê­ yt god byndeth vs to bileue / nor ye knolege of theÌ eny thiÌg sarue to the knolege & warniÌg geueÌ vs
of goddys pleasure but yf we not only can tell theym but also byleue theym / whyche bylyefe ye graunte ys callede fayth / of thys yt coÌsequently foloweth that the chyrche alwayes hathe and all ways shall haue the knowlege and bylyefe of such thyngys as god wyll haue yt boundeÌ to byleue. Â¶That is trouth q he because god hath lefte holy scrypture to ye chyrch / and therin ys all / and ye chyrch byleuyth that to be trew. and therfore therin & therby hath the chirch all that warnyng and lernyng of goddes pleasure that ye speke of / wythout whych yt caÌ not endure. Â¶what if god quod I had lefte ye scripture to ye chirch lokked vp in a close cheste / and that no man shuld loke therin / wold that haue seruyd? Â¶ Nay êde quod he. Â¶what if he had lefte hyt open & wrytten in such wyse that no maÌ coud rede yt? Â¶That were all one quod he. Â¶what yf euery man quod I could rede yt and no man vnderstaÌd yt? Â¶As lytle wold yt serue quod he as the tother. Â¶Than quod I syth yt seruyth the chyrch to lerne goddys pleasure theriÌ / and that can yt not as ye graunte your self but yf ye chyrch vnderstande yt / yt foloweth of thys yt the chyrch vnderstandeth it. And thus euery way for the fayth and knowlege of goddys pleasure yf yt be as ye saye all knowen by the scrypture & no parte otherwyse / yet alway to this poynt ye bryng yt in the ende / yt the chyrch hath the sure knowlege thereof. And than yf yt be so / ye shall not as ye lately sayd ye shulde / in eny dyuerse textê­ of scripture seming to make a dowtouse artycle of our fayth / and to brynge in questyone what we be bounden to byleue / after ye haue red iÌ scripture all that caÌ be red / and herd on both sydes all that can be sayd / than take whyche parte semeth to your self moste probable. Nor yf ye stand styll for all yt in a dowt / thaÌ after your bytter prayers made to god for hys grace & gyde iÌ ye choyse / go take you the tone parte at aduenture and cleue therto / as though ye were sure by your confidence in god / that his grace had inclined your asseÌt to ye surer syde. But sith he hath shewyd yow playnely by reasone that he hathe geuyn hys chyrch in all such thyngê­ knowlege of the trouthe / ye wyll take the sure way and put your self out of all perplexitie / yf in the poynte yt self & the scryptures that touch it / ye take for the truth that way that the chyrch tecythe you theriÌ / how so euer the mater seme bysyde vnto your selfe or to eny man els.

div.head: The .xxix. chapyter
div.p: Â¶The author proueth by scrypture that god instructethe the chyrche of Chryste / in euery trouthe necessaryly requesyte for our saluacyon.

TRuly q he ye wynde yt well aboute. But yet ye made as though ye wolde haue shewed that god had in scrypture told me / that he had & euer wold tell hys chyrch the trouthe in all suche maters. And now ye brynge yt to the poynte / not yâ¢ holy scrypture tellythe me the tale but maÌnys reasoÌ. And suerly as I shewed you byfore / I dare not well truste reasone in maters of fayth & of holy scrypture. Â¶I bygane quod I to proue yt you by scrypture / and ye than put me out in the bygynnyng. How be yt thys reason hath scrypture for hys foundacyon and grounde. And thogh yt sum what bilde farther theron / yet is it not reason alway to be mystrusted where fayth standyth not agaynst it / nor god sayeth not the contrary. Excepte reasoÌ be so farr out of credeÌce with you that
ye wyll not nowe byleue hym yf he tell you that twyse twayne make foure. I wene ye wyll fare by reson as one dyd oÌs by a â¢ alse shrew. he sware yt he wold not for .xx.li. heere hym say hys crede. For he knew him for such a lyer that he thoght he shuld neuer bileue hys crede after / yf he hard yt onys of his mouth. How be yt quod I lett vs yet see whyther god hym self in scrypture tell you the same tale or no. God tellyth you in scrypture yt he wold be wyth his chirch to the ende of the worlde. I thynke ye dowte not therof / but those wordys he spake to the hole chyrch that than was and that euer shalbe from thappostels dayes coÌtinued tyll ye ende of ye world. Â¶That iÌ good fayth quod he must nedys be so. ThaÌ were thys iÌ good fayth ynough quod I for oure purpose / syth no maÌ dowte â¢ h wherfore he wyll be wt his chyrch / excepte we shulde thynke yt he wolde be therwythe for nothynge. wherefore shulde he be wyth yt but to kepe yt & preserue yt wyth thassystence of hys gracyous preseÌte from spyrytuall myschiefe specially / and of all other specyally from infidelytie and from idolatrye? whych was the specyall thiÌg from whych he called hys chirch owt of the gentyllys. whych els as for morall ver â¢ ews & polytycall yf they had nott lackyd the ryght cause and ende of referrynge theyre actys to god / were many of them not far vnder many of vs. Let vs go ferther. Doth he not iÌ ye .xiiii xv. and .xvi. chapyter of saynte IohnÌ agayn and agayne repete / that after his goyng he wyll cum agayne to theym / And sayth he wyll not leue them orphanys as fatherles chyldern / but wyll cuÌ to them agayn hym selfe? Let vs adde now therunto the wordys bifore rehersed / that he wylbe wyth theym tyll th â¢ worldes ende / and yt aperyth playne yt he mente all thys by hys hole chyrche yt shulde be to the worldes end. Â¶whaÌ he sayd vnto theÌ I call you frendê­ / for all that I haue harde of my father I haue made knowene to you / he spake as to hys perpetuall chyrch and not to thapposteles alone / but if he sayed to them alone these wordys also I coÌmaunde that ye loue eche other / so yt none shuld loue eche othere after but onely they. Now leste the thyngys that he taught theym shulde by the chyrch after be forgoten / whych was more to be dowted than of theym self that hard it / he sayd vnto theym also / These thyngys quod he haue I spoken to you abidinge here wyth you. But the â¢ omforter whych is the holy goste whoÌ me father shall send iÌ my name / he shall tech you all thyng / and he shall put you in mynde and rememberaunce of all thyng that I shall haue sayd vnto you. So that here ye se that he shall agayn alway tech ye chirch of new / the olde lessons of Chryst. And he sayed also to theym / yt thys comforter thys holy gost yâ¢ spyryte of trouth / shulde be sente to abide wyth them for euer / whych can not be mente but of ye hole chyrche. For the holy gooste was not sente hyther into the erthe here to dwell wythe the appostels for euer / for they dwelled not so long here. Now yf the spryte of trouthe shall dwell in the chyrche for euer / how caÌ ye chyrche erre in perceyuynge of the trouthe / in such thyngys I mene as god wyll bynd theÌ to know or shalbe necessary for theym to know? For onely of such thiÌgê­ meÌt oure lord / whan he sayed that the holy goste shall teche theym all thynge. For as saynte Poule sayeth / the manife â¢â¢ acyon and shewynge of ye spyryte / ys to the vtilitie & profyt. This holy spyrite
also was not promysed by our sauiour chryst / yt he shulde onely tell hys chyrch agayne hys wordes / but he sayd ferther / I haue quod he besydes all thys many thynges to say to you / but ye be not able to bere theym now. But whaÌ he shall cum yt is the spyryte of trouth / he shall lede you in to all trouthe. Lo our lord sayed not that the holy goost shuld write vnto his chyrch all trouth / but that he shuld lede theym by secrete insperacyon and inclynacyon of theyr hartes in to all trouth / in whyche must nedes be conceyued bothe informacyoÌ and ryghte byleue of euery necessary artycle / and of the ryght and trew seÌse of holy scrypture / as farre as shall be requysyte to conserue the chyrche from eny dampnable errour. Â¶Now whan the holy goost shall by goddes êmyse / be for thys purpose abydynge in the chyrch for euer / and Chryste hym selfe hath also sayd that he wyl not leue hys chyrch as orphanys / but wyll cum hym selfe / & be wyth yt vnto the ende of the world / and sayeth also that hys father ys in hym and he in hys father / and yt hys father and he be bothe one thynge / not bothe one persone but bothe one substaunce / and wyth the holy gooste bothe one god / than must yt nedes folow that to the worldys ende / there ys wyth the chyrch resydent the hole trynytye. whose assystence beynge to the chyrche perpetuall / how can yt at any tyme fall from trew fayth to false errous and heresyes?

div.head: The .xxx. chapyter
div.p: Â¶where as ye messeÌger had thought byfore / that yt were herde to bylyue any thyng certeynly saue holy scrypture though the chyrche dyd agre therin and commaunde yt / the Authore sheweth that sauing for thauthoryte of the chyrch / men coud not knowe what scrypture they sholde byleue. And here ys hyt shewed yt god wyll not suffre the chyrch to be deceyued in ye choyce of ye very scrypture of god from eny counterfete.

NOw ys yt I suppose well & clerely proued by scrypture the thyng that I promysed / that ys to wytt that the chyrche caÌ not erre in any suche substauncyall artycle as god wyl haue vs bouÌden to byleue. Â¶But yet for as myche as ye regarde nothynge but scrypture onely / thys wolde I fayne wytte of you whyther ye byleue that chryste was borne of a vyrgyn. Â¶what els quod he. Â¶why byleue you yt quod I? Â¶The gospell sheweth me so quod he. Â¶what yf yt dyd not quod I / were thaÌ your crede oute of credence but yf he brynge wytnesse wyth hym? Â¶The crede quod he ys a thynge by yt selfe. Â¶yet ys yt quod I no parte of ye gospell as ye pater noster ys. And yet I thynke yf gospell had neuer bene wryten / ye wolde haue byleued your crede. Â¶So thynke I to q he. Â¶And wherfore q I / but for bycause ye chyrch shuld haue shewed you so? But let our crede alone a whyle and go we to the gospel selfe. whych gospel telleth you yt cryste was borne of a vyrgyn? Â¶The gospel of seynt luke quod he. Â¶How knowe you yt q I? Â¶For I rede yt so quod he in the booke. Â¶ye rede q I suche a boke. But how know yow that saynt Luke made yt? Â¶How knowe I quod he other bokê­ / but by yt they bere the namys of theyre authors wryteÌ vppoÌ them? Â¶Know you yt wel therby quod I? Many bookes be there that haue false inscrypcyons / and are not the bookes of theym yt they be named by. Â¶That ys trouth q he. But
yet though men dyd peradueÌture erre and fayle iÌ the name / as if he shulde repute a boke of Stories to be made by Titus Liuius whych he neuere made but suÌ other honest cuÌniÌg maÌ / yet were the boke nether lesse elygaunt nor lesse trewe therfore. Nor in lyke wyse if the chyrche dyd mysse take the very name of sum euauÌgelyste & gospell / yet were the gospell neuer ye lesse trew. Â¶That ys quod I well sayde. But how be ye sure that the mater of ye boke ys trew? Â¶Mary quod he for I am. Â¶That ys quod I the reasoÌ yt a mayde layeth for her owne knowlege of her maydeÌhed. But she coulde tell a nothere how she knoweth she hath yt / sauynge that she ys lothe to cuÌ so nere as to be a knowen that she coulde tell how she myghte lese yt. But here ys no such fere. Tell me therfore whereby wot ye that ye mater of that booke ys trew? Â¶I thynke quod he yt god sheweth me so. Â¶That ys well thought quod I. But he tolde yt you not mouthe to mouth. Â¶No q he. But he hath tolde yt to other in the bygynnynge or els yt was well knowen in the bygynnynge whan he wrote yt. And he was knowen and byleuyde by hys liuynge / and the myracles that god dyd for hiÌ. And after that yt was onis knoweÌ / the knowlege went forth fro maÌ to maÌ. And god hath so wroght wyth vs that we byleue yt bycause the hole chyrch hath alway done so byfore our dayes. Â¶Now cum you quod I to the very poynte. for many thyngys hath bene trew yâ¢ in procys after hathe lefte to be byleuyd. And many a thing hath in the bygynnynge bene knowen for false / and yet hath after happed to be byleuyd. But the gospels and holy scrypture / god prouydeth that though percase sum of it may perishe & be loste whereby they myghte haue harme but not fall in errour (for the fayth shulde stande though the scrypturys were all gon) yet shall he neuer suffer his chirch to be deceyued in that poynt / that they shall take for holy scripture eny boke yt ys not. And therfore sayeth holy saynt AusteÌ / I shuld not byleue the gospell / but yf yt were for the chyrche. And he sayeth good reasone. For were yt not for the spyryte of god keping ye trouth therof in hys chyrch / who could be sure whych were the very gospels? There were many that wrot the gospell. And yet hathe the chyrch by secrete instinct of god / reiectyde the remenaunte and chosen oute these foure for the sure vndowted trew. Â¶That ys quod he sure so. Â¶Thys ys quod I so sure so / yt Luther hym selfe ys dryuyn of necessytye to graunte thys / or els he perceyuyth yt there were none holde nor surtie iÌ scripture yt selfe / yf the chyrch myght be suffrede by god to be deceyued in yt poynt & to take for holy scrypture yt wryting that in dede were not. And therfore he confessyth that thys muste nedys be a sure infallyble grounde / that god hath geuyn thys gifte vnto hys chyrch / that hys chyrche caÌ alway dyscerne ye word of god froÌ the worde of meÌ. Â¶In good faythe quod he that muste nedys be so / or els all wolde fayle. Â¶Quod I than ye that wolde byleue the chyrche in nothinge / nor giue sure credence to ye tr â¢
dycyon of the chyrch but yf yt were p â¢ ued by scrypture / now se yt prouyd to you / that ye coulde not byleue ye scrypture but yf yt were proued to be scrypture by the iudgemente and tradycyoÌ of the chyrch. Â¶No quod he but when I haue lerned onys of the chyrch / that yt ys holy scrypture and the worde of god / than I bileue it better than I byleue
al the chyrche. I myght by a lyght persone sumtyme know a mych more substancyall maÌ. And yet whaÌ I know hym I wyll byleue hym mych beter thaÌ hym by whome I know hym if they varied iÌ a tale and were coÌ
â¢ rary. Â¶Good reason quod I. But the chyrch b â¢ ddith you not byleue the coÌtrary of that the scrypture sayeth. But he tellythe you yt in such placys as ye wold better bileue the scrypture than the chyrche / there ye vnderstand not ye scrypture. For what so euer wordys yt spekyth / yet yt meanyth not the contrary of that ye chirch techeth you. And the chirch can not be deceyued in any such weghtye poynt. Â¶whereby shall I knowe q he? Â¶why be we at ye poynt yet quod I? haue we so sone forgotten the perpetuall assystence of the trynyte in hys chyrch / and the prayoure of Chryste to kepe ye fayth of hys chyrche fro fayliÌge / and the holy gost sen â¢ e of purpose to kepe iÌ ye chirch the rememberaunce of Chrystê­ wordê­ and to lede them in to all trouth? what wold yt haue profited to haue put you iÌ
â¢ he rememberaunce of the assystense of god wt the chylderne of Israell walkyng wyth theÌ in the cloude by day / & iÌ the pyler of fyer by nyght in theyr erthly viage / and therby to haue prouyde you the mych more specyall assystence of god wyth hys christeÌ chyrch in theyr spyrytuall vyage / wherein hys especyall goodnes well declarith his tender delygence / by that he dothe vouchsafe to assyste and comforte vs wyth the coÌ tynuall presence of hys preciouse body in the holy sacremente? All this wolde not helpe / yf manyfeste reasone that I made you / and euydent scripture that I rehersyd you / can not yet prynte in your harte a perceyuyng that thassystence of god in hys chirche must nedis preserue hys chyrche froÌ all damnadle errours in ye fayth / and giue his chyrch so ferforth the vnderstandynge of scripture / that they may well perceyue yâ¢ no parte therof well vnderstande / staÌdith agaynste eny artycle that the chyrche bileuith / as êcell of theyr christeÌ fayth. Â¶Naye q he I perceyue yt well whan I remember it / but it was not redy in remeÌbraunce.

div.head: The .xxxi. chapyter
div.p: Â¶In that the chirche can not erre in the choyse of the trew scripture / the author prouythe by the reasoÌ whych the kyngys hyghnes in hys noble & most famous boke obiectith agaiÌst luther / that the chyrche can not erre in the necessa â¢ y vnderstandynge of scrypture. And fynally thauthor in this chapyter doth breuely recapi â¢â¢ e certayn of the pryncypall poyntys yt be byfore proued. And therwyth endeth the fyrste booke.

yEt wold I quod I aske you one thynge wherfore thinke you wyll no â¢ Chryste suffer hys chyrche to be deceyuyde in ye descerninge of holy scrypture frome othere wrytynge / and suffer theym to take a boke of hol â¢ scrypture / that were none in dede? Â¶Leste meÌ might quod he of sum false boke reputed holy scripture / haue grete occacyon geuyn them to coÌ ceyue a wronge dyctryne and wronge opinions of ye fayth / yf god wold suffer hys chirch to take a false deuysed boke for holy scrypture & for hys owne holy wordys. Â¶ye say quod I very trouthe. Now what yf in the very scrypture he shuld suffer hys chyrche mysse take the very sentence in a matter substanciall of our fayth / were they not in lyke êell to fall by false vnderstandyng iÌ to like errors / as they might by false wrytiÌg?
Â¶ Yes th â¢ t they were qu â¢â¢ he. Â¶Forsoth q â¢ od I so ãâã th â¢ y and in myche more. For in â¢ false â¢â¢â¢ ke mystaken for scrypture th â¢â¢ gh they â¢â¢ d yt in neuer so hygh re â¢ ereine for som â¢ good thynges that they foun â¢â¢ in yt / and therby sholde haue gr â¢â¢ t ãâã to byleue the falfe errours wrytten in the same / yet â¢â¢â¢ yng â¢ s â¢ he chyrch alwaye shall haue / the trewe faythe / fyrst in harte they sholde fynde many shyftys to kepe oute the errours. But now yf they falsely shold vnderstand the trewe scrypture / there were no waye to scape frome dampnable errours. And therfore may I say to you as the kyngys hyghnes most prudeÌtly layd vnto Luther / syth god wyll not suffre hys â¢ hyrche to mystake a booke of scrypture for parell of dampnable errours that myght ensue theron / and lyke parel may there ensue by the my â¢
construynge of the sentence as by the mystakynge of the boke / yt must nedê­ folowe that god wyll in thyngys of our fayth no more suffre theym to take a false sentence for trew / than to take a false booke for scrypture. And wyth this reason hys hyghnes coÌcluded hym so clerely / that he durst neuer synnys for shame touche that poynt agayne / nor eny colour coulde lay / but that vpoÌ hys owne confessyon in all substauncyall poyntys concernynge the faythe or knowlege of vertue pleasaunt to god / the chyrche hath so ryght vnderstandynge of scrypture / that yt well & trewly perceyueth / that no text therin can be ryght vnderstanden / agaynst eny artycle that yâ¢ chyrche byleueth for thyng to be byleued of necessytye. And this poynt durst he neuer synnys touch ãâ¦ã Â¶S â¢ rely quod your â¢ rend I ãâ¦ã not though he dyde not. For this poynt is ãâã
â¢ e cowld not / and I am here in fu â¢ ly satysfyed. Â¶Now is yt not onely true that myracles be wrought onely in the chyrche / & therby do shewe whyche is the very chyrche / but also they do shewe that those holy doctors for whoÌ god hath shewed theÌ / were good meÌ and of the right bylyef. For yf yt were as ye wold of late haue had yt seme / that yt myght peraduen â¢ be so yt ye holy doctors of our fayth whoÌ we take for sayntys / were in dede no sayntys nor sauyd soules / but happely those were saued soules & sayntê­ in heuyn though yt were vnknoweÌ here in erthe â¢ whyche dyde teche the doctryne here that we now call heresyes / then were yt a woÌderous chaung that wher as god amonge the Iewes prouyded yt in euery age there were som god men by theyr good lyuiÌg & his hygh myracles so notable & wel knoweÌ to ye peple â¢
that men had theÌ alwaye lyke bryght ly â¢â¢ ly starres / whose doctryne they might boldely byleue / & whose lyuyng they might surely folow / he wold now in his specyall chyrch of Cryst / not onely do nothyng lyke / but also do clene ye contrary. For yf he shold take ye waye that ye saye / to leue euer synnys thappostles dayes / all the trewe interpretours of hys and theyr holy wrytyng and doctours of the very trew â¢ aythe lye to the world vnknoweÌ / & theÌ on ye tother syde set forth wyth myracles or suffer so to be set forth wt meruayles / yt his chirch shold take & accept for saitê­ such euyl êsons or ypocrytê­ as coÌstrued ye scrypture wronge / & euer synne hys apostles days haue taught fals errors / & led his flock out of ye ryght waye in a dye pathe to hell warde wt wycked heresyes & ydolatrye / then hath not god sent the holy goost / and hym self also taryed styll therin / to teche hys chyrch yâ¢ trouth as he said he wold. But he had theÌ holpeÌ to begyle theÌ hym self / which wer iÌpossible for god to do / & more thaÌ blasph â¢ my for ony maÌ to thynke. For thys were not lyke ye sufferaunce of an vnsecrat host / wherof ye put ye sample / wherin the peoples inuyncyble ignorauÌce wyth theyr deuout affeccyoÌ may wtout harme to theyr soules be sufferyd in the thynge that seldom happeth and eÌdureth for so short a whyle: But yf god wolde leue all good doctours vnknoweÌ / and suffer hys chyrch to be deceyued with myracles and meruaylê­ done by theym that taught heresyes & setforthe ydolatrye / then sholde hym selfe as I saye not onely suffer hys honour and ryght fayth and relygyon to be perpetually l â¢ st / but helpe also hym self to destroy yt. Whych who so could thynke possyble / were worse then Iudas / and more madde then eny man in bedlem. And therfore can yt not in no wyse be / that the chyrch can be deceyued in that they take for sayntys these holy doctours of ye chyrch. Nor they so beyng / can yt in ony wyse be that the doctryne wherin they coÌsent and agre can be false or vntrue? Amonge which doctryne syth the thyngys wherof we speke / I mene the prayng to sayntys / the worshyp of ymagys / reuerencynge of relyques / and goyng in pylgrymagys is a parte as by theyr bokys playnly doth appere / we may well and surely coÌclude / that none of these thyngys be dampnab â¢ e or dyspleasaunt to god / but thyngys hyghly to hys contentacyon and pleasure. And syth we further perceyue that theyr bokys be wryten in dyuers regyons and sondry â¢
gys / we thereby well perceyue that these thyngys be parcell of the rytes vsagys and byleue of Crystys chyrch / not onely now and of late / but contynually from the begynnyng hetherto. And syth yt is playnly prouyd you that the churche can in no wyse be suffred of god to fall into any dampnable errour therby / yt is yet most surely coÌcludyd / that these thyngys be none suche. And consequentely prouyd / that no texte of scrypture semynge to sowne to the contrary / canne be so taken or vnderstanden. Nor that the chyrch caÌnot in preiudyce of the faythe mysse vnderstand the scrypture. And that the substaÌcyall poyntys of the faythe therefore lernyd of the chyrch / is one of the surest rules that can be founden for the ryghte interpretacyon of holye scrypture. And that no secte of heretyques can bee the church of Cryste / but that once churche
ys yâ¢ very chyrch. And yt is also clerely proued yt the mater of myracles therin dayly done / is neyther feyned by men nor done by the deuyll / but onely by yâ¢ myghty hand of god. And suche obieccyons as ye layde vnto the contrary of eny poynt aforsayde / be as farre as I can se suffycyently answerd / excepte yt ye haue eny forther obieccyon to laye therin. Whyche yf ye haue ye gette no thanke to spare. Â¶Wherunto he sayd & sware therwyth that he so fully felte hym self answerd and coÌteÌted therin / that he thought hym selfe able therwt to content and satysfye eny man / that he shold happen to mete wyth / yt wold holde the contrary. Whervppon for yt day we departed tyl a nother tyme / in whyche we appoynted to pervse the remanaunt of the thyngys that he had in the begyn â¢ yng purposed.

div.p: The author proueth that ye spyrytu â¢ ll iudges dyd ye man meruylouse fau â¢ ur / & alm â¢ st more than laufull / in that they admytted hym to such â¢ an abiuracyoÌ as they dyd / and that they dyd not rather leue hym to the secular handys.

And ellys yf he proue hym selfe obstynate and impenytent / the chyrch neyther is bounden nor oughte to receyue hym / but vtterly may forsake hym and leue hym to the secular â¢ handys. And dyuerse dayes were hys iudgê­ fayne of theyr fauour to geue hym / wyth sufferaunce som his beste frendys & whom he most trusted / to resorte vnto hym. And yet scantely could all thys make hym submytte hiÌ selfe to make hys abiuracyon. Â¶what man was that quod he? Â¶Mary qu â¢ d I hys abiuracyon was suche that he theriÌ abiured & forsware all her â¢ sy â¢ s / knowlegyng hym selfe lawfully conuycte. But where as they be wont to coÌfesse in theyr owne abiuracyon that they haue holden such heresyes and be gyltye therof / that wolde he do in no wyse / but as clerely as hys f â¢ wte was proued / and by as many / yet wolde he not to dye therfore confesse hym selfe fawtye / but alway stode styll vppoÌ yt in vertue of hys othe that all they belyed hym. Â¶It myght happen quod he that he had forgoten yt he so had pched. Â¶That were quod I grete wounder. For I am sure whan he had â¢ er â¢ ed so in so many placys / he had not done yt of a sodayne aduenture / but of a delyberat purpose / whych excepte he fell madde / yt were no well pos â¢ yble f â¢ r hym in so grete a mater to forgete. And by an honest ley maÌ had yt layed vnto hys charge / yt he had parelousely preched / shewyng hym wherin. Wher vnto he made answere not that he had not sayed so / nor that he had not ment so / or that they had mysse taken and wrong vnderstanden hys wordis / but that he wold preche there agayne son â¢ after / and proue hys prechynge trewe by the olde doctours of the chyrch. Â¶It was quod he possyble ynough that all to gether was false / & that they lyed all. For so myght they do by possybylyte beyng but men / and though they had ben mo theÌ they were. Â¶Ueryly q I to ãâã yt wold not seme very gay. But nowe yf Symkyn were contencyous & wold say the wager were hys except yt be so proued that yt can be none other wyse but that horse haue of late gone there & then wyll say to vs lo syrs as ye se it yt may be other wyse.
