was than all the labour and the payne that thappostles toke in prechynge all naught & synfull? all the tormentys yt the martyrs suffered in theyr passyon all together synne? all ye dedys of ch â¢
ryte that Cryst shall as hym self sayth reward wyth euerlastynge lyfe â¢ t the g â¢ nerall i â¢ dgement be they synÌ all to gether? Saynt Poule rekened it other wyse. For he sayd boldely of hym self / bonuÌ certamen certaui / cursuÌ consumm â¢â¢ i / et nuÌc superest michi corona iu
â¢â¢ itie / I haue laboured & stryuen a good stryfe / I haue perfourmed my course / now lac â¢ eth me no more for me but yâ¢ crowne of iustyce.

Â¶ Therunto he answered that saynt Powle wolde not saye that o â¢â¢ dedys were suff â¢ cyent of theym self / but that all oure suffycyency â¢ ys of god. Whervnto yt was answered that thys was lytell to the mater. For no more ys our fayth suffycyent of yt selfe / but the suffycyency therof ys also of god / in â¢ hat our lord wyth our endeuo â¢ r gyueth vs grace to byleue / and in that yt ly â¢ eth our lorde of hys goodnes so hyghly to reward yt. For surely as it is very true that saynt Poule sayth th â¢â¢ /Non suÌt condigne passiones h â¢ i â¢â¢ vite ad futuram gloriam que reuelabitur in no
â¢ is / all that euer we can suffer in thys worlde / ys not worthy the glory to come that shall be shewed in vs (For what thyng cowld a sely wr â¢ ched creature do or suffer for god in the brefe tyme of thys short lyfe / yt might of ryght requyre to be rewarded euerlastyngly / wyth suche in â¢â¢â¢ ym â¢ ble ioy as neyther â¢ ye hathe seen nor tonge can expresse / nor hart can ymagyne or conceyue) so y â¢ yt also as true th â¢ t all the fayth we â¢â¢ ue or caÌ haue can of hys own n â¢ ture as lytel or myche lesse deserue heueÌ / as our other good dedê­. For what gret â¢ thiÌg do we to god / or what grete thing coulde we aske hym of ryght / bycause we byleue hiÌ? as though he were mych beholdeÌ vnto vs / in yt we vouchesaufe to truste hym / as though hys worshyp hunge in our handys / and hys estymacyon lost yf he were out of credence wt vs. And therfore amonge many folysh wordys of Luther / as folyshe as euer heretyque spoke / he neuer sp â¢â¢ e a more frantyque / thaÌ in that he saythe yt god hath nede of our faythe. For he saythe that god hath no nede of our good workys / but he hath nede of our faythe / and hathe nede that we sholde byleue hym. Trouthe ys yt that he nedeth â¢ neyther our fayth nor oure workys. But syth that he hath determyned tha â¢ he wyll not saue vs wythoute both yf we be of dyscrecyon to haue both / therfore haue we nede of bothe. And yet neyther is there the tone nor the tot â¢ er nor they both together bytwene them / that be of theyre owne nature worthy the rewarde of heuen. But as we se â¢ yâ¢ one ounce of gold wherof .x. pownde weyghte were not of hys owne nature toward maÌ worth one ouÌce of whete / nor one hundred pownde weyght therof of the nature selfe worthe one sely shepe / ys yet among men by a pryce appoynted and agreed worth many hole shepe / and many a pownde weyght of brede / so hath yt lyked yâ¢ lyberall goodnes of god to set as well our fayth as oure dedys / whyche were ellys both â¢ twayn of theyr owne nature ryght lytell iÌ value at so hygh a pryce / as non â¢ ys able to bye theym and paye for theÌ but hym self / bycawse we shold work â¢ th â¢
Ì only to hym / and haue none other
pay mayster nor notte other chapmaÌ to sell our ware and our worke vnto / but only hym. Except we wolde be so mad & towardys hym so vnkynd yt we wold sell yt to a nother for lesse / nather than to hym for more. As some do / that had leuer trauayle far of and sell for lesse / than they wold for more sell to theyre neyghbours at home. And as do these folysh ypocrytê­ / which rather thaÌ they wold sell theyr worke to god for euerlastynge ioy of heuen / sell yt all to the world for the peuysh plesure of ye vayn prayse puffed out of pore mortall mennys mouthes wyth a blast of wynde. Â¶Unto thys he sayd that very true yt was yt all our workys toke theyre value & pryce after thacceptacyoÌ of god / & as he lyst to allowe them. But he sayd that god reiected / dysalowed / and set at nought all the workys of infydelys wrought wythout fayth. For sine fide impossibile est placere deo / wÌtout fayth yt is iÌpossyble to please god. S â¢ o â¢ his faythfull chosen peple that byleue and trust in hym / he accepteth & alloweth all the dedys. And that is sayd he / wel proued by the wordys of saynt IohnÌ / Nichil daÌnationis est hiis qui sunt in Christo iesu. And albe yt that in the rehersyng of the coÌmunycacyoÌ had wyth thys man / yt may well be yt my remeÌ braunce maye partely mysse the order / partely peraduenture adde or my â¢ ysh in some parte of the mater / yet in thys poynt I assure you faythfully / there ys no maner chauÌg or varyauÌce from his opynyon / but that after many shyftys he brought yt playnly to thys poynt at last / that he and his felows that were of Luthers secte / were fermely of this opynyon / that they byleued that god worketh all in euery maÌ good workys and badde. Howe be yt no suche as he foreknoweth to be daÌpned / no maner workys be profyfable to them. For god taketh theym for nought be they neuer so good. But on the tother syde in those he hath choseÌ fro ye begynniÌg & predestynate to glory / all workê­ be good ynog â¢ For god accepteth and taketh theÌ well a worth be they neuer so bad.

Â¶It was asked hym than whyther yt the forsakynge of Cryst by Peter was alowed and well approued by Cryste. And whyther yt aduour â¢ y & maÌslaugh â¢ ter was by god wel alowed in Dauyd. Â¶Wherunto he sayd that bycause they were choseÌ and predestynate / therfore those synnys were not / nor the synnys of any suche men be not imputed vnto theym. But god bycause he hath frome the begynnynge chosen theym to euerlastyng blysse / therfore he â¢ rre â¢ teth no blame of theyr dedys vnto theym / but all the workys of a iuste man that ys to saye quod he of a person by god predestynate to glory / turne hym to good / how euyll so euer they be. And thys for coÌclusyon he declared to be theyr very playn mynde and opynyon / for all the clockys that he set vppon the mater byfore / to make yt seme that they mened in theyr wordê­ none harme. And there yt clerely appered / that he and hys f â¢â¢ whych in theyr prechyng do couertly & craftely secte oute the dampnable secte of Luther / hoope and ga â¢ e alway for some other tyme / in whych they truste opeÌly & boldely to play the rauenoê° w â¢ luys & deuoure the shepe & marre ye hole flok. And iÌ yt mene s â¢ as â¢
Ì be coÌteÌt to play ye wyly foxê­ & wyrry siÌple soulê­ & pore laÌ bes / as thei may catch theÌ strageliÌg froÌ ye fold / or rather lyke a false shepeherdê­ do â¢ yt wold but backe iÌ syght / & s â¢ me
to fetche in ye shepe / & yet kyll a lambe in a corner. Men speke of som that bere two facys in one hode. I neuer saw eny yt more veryly play yt pagauÌte / than do thys kynde of suche prech â¢ ours. For in prechyng to the peple they make a vysage as though they came strayght froÌ heuen to teche them a new better way & more trew than the chyrche techeth / or hath taught this many huÌdred yere. And then to ye chyrch in examynacyon they shew theÌ selfe as pore meÌ of mydle erth / & as though they taught none other wyse thaÌ ye chyrch doth. But in coÌ clusyoÌ wheÌ they be well examyned / & wt mych worke that falsehode of theyr cloked collusyoÌ ys pulled of / theÌ appereth there all ye malycyous trechery / & what poyson they put forthe vnder the cloke of hony. As thys maÌ yt I tell you of laborynge all yt he myghte by many meanes to make yt seme / that in prechiÌg / yt faith alon was sufficieÌt for our saluacyoÌ / & yt good workê­ were nothiÌg worth / had nothiÌg entended but well & accordyng to ye doctryne of ye chyrch / & yt he & hys felowes neuer ment otherwyse thaÌ ye chyrch meneth / yet in coÌclusyoÌ he playnly shewed hym selfe / yt he & hys felows entend therby to brynge ye peple to thys poynt at last / yt all thyng handgeth onely vppon desteny / & that the lybertye of maÌnys wyll shold serue of ryght nought / nor meÌnys dedê­ good or bad made no dyfference afore god / but that in hys chosen people nothyng myslyketh hym be yt neuer so bad / and in the tother sort nothyng pleseth hym be yt neuer so good / the very worst and moste my scheuouse heresye yt euer was thoughte vppon / and therto the moost madde. For as yt ys sayde vnto hym / yf this were trew / wherto preche they at all? and counsayle eny man o â¢â¢ thynge or other? What fruyte cowlde come of theyre exhortacyon yf all shold hange vppon destenye? There were shewed vnto hym many thyngys for the reprofe of that vnreasonable and detestable heresye / and that the textys whyche he alledged / nothynge made for hys purpose. For as for that he alledged of saynt Powle / that there ys no dampnacyon to theym that be in Cryste Iesu / was ment of good faythfull folke that lyue vertuousely / and therefore where he sayth that there ys no dampnacyon to theym that be in Cryste Iesu / yt foloweth forthwyth in the texte / those that walke not after the â¢â¢ esshe. Menyng playnly yt there is no maÌ so plaÌted in Cryst Iesu / but & yf he folow ye fleshly ways of hys sensuall appetytys / he shalbe daÌpned for all his fayth in Cryst. For ellis it shold folow vpoÌ this false opinioÌ / if god accept wel all the workys of them that are predestynate / than is synne no synne. But in ye tother sort whoÌ god hath not predestynate. And than ys yt as myche to say as no maÌ may lawfully be nought no man lawfully do thefte or aduoutery / nor lawfully be a manquellour / nor lawfully forswere hym selfe but goddys good sonnys and hys specyall chosen chyldren.

Â¶Now where he alledged the wordys of saynt Powle / q iuste omnia cooperantur in bonuÌ / To a iuste man all thyngys worke together to hys wele / yt was sayde that yt ment that all the euylles that men dyd vnto theym / turne them to good & be to good meÌ occasion of theyr meryte / as was to Iob all ye tormeÌtys by whych ye deuyll assauted hys pacyence / and all the paynys that
P â¢ gan tyrau â¢ tys dyd vnto the holy martyrs. And somtyme ye syn in whych a good man ys by goddys sufferaunce êmytted to fall / ys an occasyon to hym of a gretter good / or of thauoydyng of a gretter syn. As theschewynge of an hyghe spyrytuall pryde / in to whyche peraduenture the contynuall c â¢ urse of hys vertuous lyfe might by the deuyls subtyll suggestyon haue brought hym / whereas one foule act of lechery hath shewed hym his f â¢ ayletye / and in stede of pryde broughte hym in to penaunce and humylyte / and make hym runne the faster forward in vertue / bycawse he hath letted and syt styll a whyle in syn / and therfore wyll he runne forthe to wynne agayne in hys waye that he byfore caste hym selfe behynde. But yt was not ment that euer theyr synnys so turned theÌ to good / that they were accepted the more and rewarded the better for theyr euyll dedys. Nor god remytteth not the synnys of his chosen people / nor forbereth not to impute the blame therof vnto them / bycawse they be hys chosen people. For he accepteth not folk for theyr persons but for theyr merytys / but where as they haue synned / he punyssheth as wel theym as other / and somtyme more bycause theyr formare good lyuyng somwhat of congruence deserued that they shold by punysshment be called agayne to grace / and not be for theyr fawte so sone cast clene away / as some other obdurate in maly â¢ e and euyll cu â¢â¢ ume of synne / deserue to haue ye grace of god & hys callyng â¢ n neuer more offred vnto them / and vnto som yt ys o â¢â¢ red that wyl not receyue yt. God called on â¢ a â¢ yd by ye prophete Nathan / and yet punysshed hys of â¢â¢ re. Cryst loked on Peter after he had forsaken and forsworne hym / and Peter therwyth toke repeÌtaunce. God loked on Iudas & kyssed hym to / and he turned to none amendement. Now god froÌ the begynnyng before ye worlde was created / foreseyng in hys dyuyne pseyence or rather in yâ¢ therny
â¢ e of his godhed presently byholdyng / that Peter wold repent & Iudas wold dyspayre / and that the tone wold take hold of hys grace the tother wolde reiecte yt / accepted and chose the tone & not the tother / as he wolde haue made the contrary choyce / yf he had forsene in them the contrary chaunge.

div.head: Â¶The .xii. chapyter.
div.p: Â¶The author inueheth agaynst the most pestylent secte of these Lutheranys / whych ascrybe our saluacion and daÌnacyon and all our dedys to desteny.

BUt now for to say as that heretyque sayd after all hys shyftys at last that all that shall be saued shall be saued only bycause that god frome ye begynnynge hath chosen theym / & bycause of that choyce all theyr dedys be good / or yf they be euyll yet god for cause of hys eternall choyce taketh theÌ well in wurth and imputeth no blame vnto theym / and that all other people whom god hath created shall be dampned onely bycawse he wolde not chose them / and that all theyr dedys eyther be nought or not wel accepted / bycause god lyst not in the begynnyng to chose theym / and that he worketh both in ye tone sorte & in the tother all theyr dedes hym selfe alone / and they do nothyng therin theym selfe / and so that god whose goodnes is iÌestymable doth dampne so hounge a nomber of people to intollerable and intermynable tormeÌ tys
only for hys pleasure / and for hys owne dedys wrought in theym onely by hym selfe / thys false opynyon is as the kyngys hyghnes moste vertuo â¢ sly wryteth in hys epystle to Luther / the most abomynable heresye yt euer was. And surely it is so far agaynst all holy scrypture well vnderstanden / so farre agaynst all naturall reason / so vtterly subuertyng all vertue and all good order in the world / so hyghly blasphemiÌg the goodnes and maieste of almyghty god in heuen / that yt is more than woÌ der how eny man erthely that hath eyther one sparke of wyt in hys hed / or toward god or man one droppe of good wyll in his harte / shold not abhorre to here yt. For thys execrable heresye maketh god the cause of all euyl / and such cruell appetyte as neuer tyrannte and tormentour had / ascrybe they to the benygne nature of almyghty god. For where as our â¢ auyour Cryst toke vppoÌ hym self all our syn / and of hys endles pytye bare the payne of theym for our sake / this dampnable heresye holdeth / that god shold be fyrst so vntrew that he sholde laye vnto vs the wyght and blame of hys owne fawtys / that ys to wyt the euyll workys whyche as they say be not wrought by vs but in vs by god / and therunto they make hym so dyspy â¢ uouse & cruell / that for hys own dedê­ so done he shold haue a perpetual delyte & plesure to tormeÌt vs. Now turne they yâ¢ trya â¢ le of holy scripture quyte in to poysoÌ. For this false errour onys takeÌ for treuth / wherof sholde all scrypture serue? wherof shold serue ye exhortacyoÌs to good workis yf men neyther eny do / nor eny can do / neyther of theÌ self nor wyth helpe of grace? or yf eny be done by them whych be not chosen / theyr dedys be not accepted of god / bycause he hath not choseÌ theyr persons / wherof shall serue the prechyngys and exhortacyoÌs to the fayth / yf the herers haue no lyb â¢ rtye of theyre owne wyll / by which they may together with goddys grace laboure to submytte and subdue the rebellyon of theyr reson to the obedyence of fayth and credence of the worde of god? wherof shall serue all ye dehortacyons and coÌmynacyons and threttys in scrypture / by which god calleth men froÌ synne and euyll workys / yf the world were onys of mynde that they byleued after Luther / that no maÌ doth eny euyll dede hym selfe / but god doth theym all hym selfe. And that euery man ys eyther chosen or vnchosen. And yf we be of the chosen sorte / none euyll dede can dampne vs. And yf we be of the vnchosen sorte / no good dede can auayle vs. He that thus byleueth / what careth he what he doth / excepte for the fere of temporall lawys of this worlde. And yet yf hys false faythe he strong / he forceth lytell of theym also. For he shall thynke dyenge in hys bed or on the galows / cometh not after his deseruyng but hangethall vppon destenye. And therfore all lawys they set at nought. And they hold that no man ys bounden to obay â¢ eny / but wold be at lybertye to byleue what they lyst / and do what they lyst / as they say that god doth with vs not what we deserue but what hymselfe ly â¢ te.

Â¶Wherof shall reason serue yf maÌ had no power of hym selfe toward the dyreccyon of hys owne workys / but that all our workys were brought forth of vs wythout oure wyll / worse than the workys be in dede out of a brute best / by the appetyte of his sensuall macyoÌ /
For oures sholde be by thys opynyon brought forth / as the leues come out of yâ¢ tre / or as a stone falleth downward / and the smoke vpwarde by the power of nature / so sholde I say all our dedys good or bad ascende or descende by the vyolent hand of god magre our myndys and thus ye bestys be not ashamed to say / whaÌ they preue howrly by theyr owne experyence in theym selfe / that whan they wyll do a thyng they do yt. And vndowtedly amonge men these takers awaye of fre wyll maye neuer auoyde that answer by reason. But than fall the wretches to the desperate wayes of deuyls and dampned sowlys. ThaÌ fall they to raylyng and reprouyng the iustyce of god & say that hym selfe he wrought theyr euyll workys / and wrongfully punysshed theym / and cruelly created theym to wrechednes. Our mother Eue layd the wyght of her synne to the serpent / and god was offeÌded that she toke not her owne parte to her selfe. div.p: Â¶That pryncys be bounden to punyshe heretyques / & that fayre handelyng helpeth lytell wyth many of theym.

HAd surely as the priÌcys be bouÌ den yt they shall not suffer theyr peple by infydelys to be inuaded / so be they as depely bounden that they shall not suffer theyre people to be seduced & corrupted by heretyques / syth ye parell shall in short whyle growe to as grete bothe wyth mennys sowles wythdrawen from god / and theyr goodys lost / and theyr bodyes destroyed by comeÌ sedycyon / insurreccion / and open warre / wythin the bowellys of theyre owne lande. All whyche maye in the begynnyng be ryght â¢ asely auoyded / by punyshment of those few that be ye fyrste. whyche few well repressed / or yf nede so requyre vtterly pulled vp / there shal fa â¢â¢â¢ the fewer haue lyste to folowe. For yf they were handled in a contrary maner / & as ye semed to mene in the begynning of our mater / in s â¢ ede of punyshmeÌt / ent â¢ eted / fauored / & by fayre wordys and rewardys brought home agayns / I fere me then that ye sholde fynde ly â¢â¢ ll f â¢â¢ yte in that fas â¢ yon. For fy â¢â¢â¢ where as they fall in to heresy â¢ by pryd â¢ /that way wolde make them pro â¢â¢ der / & set ye more by theÌ selfe. And ãâã wold many mo fall therto / of purpo â¢â¢
ãâ¦ã agayn ãâã . So yt a â¢ maÌmolukê­ & genysaryes about ye tur â¢ e a â¢â¢ sowdeyn haue vsed ãâã crysteÌ theyr ãâ¦ã
theyr fayth after / they myght be made maÌ molukes or genysaryes as theyr fathers were / and may be had in ye more estymacyoÌ and fauour about the grete turke / euen lyke wyse wythin a whyle yf we take that way wyth heretyques we shall haue yong fresh felowes fyrst bycome heretyques / that they maye be prayed & hyred after to com to Crystys fayth agayne. I wolde not they were ouer hastely handled / but lytel rygour and myche mercy shewed where symplenes appered and not hygh hart or malyce. For of suche as be prowde and malycyouse / myche profe hathe bene made all redy. For of some sorte many full fayre handled / lytell chauÌ ge theym self or come to good amendement. I tolde you my selfe and very true yt was of twayne that were detected of heresye vnto the moost honorable prela â¢ e of this realme / & in what benygne fatherly maner and lyberall also he delt wyth them. And yet what amendement made hys gentyll & courteyse intretye / in theyre stoburne stomake? were they not after worse then they were byfore? and so vsed themself that after myche harme done by them / the came in shorte space after to theyr open coÌuyccyon? They be ye wo â¢ e wel at ye fyrst custumably receyued to grace / & veryly that for such merytys / forgyuenes ys rewarde ynoughe. And yf they can not by that warnyng be war
â¢ ed / surely as saynt Powle saythe he ys not to be trusted ofteÌ / but rather of all good crysten peple to be eschewed & auoyded from the flokke. For they be so f â¢â¢ waxeÌ croked / that seld â¢ me can they be â¢ yghted agayne.

Â¶Forsoth quod youre frende yet as I sayd at my fyrst ãâã to you / ãâã I worthy to be of counsayll wyth the clergye when there were a man founden fawtye therin / whome the people haue in good estymacion for som grete opynyon of lernynge and vertue / they shold be secretely & soberly monysshed / and not the mater publyshed among ye peple. And fynally yf they so shold nedys be openly conuented and corrected in face of the world / th â¢ n wold I not yet haue theÌ called Lutheranys / lest yâ¢ peple whych had good opynyon of theÌ / or yf they happen to perceyue theym for nought and so take them / thaÌ shall they peraduenture gyue the lesse credence to all good men / and set the lesse by all good precheours after.

Â¶Surely quod I certayne rule that were alway best / were hard to gyue in suche case. Somtyme there may peraduenture suche honestye be ioyned wyth such repentaunce / that yt wolde not be myche a mysse to preserue the mannys estymacion among the peple / to whom hys perfayts chaung, may per â¢ as more than recompence hys for more erroure and ouersyght. But where as the contrary shall seme conuenyent / there can I not se â¢ why we sholde forbere to tall theym Lutheranys / syth yt is both an olde vsage to call heretyques after the name of hym whoÌ they folow in theyr heresye / and also as Luthers sect ys in effecte the hole hepe of all heresyes gathered together / yt ys nowe all one to call hym â¢ Lutherans or to call hym a â¢ heretyque / â¢ hose ãâã beyng in ãâã equyualent Luther techyng all must nothynge but heresyes / nor ãâ¦ã
name of Lutheranys shold be custumably brought in meÌnys erys as adyou â¢ e as the name of heretyques. Nor I se not so grete fere that ryther folke shall for opynyon of eny mannys vertue in whom they se theym self deceyued / wt drawe theyr fauoure and affeccyon froÌ such as are good in dede / or fall in to ye fauour of Luthers secte for thestymacyon of the maÌ whom they now se pre
â¢ ed nought. For thys wyll no man do but suche as eyther be so folyshe yt they wolde hate all Crystys appostles for ye falshede of Iudas / or so noughty that thy wold fayne haue all the world fall to the same sect & be of theyr own s â¢ yt.

div.head: Â¶The .xvi. chapyter.
div.p: Â¶Of symple vnlerned folke yt are deceyuyd by the great good opynyoÌ that they haue per â¢ as in the lerning and lyuyng of some that teche them errours.

FOrsothe quod youre frende yet wold there me thinketh â¢ e mich pytye vsed in those maters among. For many a man vnlerned when he hereth one that he taketh for cunnyng / & freth such a man as he taketh for vertuous / coÌmend Luthers way / he ys of symplenes and good mynde moued to folowe ye same. Â¶Surely quod I therin I say not nay but that these thyngys beyng such / grete pytye yt ys to se many good symple sowlys deceyued and led out of the tyght way by the authoryte of such as they reken for good men and c â¢ nnyng / whom they haue eyther by open sermons or secrete coÌmunycacyon perceyued ãâã fauourers of that vngracyous se â¢â¢ /thynkyng that men of such c â¢ nnyng and knowlege in ãâã /beyng therwyth of ãâ¦ã be â¢ hauour as they ãâ¦ã to that waye / but yf they knew â¢ yt fo â¢ good. And surely wher it so happeneth that eny symple sowle ys by the good opynyon that he hathe in hys mayster led out of the ryght bylyef of ye fayth / wenynyg yt w â¢ re ye very fayth whych he seeth hys mayster whoÌ he rekeneth good & cuÌnynge folow and lene vnto / yt ys a very pyttous thynge. And as ye person ys lesse in blame & more easely cured / so ys that mayster double dampned / as the cause both of hys owne syn & hys ye foloweth hym / and very hard ys he to mend. How be yt somtyme we deserue wyth our synne that god for ye punyshmeÌt therof / suffreth vs to haue lewd leders and euyll techers. And surely for the more part such as be ledde out of ye ryght way / do rather fall ther to of a lewd lyghtenesse of theyr owne mynde / then for eny grete thynge that moueth theym in theyre mayster that techeth theym. For we se theym as redy to byleue a purser a glouer or a weuer that nothynge can do but scantely rede englysh / as well as they wold byleue the wysest and the best lerned doctour in a realme. How be yt be a man neuer so wel lerned / and seme he neuer so vertuouse / yet can we wyth no reason excuse our selfe / yf we leue ye ryght byleue for ye trust that we ha â¢ e in eny man erthely. For our byleue ys taught vs by god surely planted in the chyrch of Cryst / & thartycles therof not newe byg â¢â¢ /but now contynued many an hundred y â¢â¢ e in the grete congregacyoÌ of crysten peple / as thyngys certayne / sure / & stable / and out of all questyon / ãâã n â¢ ne heretyque doth or can denye / and in the hartys of thys congregacyon ãâã th â¢ y wryten by ye holy hand ãâ¦ã
â¢ s he that thorow hys trust put in eny man / byleueueth the contrary of eny poynt yt the chyrche of Cryst ys taught to byleue by god.

Â¶Thys fayth was taught by Cryste / preched by hys apostles / of thys wrote hys euangely â¢â¢ es / & many mo thynge were taught thaÌ are wryten. And thys fayth sholde haue ben taught and fermely standen / all though nothyng had ben wryten. And the artycles of thys fayth had in meÌnis hartys / be the iust & sure rulys of construccyon by whyche we constre & vnderstand the holy scrypture yt ys wryteÌ. For very sure are we yt who so wold constre eny text of holy scrypture / in suche wyse as he wolde make yt seme contrary to eny poynt of thys catholyke fayth whych god hath taught hys chyrch / he gyueth the scrypture a wrong senteÌce / & therby techeth a wrong byleue. And as saynt Poule sayth cursed be he and though he were an aungell of heuen. And therfore be we not excusable yf we byleue eny maÌ to the coÌtrary of ye fayth / how good or how cuÌning so euer he seme / whyle we se yt he techeth vs a wrong way whych we may sone know yf we be good crysteÌ and know the bylyef all redy.

Â¶And we maye haue also a grete gesse therat / yf he teche vs secretely as a pryuy mystery / the doctryne that he wold not were vtteryd and shewed openly. For suche thyngys be they comonly yt these herety â¢ u â¢ s teche in â¢ uc â¢ er mur
â¢ er / agaynst ye fayth yt al the chyrch byleueth. Now ãâã I gyue thys counsayle to euery vnlerned man / whaÌ eny man so techeth the whom thou â¢ a â¢â¢ in grete â¢â¢â¢ im â¢ cioÌ for vertue or cunning / th â¢
Ì coÌsyder iÌ thy self yt he neyther hath more ãâ¦ã /thaÌ had saynt Austayn / saynt Hierome / saynt Ambrose / saiÌt Gregory / saiÌt Cypryan / saynt Chrisosteme / wyth many old fathers and holy doctours whyche byleued all theyr dayes & dyed in ye bylyefe that thou byleuest all redy / wherof he techeth the contrary. And so say boldely to hym than yf he wold begyle the. And say yt those holy doctours byleued not as thou dost / but as he sayth bryng hym to ye rekenynge byfore some other good and wel lerned men. And I dare be bold to warraunt yt thou shalt fynde hym dowble false. For neyther shalte thou fynd it true yt he told the / & bysydê­ yt he shall not let to bylye the / sayng & sweriÌg to yt thou sayest wrong on hym / and that he neuer told the so.

Â¶Mary syr q your freÌd he wyll haply say yt he were peradueÌture in ye poynte to be pa â¢ doned / bycawse of ye ieopardy yt he might fall in to by ye mayntenauÌce of his â¢ pynyoÌ. Â¶PardoÌ hym yf yt wyl q I. But yet ys he not than so good as were those good fathers. For eyther ys hys way nought / & thaÌ doth he nought to teche yt / or yf he be good / than is he nought / that for eny fere forsaketh yt. For he yt forsaketh eny trouth of Crystê­ fayth / forsaketh Cryst. And thaÌ sayth our s â¢ uyour that who so doth / shall be forsaken of hym. And he that so dothe ys not to be byleued lyke those holy fathers / which haue taught vs fat ye
â¢ rrary. For they did abyde by ye right faith that they taught / which is as by theyr bokys appereth / the selfe same fayth yt thou byleuest. And so ferforth abydde they therby / that dyuers of them susteyned grete persecucyon therfore / & some of theym deth & martyrdome. So that we were more th â¢â¢ madde yf we had ãâ¦ã send our sowlys to ye sowlys
of those holy fathers / of whose cuÌnyng vertue / and saluacyon / we be sure / thaÌ to caste theym away wyth these folke / whych how holy so euer they seme / yet shew theÌ self nought / in yt they teche ye contrary of suche thyngis as those vndowted holy doctours taught.

Â¶I meruayle theÌ quod your frend why they lyue so vertuously / fastynge & gyuynge theyre good in almoyse / wyth other vertuouse exercyse / both in forberynge the pleasure of the worlde / and also takynge payne in theyre bodyes. Â¶To thys mater quod I our fauyoure hym self answereth where he sayth in the gospell of Mathew / Attendite a falsis prophetis qui veniunt ad vos in vestimentis ouium / intrinsecus a â¢ tem sunt lupi rapaces. Beware of the false prophetys that come to you in the clothynge of shepe / and yet wythinforth ben rauenouse wolues. For syth yt they by false doctryne labour to deuour and destroye meÌ soulys / we be sure ynough that wolues they be in dede / how â¢ hepyshely so euer they loke. And ypocrytys must they nedys be / syth they be so denounced by goddys owne mouthe. And well may we perceyue that he meneth not well / whaÌ he techeth euyll. And that euyll he techeth we may wel wyt / whaÌ we se hym teche ye coÌtrary of ye whych god hath all redy taught hys hole chyrch. In which hath beÌ so many holy fathers so many cuÌning doctours and so many blessyd martyrs / yt so haue byddeÌ by ye faythe to yâ¢ dethe / yâ¢ yt were a â¢â¢ enesye / yf we wold n â¢ w agaynst so many such byleue eny false heretyque & faynynge ypocryte / techynge vs the coÌtrary. Â¶Of those holy fathers of our fayth whom theyre bokys sheweth to haue byleued vs we byleue / we haue sene and knowen theyr vertuouse lyfe well proued by theyre blyssed ende / in whych our lorde hath testyfyed by many a myracle / yt theyr fayth & theyr lyuys hath lyked him. But now haue we yet sene eny such thyng by eny of these heretyques. Nor yet so myche as eny const â¢ unce in theyr doctryne / but & yf they were onys found out and examyned / we se theym alwaye fyrst redy to lye and forswere theÌ self yf ye wyl serue And whaÌ that wyl not helpe but theyr falsed and periury proued in theyre facys / than redy be they to abiure & forsake it / as long as that may saue theyr lyuys. Nor neuer yet fouÌd I eny one / but he wold onys abiure though he neuer entended to k â¢ pe his othe. So holy wold he be and so wyse therwith / that he wolde wyth periury kyll hys sowle for euer / to saue hys body for a whyle â¢ For comenly sone after suche as so do / shewe theym selfe agayne / god of hys ryghtuousnes not suffryng yâ¢ theyr fals forswering shold stand theÌ loÌg in stede.

div.head: Â¶The .xvii. chapyter.
div.p: Â¶The author sheweth yâ¢ som which be Lutheranys & seme to lyue holyly / and therfore be byleued & had in estymacyon / entende a ferther purpose them they pretend / whych they wyll well shewe yf they may onys fynde theyr tyme.

ANd as for theyre lyuynge / the good apparence wherof ys the thyng that most blyndeth vs / as mych suretye as we haue of the godly lyfe of our olde holy fathers / wherof yâ¢ world hath wryten / and god h â¢ th borne wytnes by many grete myracles shewed for theyr sakes / as vncertayn be we of these men / wyth whom we neyther he alway pre â¢ ent / and ãâã also can tell
what abomynacyoÌs they may do to suÌ of theÌ secretely. Nor yet caÌ know theyr enteÌt & purpose that they appoynt vpoÌ and ye cause for whyche they be for the whyle coÌtent to take all the payne.

Â¶Uery certayne ys yt ye pryde ys one cause wherfore they take the payn. For p â¢ yde ys as saynt Austeyn sayth / ye very mother of all heresyes. For of an hygh mynd to be in ye lykiÌg of ye peple / â¢ hath cuÌmyn in to many men so mad a mynde & so frantyque / yt they haue not rought what payn they toke wtout eny other recoÌpence or rewarde / but only ye fond plesure & delyte yt theÌ self coÌceyue in theyr harte / whaÌ they thynke what worshyp ye peple talketh of them. And they be ye deuyls martyrs / takiÌg myche payn for his pleasure / & his very a pys / whoÌ he maketh to tuÌble thorow ye hope of ye holynes yt putteth theÌ to payne wt out fruyte. And yet ofteÌtymes maketh theÌ mys â¢ e of ye vayn prayse wherof only they be so prowde. For whyle they delyte to thynke how they be take for holy / they be many tymys wel perceyued and taken for ypocrytys as they be.

Â¶But suche ys thys cursed affeccyoÌ of pryde / and so depe setteth in ye clawys where yt catcheth / ye hard yt ys to pull theÌ out. This pryde hath ere this made suÌ lerned meÌ to deuyse newe fantysyes in our fayth / bycause they wold be syn
â¢ ular among the people / as dyd Irrius Faustus Pelagyan & dyuers other old heretyques whose false opynyoÌs haue â¢ en long tyme passed opeÌly coÌdempned by many holy synodes & generall couÌ sayles / â¢ now god be thanked not only theyr opynyons quenched / but also all theyr bokê­ clene gone & vanyshed quye away / ere euer eny law was made for such bokys burniÌg. So yt yt well appereth to haue beÌ ye only worke of god yt hath destroyed those workys / whyc â¢ e wrought in theyr tymys myche harme in hys chyrch. Thys affeccyoÌ of pryde hath not only made som lerned men to bryng forth new faÌtasyes / but maketh also many men of mich lesse thaÌ meane lerniÌg so sore to long to seme far better lerned thaÌ they be / yt to make the peple haue theÌ in authoryte / they de â¢ yse new sectys & scysmys to the pleasure of new fangle folk / sparyng no payne for the whyle to set forth theyre sect wythall / rewardynge theyr labour wyth onely delyte of beholdyng what pleasure the people haue in theyr prechyng.

Â¶And albeyt yt thys fraÌtyque pleasure wyth wyche ye deuyll inwardly fedeth theÌ / be yâ¢ onely thyng yt satysfyed & coÌ teÌteth som / yet many are ther of those yâ¢ euyl techeth & appere holy / whych are bothe secretely more lose & voluptuou â¢â¢ then they seme. And some also whyche warely kepe theÌ selfe for ye whyle / entend towarde more lyberall lewdnesse at length. Wyll ye se ensample therof? loke on Tyndall yt translated ye newe testament / whyche was in dede (as ye sayd in ye begynniÌg) byfore hys goyng ouer / takeÌ for a man of sober & honeste lyuing / & loked & preched holyly / sauiÌg yt yet somtyme it sauored so shrewdly / yt he was onys or twyse examyned therof. But yet bycause he glosed then hys wordys wyth a better sente / & sayde â¢ sware yt he meÌt none harme / folk were glad to take all to the beste. But yet ys se yt though he dys â¢ embled hym selfe to to be a Lutherane or to bete eny fauor to hys secte whyle he was here / yet as sone as he gate hym heÌse / he gate hym to Luther straygh â¢ .
